qoBja9QwQHFR2jaDvRe_hw.text: The fried green tomatoes were outstanding. The other food was just alright. The voodoo pasta was watery and the shrimp tasted frozen, not fresh. The service wasn't very good and the restaurant was not crowded at all. We never got offered more drinks or checked up on. We would came back for the fried green tomatoes and sit at the bar.

kkFgEVFbzd7eDehoqMc0gw.text: ow, I was really blown away at NOLA at Market Square. This place was recommended to me by a work associate complimenting the food. I walked in to a busy bar that seemed lively. Come to find it was a pub crawl that stopped crawling. I ordered the squash and pumpkin soup ($6) with the Shrimp and Grits ($27).   I Thought is was very pricey but I don't mind if the quality is up to par. The atmosphere is very authentic to NOLA but that's where the similarities stop. The soup arrived in seconds and was bitter and salty, obviously it had been reducing for days, which was upsetting because squash and pumpkin soup is usually sweet, warm and delicious. The bartender offered to get me something else so I tried the french onion soup. It took 10 minutes, the cheese was nicely baked but the soup had little onions, it was very salty, and the bread was a gel.   At this point I was scared to see the shrimp and grits. And as expected the dish was unrecognizable from my Cajun experience. The grits were served as a cake bar which was not seasoned topped with a watery sauce that had congealed under the lamps. The celery was raw and crunchy. This was garnished with inedible garnish "to offset the color". Which is sorely needed as the color was disgusting.   I spoke to the manager who apologized but was unwilling to try the food and didn't seem interested in my opinion. He told me this was a Pittsburgh take on shrimp and grits. And he assured me others like it and removed everything from the bill. I left hungry and unhappy with the managers attitude. If they cared about quality or service the manager would have addressed the poor food immediately.  I feel sorry for everyone there that has to stomach that blemish on Cajun cuisine. In the future listen to customers and if you're going for Cajun in Pittsburgh keep it authentic!

RfX21xiiavA32bBlIYyZuQ.text: Went here for lunch and was thoroughly impressed. Service was quick, friendly and very good. We had gumbo soup, fried green tomatoes, po' boys (shrimp and oyster) with fries. The shrimp had a great batter though it was unseasoned. Paired with this sandwiches is a 'pepper jam' that is well balanced as consists of honey and chili pepper. Absolutely amazing jam that could go with a number of items. The shrimp was a good size and tasted fresh. The seasoned fries were also very good. I'll definitely be returning.   Nola is also a Yelp Cash Back participant, so you'll get 7% of your meal cost sent back to you in cash, as long as you sign up on Yelp for the program.

F8ilmtG-YbIc8aAwdIGNuw.text: NOLA is wonderfully located in Market Square.  And it has decent food and great bartender service.  Valet parking is great.  But keep the receipt as we were ticketed by Pittsburgh for not parking .... even though we paid the valet service....   NOLA refused to allow for reservations in the "bar area" for watching/viewing bands.  We used to go about 2 hours early to wedge our way forward toward the performers.  But the management's view is not conducive to getting decent seating.  We have been there before and told to "wait" at the bar, then others come in and get band row seating.... (secret handshake?).  We used to call the manager over and ask for decent seating.... "maybe."  My party of 8 decided, after this call to reservations today before 1 pm, to go elsewhere as we told there could be no assigned/reserved seating toward the band(s).  But others come in and are seated....   Sigh.  There are so much better Pittsburgh venues for appreciating music, and having seating/reservation service.    Amusingly, BJ's in Wexford doesn't take reservations per se but puts one on a priority list for seating depending on traffic.  And they discuss the options and timing of arrival.  Stunningly different customer experience.    Fred.

jtXI1P7KxMFXjf9iiK8OQQ.text: Love the atmosphere.  Had a fun jazz band Friday night came back saturday to eat.   Had Voodoo pasta with blacked catfish tryed 2 specialty drinks. Both yummy.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

TXyJCdiYoS__ReGm9EEKOA.text: Food was not good! The staff was very polite but the food was awful! I had shrimp and grits and the grits were very grainy and soupy. I'm from the south and this is not the shrimp and grits I'm accustomed to. My son had the shrimp Po boy and said it was ok.

mOTq9L15hxSFVb5OpEeIYQ.text: My wife and I went here on a date night. I ordered the jambalaya and while eating it found coal or charred wood in it. Not sure how it got in there but it really killed my appetite. The server was amazing and apologized for the mistake and offered to have it remade but i was no longer hungry. It wasn't one of those situations where a customer eats the majority of the meal then sends it back. I was only a couple bites in. My wife said her meal was okay but nothing special. (I think she got the voodoo pasta). In the end, my meal was removed from the bill, my wife had no complaints but no praise, and our waiter was so extremely nice. Overall, I was hoping this place would be a frequent spot of ours since the uber ride is so cheap since we don't live far, but I don't think we will be heading back.

7vw7J778ruRBs6g8uakCAw.text: Lovely venue inside and out from the decor, ambiance, pleasant waitstaff, menu options, and taste.  It's much bigger inside than the entrance would lead you to believe.  The inside seating is very charming and atmosphere very soothing.  I have to admit to not being a huge Cajun menu fan but there are plenty of options.  I selected the Seafood Mac Daddy and the portion size and flavors all hit the spot with lobster, shrimp, pasta, and plenty of great cheese taste.    It was such a nice walk from here to Heinz Hall, as well.    I'd definitely choose this place for a nice date night, anytime.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Seafood mac daddy
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Seafood jambalaya

w8baCOr5qz5dlhA20zLzbg.text: On a busy night on the square it may be your only choice...food is sub par.  Rice in my gumbo was hard/uncooked....the catfish meal was $20 & it wasn't anything I'll ever remember, other than it was $20. The beignets are a total joke, not even close to a beignet...if you're lookin' to find NOLA food in Pittsburgh, you won't find it here. Gross sticky tables too.

zrdyemlF0mdlLTrHLfB0Vg.text: Had a couple great experiences here! The live jazz on Friday night is great.  Returned the next night for dinner and was not disappointed. The red beans and rice were seasoned wonderfully...add the shrimp!  You won't regret it.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Nola salad

-0AdXhQqSGlwSbuKOMImug.text: This was our first time at Nola. We ordered the alligator appetizer, which was plenty for two to share and had a nice tasty sauce that came with it. I wasn't crazy about th appetizer but it wasn't too bad. I also got the chicken and dumplings for my meal for the first time and it was delicious. It was also very filling so I would definitely get this meal again! We were seated right away on a Saturday night and had no wait.

fJQCGPm7rnz1PNuFU0JdSA.text: Step into Nola and suddenly you're transported directly to New Orleans. The decor here is so charming and inspired entirely by the city. The color scheme is all purples and greens, and there are many historic touches such as a beautifully detailed ceiling. You almost forget that you're still in Pittsburgh!  The staff here is fantastic. My boyfriend and I enjoyed our waiter who was very personable and talkative with us. He even gave us pointers for some of his other favorite restaurants in the city that we should try out.  We started with the red beans and rice as an appetizer, which were so packed full of flavor I couldn't even believe it! You won't find a bland dish on the menu here. I had the shrimp and grits for my entree, and they were the best shrimp and grits I have ever had. The presentation was stunning (see the photo below), and I talked my boyfriend's ear off about how delicious it was for basically the entire time I was eating it. For dessert we shared this phenomenal chocolate and caramel cake that was also expertly decorated. I highly recommend the food here. It is on the more pricey side, but in my opinion is absolutely worth the price. This is a great place for a date night or special occasion. I have always wanted to travel to New Orleans and have never been able to, so I'm thrilled that I have such a delicious and authentic creole restaurant right here in Pittsburgh!

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Royal Street Blues martini, and the Gumbo and Red Beans and Rice (both $1 during happy hour)!
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. $5 flatbread at happy hour. Red peppers, green peppers, sweet onions, cheese, Brussels sprouts leaves, and bacon. SO GOOD!
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Our chocolate caramel cake, which was presented beautifully.

K4oj4gggo9DGbA3yfMbJ8Q.text: Stopped by tonight with my friend and sister for drinks during happy hour. The drinks were large and mixed perfectly. We ordered the pierogis, stuffed mushrooms and margarita pizza. All of of them were really good! Our server was very attentive. It was a very good time. Definitely somewhere I would return to check out dinner service!

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

jmKjvnRssvmJmAhvCCqgag.text: I went with a friend on a Friday for dinner and drinks. They had a live blues band playing at the time. We sat toward the front of the restaurant to be near, and it was super loud. Of course we didn't complain since we wanted to sit there, but others further back did.   Unfortunately, the quality of the food and drinks were bad. We ordered fried green tomatoes, frog legs, brisket sliders (on special), and crawfish flatbread. The tomatoes came out first, well before anything else - they were very bland. So about 20-25 minutes later the other appetizers came out with an additional plate of tasteless tomatoes. They advised the additional plate was on the house for the wait. Now for the frog legs... They were prepared differently than describes on the menu. Instead of being breaded, they came out in a broth... This was also very bland. The crawfish flatbread was soggy/slimy, but the brisket sliders were okay. They were dry, but the only decent item that we had. For a Cajun/Creole restaurant, the food was disappointing. The drinks were also very disappointing. We were going to order actual entrees, but given the quality that night - we opted out of that.   At least the service was good. The waitress brought us everything we asked for, and came to check on us often.  The last time I was at Nola the food was very good, but that was a couple years ago. Not sure what happened, but I won't be visiting Nola again any time soon...

ztlPYVPdbJ5z0hxLSaTdnQ.text: The staff is top drawer. We had a large party arrive at prime time dinner hours with no advance notice and still got a wonderful table. It was a spur of the moment thing. The place was packed, and I was worried we would have to go elsewhere, but, no, NOLA was up for this challenge. We were assigned a feisty, diligent waitress who was everything you want in a server and were treated like royalty. 5 stars.  The food was not as sensational but agreeable. I started with the alligator tail appetizer--it was compromised to a certain extent as the batter had too much chili pepper--made it difficult to taste the meat. Once I pulled off the batter, the alligator was tender and of good quality.   We all shared our various main courses a la family style--so got to taste a lot of NOLA's entrees in one visit. Steak marchand de vin was excellent; blackened catfish was respectable; chicken and dumplings was below average; and seafood jambalaya had way too much heat (and was even ordered less spicy). Also partook of the NOLA salad and the smokey caesar salad and both were just okay. Nothing jumped out at me in terms of the desserts.  It's a fun spot with lots of charm and gaiety. There is live music, and that is a very nice feature however it was almost too loud for us. Perhaps reducing the decibel level during peak dinner hours might be a consideration.    NOLA is a place where "laissez les bon temps rouler" is for real.

h882dl7h4azyGoqf2BsYkA.text: My wife and I both had excellent meals at this restaurant. I had the grilled catfish which was perfectly spiced over mashed potatoes. I asked the waiter to make s suggestion between the catfish and the voodoo pasta and he recommended the catfish. Great choice. My wife had the special which was a seafood pot pie and she raved after every bite This dining experience was so good that I sought out the manager on the way out and thanked her for the way her staff performed.

QziwPOfS5od2XtvSYwAkKw.text: An update on NOLA that evening.... The manager ended up comping what we had ordered prior to us leaving, which was the right thing to do.

fG-r9_IjhrxNwozcFuxwRA.text: Stopped by for lunch and ordered the gumbo and the Chef's special, blackened red snapper sandwich. The gumbo had a nice flavor and color to it but I prefer a little thicker soup then this was.  It was also very short on meat and veggies.  Mostly broth and slightly undercooked rice. The sandwich was pretty good, slightly on the salty side but nicely cooked and nicely presented. Overall, nice menu, average food, good service and pretty cool atmosphere.  I'd try the place again.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Blackened Red Snapper Sandwich
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Gumbo
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

xsRj0Wz8xK-9-n34I1C4UQ.text: I used to really like NOLA, but I have had very poor stomach reactions (of food poisoning-degree) to the food twice now.  I know that others have as well.  My staple used to be the oyster stew but I think that this might have been the two-time culprit.    I think generally the quality of the food has gone down.  Still a decent place for a drink, though.    I also think that the floors are generally really dirty, and this is a huge turnoff.    My suggestion, if you're looking for a good place to eat in Market Square, go to Sienna or Il Pizzaiolo.  In the beginning, NOLA was a novel idea (although not even authentically New Orleans cuisine).  The novelty just wore off.

ztbBUVNDU8kZ70unxvYaiw.text: Clean restaurant, pretty attentive server, and pretty good food. Everything was slightly above average but nothing too exceptional.   The flatbread was a little ton heavy for my liking but I really like the fish of the day that we got. Yuuuuuum

GYnYrEkb3tRx-VIMogbI7g.text: Nice for lunch and dinner, and fast enough for a work lunch.   I got the Heirloom Tomato & Wood Roasted Corn salad with salmon added; delicious! The spiced watermelon and pickled radish in the salad are so good - never had watermelon or radish that way.   Service was quick, and we sat at a hightop near the open terrace.   They serve yaka mein, which I saw on Anthony Bourdain or Andrew Zimmern (I forget) once, which I am definitely going to try soon.

cFqTHfmdcZxjrvnYzrXUoQ.text: A taste of Nawlins on Market Sq? Close...  Although the drink menu was extensive the actually menu was a bit limited and wordy.  I'm all for describing your foods but, to who's determent?    I had the fried shrimp which was delicious but, became a bit too much about the 5th shrimp.  My dining companions all loved their food and drinks but, would have loved a bit more variety when it came to actual dishes.

Hl8mhpszbUgfg2RefM5SWw.text: Came here with a group of twelve and had a great experience. Service was friendly, food came out rather quickly and everything was delicious. I got the Cajun catfish and loved it, it was cooked well and the potatoes were seasoned perfectly. We also got the jumbalya, steak frites, shrimp and grits, flatbread as well as the Mac cheese. Everyone was sharing and loving their meals, and all but some of the rice for the jumbalya (quite a large portion) was gone!  The appetizers were a little on the small side, but they were also delicious! We got the alligator and some shrimp something. Yum!

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Steak Frites
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Cajun Catfish

VgRDFRwXcbu6ERqJr4ftvw.text: Went here for lunch and had the crab cake.  It was really well cooked and not too heavy. The waitress was really friendly and the atmosphere was pretty laid back for downtown lunch. It didn't take very long to get our food.

CJ3Rn_38yQVBBs9H9kflvw.text: Ok food but the service was ridiculously bad. Don't waste your time - and it will be a lot of time. We were seated for over 1 hour before our food came and it wasn't even busy! Waitress had such an attitude when we inquired pleasantly about when we would be getting our food. Never say never, but almost never going back there. Too many great alternatives to waste your time or money there!

p9TCOL27geBs69beNWf00w.text: I came here with my cousin and friend and we had EXCEPTIONAL service. Everyone was really nice and our food was great. I love the atmosphere and the warm ambiance. Their fries are the bomb diggity, no doubt!!

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. At NOLA on the Square.

aQuCdjZkhw34Z_ODeoy76A.text: I have been to NOLA two times both around lunch time and both times we had amazing experiences.  We had flatbreads to start.  They are SO yummy!  I had the shrimp and grits both times we were there.  They are SO good I actually crave them!  I am not one for spicy in food but they add just the right amount of heat to them.  The Beneigts were just amazing!  We had terrific service!  We will DEFINITLEY return for the shrimp and grits!  Oh, and the atmosphere is sublime!

Kqk0BTA5teH3wnBSVUraTg.text: Wonderful taste of New Orleans cuisine. The hush puppies and the sauce they were served with were very filling. By the time my flatbread ($9) arrived, which was big enough to split as an entree, I had it wrapped to take home. I had to have beniegts wrapped to go fo dessert as well. That was a huge portion, big enough for two to share. They were still warm when we got home. Four, palm-sized, light beniegts coated with powdered sugar, served with sorbet. My husband ordered a cup of gumbo and the featured dinner-blackened kobia (fish) with roasted peaches, chantrel mushrooms, and corn served on endive leaves. (see  picture) Service was excellent, tables were available inside and on the sidewalk out front. Had to wash it down with an Abita brew. Looking forward to our next visit.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Kobia with roasted peaches,  chantrel mushrooms, and corn served on endive.

XJx2A_rjDi9H6YM_H6-RCg.text: Market Square is a very nice spot for a plethora of options to choose from for food. NOLA has a great vibe inside. I had the Jambalaya, and it was very good.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. A creole restaurant with a god vibe and great beer selection.

V3TeQBL4Rfyfail5BIjzGg.text: As good of a restaurant as I have ever eaten at. The food was amazing, the service was excellent. I ate here two nights in a row and it was amazing both nights. First night, Shrimp and Grits and an amazing waiter named Chris. Tonight, Venison Chili, Seafood Jambalaya and a free beer. I'm eating 2500 miles away from home and feel like I'm having dinner in my dining room. Too cool.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Seafood Jambalaya. Yum

9ugMrZuffJJhd-iLqVlaqw.text: The food is good. BUT the waiting time is insanely long!! We waited for an hour for the entree to be served on a Sunday morning.

atfvRq2Jx-1B8nPcGYoPtw.text: I'll try NOLA again, but I have to say my first experience was less than stellar.  We had a reservation but sat for 45 minutes at the bar waiting for them to get us a table.  I went up to them about 30 minutes in to see if they had forgotten us and got a confused look and finally a yes, we have you on the list.   They never seated us and never came around to offer alternatives or anything.  There were open tables.  Finally, we left and ate elsewhere.  Beyond the service, there was loud music--too loud to talk--blaring in the dining area.  I like music.  I like restaurants.  I don't mind when restaurants have music.  But when you cannot hear what the person you are eating with is saying to you and the bartenders cannot hear what you are ordering, the music is too loud for a restaurant.  I go to restaurants to enjoy a good meal and have a nice conversation with whomever I'm with.  I would guess most people share that belief.  If I want it that loud, I'll go to a bar, not a restaurant.    Oh, and the beer from the taps tasted funky.  They either aren't cleaning their taps or are cleaning them improperly.  I tasted both an IPA and a wheat beer.  Both were weird.  Sorry, NOLA, but nothanks.

f8P81UcSNppu37-fQmQRog.text: Food was absolutely delicious.  Best jumbalaya I've ever had.    Came for lunch at 11:30 and waited about 15 min for our server despite our being one of about three customers at the time.  Our waitress didn't tell us the specials as well which is why I withheld a fifth star.    Would definitely eat here again.

ZE8GcjjHkcFJSGl27smPoQ.text: Authentic New Orleans fare in the heart of downtown Pittsburgh. Informative server who was helpful with his thoughts on the menu, all choices were wonderful. The Jazz band was a wonderful backdrop to the evening.

wDD1wd1unXKDJE8l9KBcCQ.text: Great lunch spot! I've only been here a few times for lunch and once for happy hour. Both experiences were great with no complaints. The atmosphere is also quite nice, feels a bit fancy and the space is a lot bigger than it looks from the outside. For lunch, I always get the soup and half sandwich duo (with fries, of course) because it's a little bit of variety. I've tried the gumbo and french onion soup, and the shredded beef po boy (which I think they took off the menu) and the muffaletta. All have tasted great, a few steps up from an Au Bon Pain lunch. The voodoo fries are seasoned pretty well, a little spicy, so you might not even need ketchup. Nola gets a crowd for lunch, though, so if you plan on coming here, call and reserve a table ahead of time. In terms of drinks, their drinks are pretty great too. The cocktails are a little pricey, but around $10 is the going rate for most drinks downtown anyway. Overall, I think this place is pretty good and my coming back soon is very likely.

M-DP_lIYvjC9OaYskmFsxQ.text: Let me say this. I am so thankful I did not review this place after my first visit. I had went during their grand opening phase it was not what I anticipated at all, however, I thoroughly enjoyed my experience this week.  As a person with a sensitive stomach I am nervous to try many different things with unknown spices or possible ingredients I could get sick from. I did try the red beans and rice which were amazing. I definitely would get that again. And it should be good. I mean. If a New Orleans inspired restaurant cannot make good red beans and rice, why is it open?  Since I was there for lunch I knew I wanted a flat bread. The waiter suggested I try the eggplant and chevre. I like it but would not run back to order it again. The flat bread itself was good, I just was not feeling the flavor. In the past I have had the pissaladiere which was very good. I also stole a few of my coworkers voodoo fries which were amazing. Honestly I'd go back just for the fries. The sandwiches all looked great and I really like their lunch combination ideas and the way they are presented.  It is just such a neat place inside. I hate describing things as neat, but it really is. I wish it were more voodoo decorated, but that is just me. I think for it's location (being in the north), it does New Orleans justice. I cannot wait to go back and get the shrimp po boy!

OGGI3-d-0wihyrftb8iFuw.text: What an incredible  jambalaya! Best I've ever had. Service was good  atmosphere comfortable, and priced right. The entire menu was terrific.

SJ8vISKgthE_qk4R6BwUmQ.text: One and Done! I tried this place today with some co-workers, there were 6 of us in total.  We were seated pretty quickly considering the size of our party and the fact that it was approximately 12:30 or so.   Our waiter had the personality and friendliness of a rock.  So despite our pretty quick and good start things quickly went south from there.  After taking our order they began bringing out the food roughly 20 minutes later.  That is food for 4 out of 6 of us.  After 10 minutes our waiter realized that two of us didn't have any food and came over to ask "what ya order"?  Apparently the cooks 'lost' our order.  A couple minutes later one more of our party had their food but the last person still did not.  10 minutes after that the manager greeted us, apologized and said that the last person's meal was on the house, and offered him a free soup in the mean time.   Everyone was now free of guilt to eat their food as the last member had some soup.  The food was pretty good, but nothing great. The icing on the cake... our bill was wrong and we were over-charged by roughly $30.  We had to speak with the manager to get that sorted out as well.   I will not be going back.

BfZOhZ2XRfoNo9vfyp1Dxw.text: Walked in and sat at the bar. At exactly 8:43pm on a Sunday after the Steelers home opener, we were told they just had last call. Bartender then promptly walked away. The don't close until 9pm on Sundays. I understand we were close on our timing, but we were denied dinner prior to closing time.

_Pgbnuj_Ir2tpDdVisanfA.text: I have dined here 3 times now so I feel like I have tried enough to give it a fair shake.  To be fair, this is a 5 star restaurant in Pittsburgh but I have actually left the city limits unlike some of my neighbors and dined in cities all over the country.  I would not visit this restaurant if it were in New Orleans.  I own a house there and am there quite a bit so they have a pretty high bar to reach with me.  It might do ok in the touristy part of the city on Decatur St but would certainly close if it were out in the neighborhoods.    The service has been pretty good.  Although last night we had 3 members of the waitstaff try to take our drink order and give us the spiel.  I was pretty irritated by the 3rd person and had to tell him to stop and tell the others he was duplicating service.  The rest of the night, blessedly, they left us to enjoy our meal.  I like the flatbreads.  I had them the first time I visited.  I also think the pork chop dish is really good.  I don't love the beans and rice.  They've missed here and it's a serious offense for someone who loves this food.  There's too much grease on the plate and there's chili powder or something in there.  It should just taste more like beans and andouille.  I fear they've tried too hard on this one.  I had a perfectly cooked redfish and I like the slaw.  The duck and oyster special gumbo was good but is missing the umami of a terrific gumbo and if it were my first one I would probably have thought it terrific.  The food all the way around is solidly good but I am not a 4 star fan.  It just misses for me.    If you've never had this cuisine and live here you should definitely go and check it out.  It's a lot of fun and I am sure you'll have a good meal.

aQReaQApwCl2NE0el7tJiQ.text: Great atmosphere, food & service! atmosphere is a little loud & more of a bar vibe than restaurant, which we don't mind (and while making reservations the man I spoke with on the phone made sure to point this out & recommend a seating spot for us!) although this may have had a lot to do with the band playing. The wait staff were all very nice & well trained on the menu (my husbands a VERY picky eater) side note: if you are a picky eater too there IS a "bar menu" they do not serve you if you sit in dining area. Try the fried alligator, it was absolutely delicious & the sauce served with it was fantastic! Will be going back!

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Delicious Fried alligator

Vb42iJcL58uD971hTTUYtg.text: We hit NOLA a couple of weeks ago on a Saturday night.  We got there pretty early and were part of the show crowd.  The place is misleading, size-wise from the outside - it's pretty large inside, with at least three distinct seating areas.  It also seems as though there should be one table removed from the area where we were seated.  While understanding that table turn $$$ is why every restaurant is in business, it was like dining in a NYC subway car at 6pm.  Seasonal House Sangria was tasty and different.  Of course it included bourbon and also sported a bruised rosemary sprig instead of fruit - Yum!  It indeed tasted like the perfect winter sangria - we both loved it.  Fried Green Tomatoes are an obsession of mine so I couldn't wait to sample NOLA's version.  While they were good, the tempura was overpowering and left me still wanting fried green tomatoes. Two entrees were enjoyed.  I had the Wood Roasted Quail which was served with the best prepared asparagus ever - nice and firm.  The quail was well done and flavorful with both the rice and cranberry sauce complementing the bird.  The oyster dressing was not great; mushy describes both flavor and texture.  My companion had the Scallop and Shrimp Mac Daddy which was served in a cast iron pan and had great flavor.  I would go back only to try out the sandwich side of the menu, as it also looked tempting.  They were very busy, but I feel like if I go in with diner expectation I would be better satisfied with the loud atmosphere, tight quarters and rushed staff.  Muffaletta or Po'boy... sangria can make the jump!  Also - made reservation through Yelp - how much easier can things be???  I wish more restaurants used this feature!

wjVFgcDZyevPVKGlSpcnbA.text: Went there on Wednesday after work for dinner and must say it was delicious.  We split the alligator, he had the gumbo (extra spicy), and I had the leak/brie pasta.  The alligator was disappointing not because of the tastes, it was extremely delicious.  It tasted like a mix of chicken and calamari with a spicy seasoning.  Heavily breaded and heavily spices.  The sauce that came with it tasted almost like the onion petal sauce from the Outback.   However it was so small and it came on a long plate.  There were 12 small pieces of it.  There was more sauce than alligator and it was $13!  Never again.    His gumbo wasn't particularly spicy and it had too much tomato sauce but it was close to New Orlans.  Can't complain too much considering how far away we are.  My pasta was extra saucy and small.  The dish it came on was huge too.  Why the excessive presentation?  Biggest complaints?  No po'boys, no ghost peppers, and no jazz through the speakers!  Plus the decor looked as if they were getting ready for Mardi Gras.  Nice artwork though and the waiter was a sweetheart (thanks Miles!).  He was attentive and polite.    All in all I probably will not go back for dinner.  Granted we tipped Miles well the cost was just excessive for how little we got.  Will try again for lunch one day.

RGTAAOQnFb5AggUiQADL2w.text: Top quality food and drinks in Pittsburgh's downtown Market Square. This New Orleans themed restaurant replicates the tastes and ambiance of Bourbon Street, while keeping things classy. Though the menu focuses prominently on seafood fare and traditional New Orleans favorites, something is available for all patrons' taste buds.   Bonus Points: Extensive "Gluten Free" menu options

SEdcuEgo-HcrEPkpj6Xkpg.text: Not only was the food amazing, but the service was wonderful! We went on a Friday evening around 7:30, and I do suggest you make a reservation to be safe. I highly recommend the Duck Mac Daddy, which is duck Mac & cheese. It was very rich and filling but my favorite menu item. We also got the fried green tomatoes as an appetizer and they were cooked perfectly, and were topped with a very delicious Cajun cream sauce. I would definitely save room for dessert. Kira was our sever and she was attentive, charismatic, and fun, but she never once was overbearing or got in the way of us enjoying our meal. Overall, I would say a great dinner place or just to get drinks and apps!

zrb_ugO7QluLrGvWAyJLMg.text: The entrance has a very "bar" like feeling with Super Loud music (live band) and people holding beer bottles. at first I was a little worried because I had come here for a relaxing dinner rather than beer and loud music, but the waitress took us to near the back where there was a nice big area with large tables and a relatively quiet atmosphere. It was next to the kitchen. Great quality, thought out food that seems to have been carefully made.  The scallops were amazing in one of the steel pan dishes I forgot what it was called, but overall nice experience.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Green tomato

5Cbir08H5qCky8sgPYOlSA.text: We stopped in for lunch on a Friday afternoon. Ordered a Shrimp Po'Boy with Cajun fries and Jumbalaya -- both were very good and flavorful. Portions were perfect sizes for lunch, we didn't feel overly full afterwards. The waitress was nice and attentive and even had a suggestion of dipping my fries in the hot sauce as an alternative to ketchup. I would most likely go back again if I had a craving for some NOLA food!

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Shrimp Po&#39;Boy with Cajun fries
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Jumbalaya

3qfw6bgrTSv44eqvyF9XVA.text: New Orleans in Pittsburgh! Ate here on a Saturday evening early. No happy hour on the weekends. We opted for the outdoor seating as it was a beautiful day. The menu selection is limited and pricey. We got the gumbo and the Mahi-mahi special entree. For the price it should have included a salad or at least bread. Food was tasty but the meal should have included more for the price. Service was great. There was no wait. We walked so parking was not an issue for us. There were

2-OuXtoCf2JpTS6IosnuNA.text: Food was delicious (based off of the soup they remembered to give me and my parents food. My family and i came in for lunch here. It wasnt busy at all and it took over an hour to get our food. The waiter was fantastic. The cooks in the back, not so much. Although the food tasted great, they were so slow, the waiters were standing around with nothing to do. They forgot the salad I orderd and it took them so long to get me another one (IT WAS A GARDEN SALAD)  I had to request it to go. They also forgot to add the dressing, which the waiter realized and was kind enough to go fill up a container of it for me himself. I would come back again, but only if I have nothing to do for the next two-three hours. My parents had a Pirates Game to get to.

NLj9DJTwoYg8Ro3KfUEODw.text: I love cajun and creole food. LOVE IT. I know this isn't New Orleans and what can you expect from a Pittsburgh restaurant offering cajun food. Well, how about some crawfish??? Is that too much to ask? None on the menu. None available off the menu. Zero. Considerable disappointment. Oh, ok, you can get excited about the novelty of alligator bites. I've had alligator in every form (including ribs) all over the Gulf states and in a dozen restaurants in New Orleans, and these are nothing special. They're good for an experience and to tell everyone you ate alligator but how much joy do you get from that. You won't order them twice.  I'm a jambalaya afficianado. NOLA's is complelety unremarkable. Wait, I take that back. It's remarkable in it'soddity - they use 3 whole chicken wings for the chicken component. Messy and not a good call. And where's the mudbugs? Jambalaya needs crawfish!! And where's the ettoufe? Nowhere, that's where.   I love Abita beer and they have  a good selection. But that's about the most positive thing I can say about the place. Sure, it's a novelty. Yeah, it's a great place to take your out of town guests for someplace new and different. But if you ask me, it's not a place I'd recommend. Go once. You'll agree with me.

AqHuKqRJQ4uZMTfI5Zyqpg.text: Great food but slow slow service !! They think they are at its peak in terms of upscale dining scene in pittsburgh , but they have a lot to catch up !!

m0oavQPykXQQw_cXEOXRzQ.text: Another place that I enjoy but is presently closed but due to reopen soon.  My fiance & I love love LOVE their Louisiana Cajun style food. ...SOO OOOO good.  Our favorite is the alligator tail meat appetizer that's fried & seasoned to absolute perfection. They also have an excellent fully stocked bar & they have a nice cocktail list too. Looking forward to when they open again, the live music is also awesome & gives the place a great atmosphere to kick back & enjoy.

WJjaW4pgYBaQ-LfldsMbzA.text: Ate at NOLA last night. I tried the alligator bites and crawfish flatbread for appetizers. Both were pretty good. I had the Duck Mac Daddy for the main course. It was absolutely delicious. Probably one of the best meals I've eaten. Highly recommended!!!!!!

P68KV8MsaumIvax00XLSlA.text: I wish I would have found this place sooner. It was a welcome surprise to find. Being a Louisiana native now living in Pittsburgh, you rarely find any cajun food anywhere and if you do, it's not what it should be.   Everything I had was delicious, the chef was more than helpful with preparing an item I had requested and then just went ahead with making the entire meal an amazingly delicious experience that reminded me of home.   The bartender did make the oddest version of a Hurricane I had ever had. I don't think that particular person knew what they were doing, but my review is for the food, not the bar.   My only other complaint, would be that the waitress didn't seem to know much about the food. She served my husband and I a tasting of etouffee, but never brought the rice to go with it and had not come back to check on us so we just had a few bites of it by itself. It was good, just not served properly. Being in the service industry myself, it really makes me a lil picky about how I get treated when I dine out, and I was turned off that a place this unique to this area, where especially most people here don't know this type of food, should have servers who know what they are serving.

pFD-pfzd8czFeY7aC0hSBQ.text: Had a delicious, quick lunch here. I ordered the summer spinach salad. It didn't look like it had any dressing on it and I was nervous I would feel like a koala bear eating it but it was perfectly dressed with a peach tea type vinaigrette . Everything in it was perfectly seasoned from the spicy almonds, goat cheese, and pickled tomatoes.

kayETA6CNIZawpeXCNWW4Q.text: If you don't know any better, it might be good. if you're familiar with New Orleans cuisine, it's barely OK.   The Debris Poboy is a far cry from a real debris poboy. It was simply juicy roast beef.   The Red Beans and Rice were just kidney beans and rice. Very little flavor. Popeyes actually has better red beans and rice.   I'm a New Orleans native and should know better than to try NOLA cuisine outside Louisiana.

ySOrYGbducFBvZ5g01O98A.text: Took my mother here for dinner and the one bartender/server gave me the impression that he couldn't be bothered. We had to seek him out for refills and he seemed bothered by us wanting to order food. Definitely wasn't a welcoming atmosphere.

GHjwIzPme5mpS4nMq_h8YA.text: I stopped by for happy hour 5-7. The crawfish flat bread was tasty and the fried pickles were delicious. Service was nice. I also tried the mango captain white daiquiri. Very nice

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

YJjZlVu14b5GuNrQV1o_zw.text: Since I used to live in New Orleans,  miss Cajun food in Florida.  Decided to go to NOLA in Pittsburgh and again, can't go wrong with Cajun Food.  Place and service was good.  Reasonably priced.  Will definitely go back.

91IUNh7DHhSPVQkw2RHOWw.text: Slightly contemporary and good food. I had the chicken and dumplings and blueberry bread pudding. I would highly recommend the bread pudding! The chicken was a little dry but the dumplings were made well.   Live music at the location. Sitting outside is a little difficult if you are in a date or want to communicate.   Casual or slight dressed up attire is needed for this venue.   Bar tenders do a good job with the odd drinks and he drinks are very well made.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

7RXguayWgSIKQWE1bE1rWg.text: Typical go to after your dreaded day at the office. Every spineless group of sheeple flock here during happy hour. Your drinks will be poured by your stereotypical xenophobic hungover bag of bones behind the bar. There's a great opportunity for a decent pub in this location, but for some reason, they chose to fill it with a bunch of robots hungover from yesterday's bullshit. Thanks but no thanks Nola. Keep slinging Bud Light drafts to Pittsburgh's finest   2 stars for the amazing kitchen work. If you can sit through the inhospitable staff, order from the food menu.... if it's provided..... CHEERS!

MjU6xVExt96buKO4ezlVfQ.text: I planned my annual office holiday party at Nola's event space, Perle. I was blown away, not one complaint from anyone, a total of 67 people attended. Kathy (event planner) was a pleasure to work with, Ron the general manager of Nola/Perle was just as great. Everything from the appetizers to the drinks to the food and especially the staff were perfect. Food was great, guests had the option of filet, crab stuffed salmon, chicken and dumplings or vegetarian.  The event space was decorated with Christmas trees and holiday music was playing in the background. The space was clean, open and perfect for mingling. We had a blast, we will be back next year.

qHXGUE6rGmENipf9862L_g.text: I finally had a chance to come here and see what the buzz is about! I came here for a diner date and was surprised by my experience. On walking up I was confused by the store front making it blend in as I was expecting it to be "poppy". It was a Sunday so on entering it was dead maybe two other tables dining. We where greeted and seated in the back by the grill. It was much different than I was picturing in my head with a name like "NOLA" thinking New Orleans and it's colors and liveness. But that's ok because it did have a few cool art pieces. Now for the menu I can say it's a bit updated from what's on yelp and there site. I was disappointed to see there was no frog legs on the menu like I've read about from past reviews. It was much smaller than you would expect from a place like this but maybe it's a good thing cause they can focus more on there main dishes. I decided to try the "gumbo ya-ya" for a soup starter. I was impressed with the taste and the large chunks of okra and the meats. The rice was great not over cooked at all. Overall for the soup the flavor was nice I just wish it had a kick of heat. For my main dish I decided on the "country fried pork chop" and I'm very happy I did. Now for this  it was so rich with flavors and blended so well it really was a New Orleans style dish. It was a large portion pork chop that was still juicy with that crispy breading coating. The andouille mustard greens where out of this world so delicious and packed with flavor. As for the white rice it was sadly kinda cold and it was noticeable cause everything else was so hot. But the gravy really pulled everything together! A side note and I think it was a mix up because it says the dish comes with a side of "apple butter" but I got a side of cranberry sauce. The service was very nice and the waiter did answer questions about the menu. Overall I would return again to try a few other things on the dish.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Seating area with artwork
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Menu 2018
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Country fried pork chop

SEJRIe8v17ydhsSuKY5o_g.text: This was the third time I have been here and it just keeps getting worse. This time we had a party of 10 and they could accommodate us without a wait which was the only reason we were there.  We ordered 2 bottles of a cabernet off of the list and after about a 15 minute wait they returned to say they were out of the one we had chosen.  We chose another but it was very watery so we refused it.  They returned with another suggestion which we took, but declined to open the second because it just wasn't worth the $70 price tag.  All of this took 30 minutes before we could actually have a sip of wine!  Several people ordered cocktails from the bar and that took over 20 more minutes to arrive.  Overall the service was slow.  The burgers which some ordered came out rare when they were ordered medium or medium rare.  The catfish po-boy was greasy and soggy, obviously cooked at the wrong temp.  The one person who ordered chicken got violently ill later that night. it was obviously undercooked or spoiled.  So between the issue with the bar, the slow service and the food quality there is no way I would patronize them again.  It's a great location, I hope something better eventually takes over the spot!

gH3nr_hdVMFXKYeDDJZ0Ug.text: Definitely worth it for happy hour (M-F 5-7PM), they have drink as well as food specials. However, the two dishes that I ordered (Cajun cheese sticks and fried Cajun andouille balls) were kind of bland and nothing special, but for $4 each, I can't really complain.   The captain mojito (also $4), however, was amazing and not too strong! They have different flavors depending on the day and although mine was supposed to be grapefruit, I did not think it tasted like it. Still delicious regardless!      The staff was attentive and food came out petty quick as well.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Captain mojito (grapefruit) - only $4 during happy hour!

XtjV8LS5xkujeslvyh3hOA.text: Had been wanting to get to NOLA for a while and finally made it yesterday. The food was very fresh & tasty. We tried the fried alligator - the aioli really made it awesome! For a place that emphasizes New Orleans cuisine, the pierogis were fantastic, don't miss them. They were everybody's favorite. The po-boys were really good, the fresh baguettes are the best. Nice atmosphere and friendly staff. Very enjoyable meal.

Ntcj3_I2XJeegrUejgYqqw.text: Excellent meal, great vibe, attentive staff. Fried alligator appetizer was great. Seafood bisque with lobster, crab, and crawfish - yum. Grilled chicken and dumplings was fantastic. My son  had the Crawfish broil and loved it. Wife had the jumbalaya and lived it, but it is spicy. Hurricane was great too. Highly recommend.

HNH1coWcUDdzC709Fnutgg.text: The praline old fashioned cocktail was amazing as was the shrimp and grits (bartender recommendation)! Place was very quiet, but it was a Monday. Would definitely recommend, especially if you are craving some Creole soul food!

9w9LVZC_lCPtFogy7E7c1w.text: We only stopped here for drinks, so that is what my rating is based upon.  The atmosphere is nice, love the New Orleans theme.   At 6:30 on a Saturday, we were the only patrons at the bar.  I ordered a cosmopolitan and my husband ordered a Moscow mule.   The bartender was efficient and made wonderful drinks.   The cosmo was perfect and very cold which I love.   The mule was served as it should be, in a copper mug, and also the right mix of ingredients.   Since I liked mine so much,  my husband asked the bartender how he made it, so hopefully I can have one at home now.  We did see some of the entrees and they looked and smelled yummy.

S7EevS-fY-01u1-J6O6QpA.text: Not impressed this time around. I was here a few years ago and really enjoyed it so decided to return for a night out with my wife. First of all I have been to many places with fried alligator and have never experienced this mostly breading crumbly mess, what a waste of money I don't think all the crumbs made up on piece of alligator. Second our main dish seafood pop pie was mostly potato and crust with peas and a small amount of seafood  I think I had a total of four pieces of seafood in mine. Needless to say I won't be back. Save your money and go to New Orleans for some good food stay out of this place.

0aKik449nbohLWY1LRFaIQ.text: Going to the Cultural District to see a show always brings up the opportunity to also explore some of the fun restaurants that cater to the people who work and play in this area. We've not been to Nola on the Square before, so thought we should... and we did.  The building is quite colorful on the outside and the storefront itself is quite narrow. Once inside, the decor is on the dark side with a long corridor between the bar and some table. However, it widens out towards the back (where the kitchen is) and also has an upstairs, so there is actually quite a lot of space there. We were there early, so we saw the staff doing their prep work and watching TV...  Our server did treat us well and came to check on us periodically, so the fact that we were one of only three parties on hand meant that the did not take lesser care of us for watching TV!  The menu is slanted towards either Creole or Southern cooking. In addition to the New Orleans dishes that you might expect to find in a place with this kind of a name, we also saw Fried Green Tomatoes; Chicken and Dumplings; and stuffed Mushrooms that used Pimiento Cheese!   We ended up ordering the Fried Green Tomatoes and the Mushrooms for our appetizers; then we went with the Voodoo Pasta and the Seafood Jambalaya for our main dishes, and some Beignets for dessert. We also got a bottle of wine and were quite pleased with the price of about $70 per person - which is not high considering the quantities of dishes.  The food quality was somewhat variable, unfortunately. The Fried Green Tomatoes actually needed to be salted, but they came with a yogurt sauce which was fantastic and made the dish! The Mushrooms were disappointing in that was so little of the Pimento Cheese that you could not really taste it. The Voodoo Pasta was supposed to have Bucattini, but I swear that what came on the plate was Spaghetti! the sauce was supposed to be spicy (hence the name) but reminded me more of an Italian Arrabiata sauce than anything else. The Seafood Jambalaya was a study in contrasts: The shrimp and scallops were expertly prepared, but the chicken was charred and overcooked. The sausage was good. The star of the evening were the Beignets that came covered in powdered sugar and also with a small dish of Mango Sorbet (our choice). This dessert made the dinner!  Our waiter was highly knowledgeable about the food and steered us to the appropriate combinations for our taste. We also some saw dishes being take to other tables, and they looked very nice. I would definitely come back here as the cuisine is not the normal Pittsburgh offering and perhaps some of the faults I noted were temporary.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Stuffed Mushrooms
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Fried Green Tomatoes
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Seafood Jambalaya

8SMU69D8rQWPK8o3vOscrw.text: We traveled to Pittsburgh in escape from hurricane Florence. I found NOLA on YELP and we decided to give it try. Exceptional choice!  The restaurant is much larger than it appears from the street. We were greeted by our fun and efficient server (Lauri), and presented with menus. The food is less expensive than most Cajun/Creole restaurants outside of Louisiana.  We began with a flatbread (prepared in a stone oven). I had a gumbo followed by jambalaya (which I requested they make VERY spicy.) The gumbo was authentic and delicious and the jambalaya was perfectly prepared with large shrimp and andouille sausage spiced as I requested. My partner had chicken and dumplings (and an odd choice for him) and he thought it delicious. I ate one of the dumplings: he was right!  I requested to speak with the manager to let him know how pleased we were with the service and the food quality. He, too, was delightful. He sat with us and chatted about the restaurant, plans for the restaurant's future, etc. We left very pleased with the NOLA experience. I give this restaurant a near perfect review and recommend it highly.

-SOXSUVXq0aVsoC5ThABMQ.text: With friends visiting out of town, we were doing the usual "Yinzer for a day" tour downtown. They wanted to try that famous sandwich shop across the square, but due to a long line, we ducked into NOLA instead. We had a fantastic lunch here! The shrimp po-boy reminded me of when I lived down south and everyone agreed that the french fries were among the best we ever had. And the waitstaff did a great job with our large party that featured more kids than adults :-)

8qwL8nhDD_7mvqyLHO4vBQ.text: Say what you will about Nola. All I have to say is Happy Hour! They have a $4 menu of both drinks and appetizers. Fried pickles! Po'boy sliders! I can even get a decent martini! There aren't enough places in the city that have a truly great happy hour but Nola is one of my favorites! I don't honestly know if I've ever eaten an item or drank a drink that was over $4.   There is also live music and a patio. Both are beautiful things!

pSooiUSytiZX_WlJucXvQQ.text: Poor service and sub par food overall. First, it took at least an hour to get our appetizer and soups which I'm pretty sure were only brought out because we reminded him... his response was, "oh I thought you wanted it all out at the same time." Not sure where he got that idea.. we ordered the soups and appetizers in addition to our full meals.  Next, of course after we asked, he brought out some rolls. The rolls were hard and so was the butter. Spreading wasn't even an option.   Mind you we also ordered drinks when we got there. They came out timely, however in the 2.5hours we were seated in our back booth (a table of 6... large enough to have the potential to get a decent tip, but not too large that we were at all hard to handle) our waiter never asked us if we wanted more beverages. He checked on us a total of 3 times throughout our time at Nola and never asked us if we would like to see a dessert menu. We also had to flag him down to get his attention in order to pay for our meal.  The fried green tomato appetizer and French onion soup was the only good part of the entire meal. The portions were small for the price and not anything earth shatteringly delicious.  We will definitely not be going back for dinner. Maybe for lunch if we aren't in any hurry or aren't very hungry.

-U_WTkCuoK_tp3KeQ9vDbQ.text: I went to NOLA for lunch with 3 colleagues. I got the salad and sandwich option, the NOLA salad and the catfish po' boy, which also comes with their fries. The po' boy is usually beer battered but because I can't have certain fried foods, the server checked with the kitchen and suggested that I get the catfish blackened. The salad was great, I always get it in my combo meal, and the fries were hot and perfectly seasoned. The blackened catfish on the sandwich was so good, exactly what I wanted. I enjoyed the sandwich overall but I think the sauce on it was just mayo and this made it bland. If there was a spiced aoli on there that would have made it outstanding. This is why I rated this meal as a 4 instead of a 5. Service was great and I really enjoyed my meal.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. NOLA Salad and Catfish Po&#39; Boy (Blackened)

1xQHFckcTmpwPDNouHJgXQ.text: I must say, the Nola salad is absolutely delicious and if you do go, you should definitely give it a try. I ordered it with no tomato and dressing on the side. And as far as restaurant salads go it is relatively healthy. However, we went at lunch time, 12 PM on a Tuesday. They were by no definition busy. All we ordered was salads and half sandwiches and we were waiting for our food for about 45 minutes. I would not return for this reason alone. Not exactly what you're looking for when you just want a quick bite on your lunch break.

6I7nNvyBCyTGMNYAdhPW5Q.text: Everything about this restaurant was average.  I went here with my mom who came to visit me on a whim.  We ate outside, which was nice.  Our waitress was very prompt.  They really try to give you a New Orleans feel here.  And I give them props for trying to do that in downtown Pittsburgh of all places.  But....the food was ok. There wasn't a whole lot of unique to it.  I mean, one of the specials was a New Orleans styled salad.  Salad.  As a Special.  It's just lettuce and some "stuff" in it right?  That's the special?    Adding cajun fries was nice, but it's not what's bringing me back.  The French Onion soup was good, but salty.  The burger I had was very greasy.  The service, outside of the initial promptness was slooooooooow.  I think the waitress forgot to put in our order.  We waited a long time from order to delivery.  The people behind us didn't even get waters for the longest time, and they weren't that busy.  The watress apologized, but still got my mom's salad wrong, as she asked for no onions, but gave them anyways.  Either way, nothing here from preventing me from going back, but I'll probably check out the other restaurants in  Market Square first before going back.

lzSCBIy-dRg8Xo5DQvYxkw.text: The atmosphere at this restaurant is great!  Its in Market Square, they have outside dining so I really love to come here in the summer.  Its nice to sit outside and eat and watch all thats going on in the square!  They usually have a band playing there in the evenings which is nice.  The service was pretty good, and we didn't have to wait to long for our food.  Oh and I forgot to mention we were there on a friday so we did have a half hour wait , but it went fast because you can walk around the square, or sit at one of the tables in the square and watch all the people, so it was entertaining.

bz0PksFIjISq6kJ_9lfH8w.text: We got lucky and were able to walk in and get a table- no reservations.  Having been to New Orleans, we were excited to get Gator as an appetizer.  It was every bit as good as what we got down south.   Our food was delicious, and my husband discovered that he likes fava beans.   The service was great as well.  We will eat here again.

yYQZB0Gr2b6pYtdMn7yuGw.text: Food is great!  But....Server...no personality...forgot item on order.....had to flag someone down for drink refills...Thursday night... not crowded ..disappointing customer service.

M5D4G9GefSA8tDDABoLRvA.text: My boyfriend and I had a very pleasant experience on a Friday night at NOLA.  I normally don't like loud dining venues, but in this case, I loved it! The live band was awesome...I was getting excited to hear what song they would play next.  The food was also really good.  I had the Brie and leek pasta because it isn't a very common dish to see served at restaurants, and although it was certainly a large enough portion, I found myself wanting more of it!  I also ordered several drinks and appetizers and was very pleased with all of them.  Our waiter was great, but I felt bad for him because he practically had to yell all night over the band to his customers.  I would definitely go back for dinner again!

2Eg7SXVOv4zrjb7IWMauHQ.text: So I was at NOLA this past Saturday and actually ordered some food. Of course I mean I started off with my milk punch. That drink is so yummy.  I did a half-and-half soup and sandwich. I chose the gumbo and the pulled pork. The gumbo was pretty tasty, especially when I accidentally dumped a buttload of habanero sauce on it. I thought it was going to be way too spicy to ingest after that snafu, but I think that made it taste better. The sausage in it was absolutely delicious.  The pulled pork sandwich (with onion rings on it, oddly enough) is the best I've had in Pittsburgh thus far. Which is not really a compliment to NOLA as it still wasn't that good and I wouldn't order it again.   The meal also came with voodoo fries. Yum-my. I would order a side of those at any time, they are so good! I don't know what spices they put on them, but they're great.  We ended lunch by sharing some sorbet, mixed berry and peanut butter. The peanut butter one was great, but I am a big lover of all things peanut butter-flavored. It also came with some fried and sugar powder bread that I cannot recall the name of (and can't find on the website!). It was all delicious.  I also upgrade the rating one star because our waiter was kickass. I wish I could remember his name. He was friendly, humorous, came back and checked on us often enough.

2jReFFXnnDqtUN_iG46S2w.text: Excellent food and presentation. They're going for that New Orleans flair. I personally have not been yet, but i could only imagine from the ambiance that NOLA provides.    I went on a Wednesday and there was a live jazz band playing. Had the filet mignon and it was cooked to perfection. It came with cream spinach and potatoes.  The spinach left a bit to be desired, but the meal itself was still delicious.  For an appetizer, I had the BBQ shrimp. 6 pieces of the juiciest most succulent shrimp ever.   The place was a bit pricey, but I'd say it's worth it.

eBI3NToN3VyU_sw0E0NOMw.text: So glad I didn't spend $27 on shrimp and grits. Funny exchange on that. When I mentioned the high price, it was explained as being a function of the grits from NC. Yeah- me too, from NC and grits are poor people food!  The shrimp and sausage should be the money in the dish. So, I went salad and flatbread. Got out more cheaply but this place confirms my Market Square theory: you eat there to sit there -in the square- and not to actually eat a high quality meal.

mIryyMCJ4WWHKqu2qkGo_A.text: Has gone wayyyy down hill! I've eaten here about 10 times and each time I've enjoyed it less and less, however last night was my last night eating there.   From the poor wait staff, to the over cooked porkchop and sad jambalaya, ending with a 35 minute dessert delivery and silverware washtubs being carried through the dining room I've had enough.   I came into work today and told everyone about how awful is was and how upset I was just to hear they had the same experience a few weeks ago.   The service- I've had good people before however this girl was slow, didn't know the menu, left all of the wine glasses on the table even though I was drinking a martini and the others beers. She didn't check on our table so I had to get up and request a manager to address the over done pork chop. (ordered medium came wayyyy past well- replacement chop was great)   The Jambalaya- just a cheap version of something that used to be amazing. Made with no attention to detail, so much chicken and not enough seafood and andouille. This dish used to be two small chicken wings now they use huge grilled tenders and cut down on the actual meat you're interested in. Something else about the way it tasted was just off-- I feel like they are just cutting corners.   Those are my thoughts--Sorry NOLA but you lost your touch

Cmzoazv2TA3RL6-dMHfp5w.text: Imminently forgettable.  Bland, boring, and tasteless.  I tried the fried alligator appetizer and the jambalaya for the main course.  The best part of the jambalaya is the andouille sausage, and that's not saying much.  The shrimp were as tasteless as the chicken and the rice was worse than tasteless.  And it's not spicy.  A jambalaya that isn't spicy?  That makes as much sense as calling white chocolate chocolate.  They get an extra star for putting in the effort to have frogs legs and alligator on the menu, though the alligator was so drowned in aioli that all you can tell is you're eating fried...something...in aioli.  I got the distinct impression they only have these things on the menu to seem edgy, which is a huge disappointment.  All this with New York prices make for a fairly lame experience.  Granted, this is right in tourist central, but for some reason I was hoping to get more than the usual tourist razzle dazzle and sky-high prices.  I was very wrong.

mV8n7fgkPhxyOoKvRTaDrA.text: So, the atmosphere is nice and fun and the drinks were good. The services wasn't great, but I think the server was new or overbooked. My real issue was the oysters. They don't know how to shuck them--they were all shriveled and mangled and there was no water in them. On top of that, they were warm, so I have a bad feeling they were not stored correctly. I'll update in two days if I get sick.

-G5Q_iEtrAfWNrWlikAgmw.text: Wow great choice on a very warm Friday night , got a table outside on market square and enjoyed the surroundings ,I ordered the seafood Mac Daddy .it was over the top ,the lobster and shrimp were done to perfection ,I highly recommend ,so give em a try .

hLbQHPwWm6Ry1P9Qs1qoKw.text: Last chance! NOLA is one of the few places that take reservations on Sunday for an early dinner. They were very responsive and put my party of 10 at a great quiet table. That was where the service ended. It took forever to get our drink order and even longer to take our food order. It was not busy and there appeared to be plenty wait staff. If you have never been to real New Orleans, you probably think that the food is authentic .... not even close and the quality of the preparation was poor.  Even though we commented to one of the waiters that the service was slow, no one even tried to make us feel better about our dining experience. Maybe they don't need the business. Won't be back.

QzUK1Q97Wl-D60CGOqBRUQ.text: Interesting Cajun place midst a number of other restaurants in market square.  Interior was honestly pretty gaudy, I understand embracing the New Orleans feel but the sheer quantity of decorations was distracting.  Service was excellent, we were seated and served quickly.  Po' boy sandwiches were good, but dry.  Excellent fries and slaw with the meals.  Soups were among the better choices at our table, especially the oyster stew.  I was a little underwhelmed by spice usage in all of our dishes, I expected more of a punch.  Prices were reasonable considering the location, and the drink selection seemed fair enough.  Pretty tasty food, worth a try if you're hankering for some Cajun, but be cognisant of other options in the immediate area.

u3rmsHmi4k03gtwlc6N2Cw.text: I had high hopes for NOLA.  My boyfriend's family lives in New Orleans, and we visit yearly.  When I first walked into NOLA, my first impression was that this is kind of like the Disney World version of New Orleans.  It is over the top, cliche, and kinda cheesy.  That's fine, I can deal with that.  Cheesy can be fun, and the music was great.  I tried to keep a positive attitude.  I ordered a Sazerac, a classic New Orleans cocktail, and it was served warm.  It was also very heavy on the absinthe rinse.  Friends have told me they've had great Sazeracs at NOLA, so I'm hoping this was a fluke.  Next, I tried the alligator appetizer.  It was pretty tasty, but the presentation was not great.  The tiny nuggets of fried alligator were dwarfed by the huge rectangular plate they were served on.  It just seemed like an interesting choice. The red beans and rice dish was pretty awesome, but it wasn't as good as those I've had on the Gulf Coast.  They weren't as thick and creamy, and they were lacking in spice (a bottle of hot sauce fixed that).  Overall, NOLA did not do justice to the awesomeness that is New Orleans cuisine.    I love New Orleans, and I want to love NOLA.  I'll definitely give it a second try.  Some perks:  live music, $5 valet parking after 5 (for all of Market Square), good service, fun ambiance

hIs84XLcgNYKaOejg4CPNg.text: Was in PBurgh for a conference this week and stopped by this place for lunch in the Market District. I had the turkey Cuban and some red beans. I will have to say I was pleasantly surprised. Very tasty, fresh ingredients with a little kick. So much food. Seriously, go for the half sandwich. It was a ridiculous amount to eat.  Service was great and fast- easily doable in an hour. Price was reasonable. A little jealous we don't have NOLA in Columbus.

S9gvAYgbvautoONz87W0Hw.text: I hate to seem like a pretentious snob, but I wouldn't say the food is really all that authentic "Cajun" or "Creole". Been to NO many a time, and I know what authentic Cajun food tastes like. The food was okay, but I've had better.  Even so, I'd still rate this place fairly high. As I said, authenticity issues aside, the food is okay. The service was definitely over par, so if you're not hung up on the fact that it's not quite what you'd get in the French Quarter, then go there and you'll probably have a good dining experience. The decor and ambiance are definitely high on the cool meter. I'd probably go back.

0JzUhO1w48Q4qBZwHUv69g.text: Ups and downs.  Went on a Saturday night relatively early.  We were excited to get some fried alligator appetizers.  They were out.  Ok, stuff happens.  We were with a party of 10 (pay attention...that'll come back up) and warned that they would add automatic 20% gratuity (ok, no biggie) and would not split the check -- no problem.  A bit tacky, but ok.  We brought a pen to split it ourselves.  Everybody was happy with their entrees, and the soft-shell crab on cucumber (?) gazpacho was OUTSTANDING.  All's well.  Server brings the check -- we're ready!  Pen comes out!  Paying with 4 cards, we split the bill and give her the 4 cards -- put the balance on the last one to cover the tip.  Not sure what the problem was, but there was a minor meltdown.  She ended up grabbing the bill saying "Ugh, forget it...I'll just split it" and then came back and threw each of our bills back down on the table.  No exaggeration.  I've never had a bill envelope slammed on the table in front of me.    Guess she got her 20%....so who cares, right?  Look, it's not that hard to split a check for a group.  It's basic restaurant etiquette.We would have let you know up front.  But it wasn't "allowed."  We left slightly offended with a bad taste in our mouths.  I'm....not sure we'll be back.

nQuLx0jNXSnjUI3Zrhc6AA.text: For those who work downtown, NOLA seems to continue to be a well-liked lunch spot...  personally, I never initiate that decision.  While the food is alright, I definitely never feel its worth its cost  [for ~$12 you can get a lunch combo (choose 2-2 of soup, salad, sandwich, fries, etc.)].  In addition, the consistency is definitely not there and every time my food comes out, it looks and tastes like it's sat under a head lamp for at least 10-15 minutes.  The one consistent item I landed on was the Chicken Po-Boy, but alas, on my last journey here they updated their menu and did away with it!  Haven't had a chance to come in the evening for live music, etc., but it seems like it may have some potential for a decent date spot.

oo6vTg0s-x0l6bJ-hgHPwQ.text: Very salty and not what I expected. Was sat down and had to ask for silverware when food arrived. Needs improvements.

AolHWtactp67HKUaU9jpLA.text: It was a Saturday night and I wanted to go somewhere different. I'd heard about this restaurant and Market Square is always lively on the weekend so we chose to go here to start the evening off right.  I walked in Nola and was immediately transported to New Orleans. The music was lively and it felt so cozy inside. We got a table in the back where you can see the open kitchen...pretty cool! The service was great and the drinks...my my my. Wow. Amazing! We split appetizers of fried green tomatoes and a crawfish flat bread that was made with a really yummy olive tapenade. Both apps were very good. I can't wait to go back to try their entrees among other things.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Onion tomato flatbread with...brussel sprouts that tasted like mushrooms! Crazy good
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Love the artwork here

UiczmAQIfIKTRBtsJ2VoWQ.text: I just...wow. It isn't often that I get to enjoy a meal that leaves me content to the point that I don't have the words to describe the level of nirvana I've reached. But my long overdue first visit to Nola managed to do just that.  It admittedly took me way too long to finally eat at Nola's - when they opened I was a broke college student, when I graduated I was a broke graduate, and then for a while I honestly was more in the mood to try the many other new eateries we've seen in the last few years. But finally, they were open and I was craving something different. So a meal at Nola it was.  I came here with my family, and between the four of us we sampled a decent chunk of the menu as we traded a couple appetizers and meals between us. After that I'm pretty convinced you can't go wrong with anything here. I loved absolutely everything I tasted. Our appetizers set the perfect tone for the meal - the Catfish Croquettes simply couldn't contain any more meat or stuffing, while the Fried Green Tomatoes were the freshest and richest I've ever tasted. And my Gumbo Ya-Ya struck me as one of the most unique foods I've eaten, and was full of rice, chicken, and okra - yum!   Even better, after salivating over the appetizers the main courses continued to impress - we sampled the chicken and dumplings and Pork Tenderloin. The first dish contained dumplings that had to have been made fresh and by hand, they were so good - although they paled in comparison to the flavor of the tenderized chicken that came covered with butter and vegetables. But my favorite dish of the night had to be that Pork Tenderloin - the meat practically melted in my mouth, and every bite of marinated pork gave you an amazing explosion of flavor, especially when you piled your fork high with the vegetables and sauces served with it.   What I'm about to say is probably the understatement of the month - but Nola = YUM. And for the most part, the service was just as fantastic; while I wouldn't have minded a faster pace at the end of the meal as we waited for our checks and boxes, they did provide us with plenty of water and kept our tables clear of empty plates throughout the meal itself. It's probably fair to attribute the slight slowdown to the fact that Nola is just very popular and always busy. I'll admittedly have to remember to give myself plenty of time to enjoy a meal at Nola in the future, just in case, so that I'm not late to my post-dinner plans - but it'll be extra time well spent as far as I'm concerned!

816_7Uyf606ksdF3Km8Y-Q.text: Food was very good! Had the fried green tomatoes, the crawfish bisque and the duck! Originally wanted the catfish, but the kitchen said they were out! Overall the service was slow and it took a while for some of the apps to come out.
