9AvmmQqt9jQK6VfB9H6h8A.text: The food was a C for us but I am a New Orleans regular. So I can't be easily moved with creole/Cajun cuisine. BUT the drink was great and the staff was AWESOME. so the experience was balanced.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. New old fashion good really good.
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Salmon cake. Yummy
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Seafood Creole or etouffe not sure. Just ok.

fjqk-7CHvFnZwmM6McHVdA.text: Service was horrible.  Sat for over a half hour before we got our drinks, after we waved down 2 different people asking to place an order. I typically tip 20% or more.....i will begrudgingly tip under 15 which i have not done in 15 years...service was that bad. Food was good, borderline great. Unfortunately the sevice was do shitty that it ruined the meal.

GQMPURUbffs74DPwH3V9og.text: I was really excited to try NOLA as I love New Orleans cuisine.  The new lunch menu looked fantastic.   Our table was a group of 6 coworkers. Our server was new and had a huge section of tables, so while he was very nice, it was pretty slow service. One coworker didn't get to eat since he had to get back for a meeting.   We started with fried green tomatoes & gator appetizers. The server said it would be enough food; it wasn't. Four fried green tomatoes & a small plate of gator came out. While the apps were delicious; the portions were very small. We ordered a second gator appetizer. The flavors were there but the portions weren't.   I had the soup & half sandwich with voodoo fries combo. I opted for the crawfish bisque and catfish Po boy. The soup was very good. The Po boy was very greasy. While I understand it was fried; it shouldn't be dripping with grease.   No one raved about their food. I'm not sure I'd go back.

vw4JMfqQMSRutkhpILdQFw.text: My friend and I came by here one rainy Friday evening for dinner. While waiting to be seated, we decided to split a hurricane. The hurricane was very tasty and strong, I definitely recommend it. For dinner, we ordered the fried green tomatoes, gumbo, and the pork tenderloin. We also had the bourbon ball and beignets with sorbet for dessert. We were told by our waiter that the food at NOLA is comparable to New Orleans' food with a touch of Pittsburgh, and were expecting mediocre food but everything was absolutely delicious and brought back fond memories of my trip to New Orleans.  Service was great as well and the waitstaff was superb. NOLA is definitely one of my favorite restaurants in Pittsburgh and I am looking forward to returning soon.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chocolate bourbon ball and beignets
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Fried green tomatoes

1PXTThXIa-MBMzQ7nl47AA.text: Started out with the Royal Street Blues Martini and delicious fried green tomatoes.   For dinner I enjoyed the blackened salmon over crawfish etoufee. Seasoned and cooked to perfection.  The weather was unseasonably warm so I sat on the patio.  Excellent service from the entire staff.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

Avk8SeRNNOBSIh8_5gggXg.text: I go to NOLA for one main reason...the Seafood Jambalaya!  I has huge shrimp and scallops and just the right heat.  And I can handle that heat.  Andouille sausage and chicken are in there, too.  I was stuffed and didn't even finish it all!   Oh, and don't forget to have a cocktail.  I had the Cajun Martini.   Wow, that one is spicy hot!!  It's really tasty, especially mixed by Troy the bartender.

4sTMtdvume3F0NXsHnVQzw.text: Excellent food and service and definitely the right flavor. On the strong recommendation of an acquaintance, I went to NOLA for the first time yesterday. I was eating lunch by myself and I asked to be seated away from the bar. I was given a nice little booth/table in view of the open kitchen. Pleasant atmosphere.   My server (Lynette) was exceptionally courteous and attentive. She was knowledgeable and could sell the heck out of the menu and upcoming special events, but she did it in a very conversational helpful way - If NOLA mgmt is reading this, please know you've got one heck of a server and seller in her!  I started with the crawfish bisque, then a catfish and greens entree.This entree had a long mouthwatering description on the menu that I have forgotten; but I will not forget this meal for quite some time. It was a delightful blend of comfort food and fine cuisine. Execution was flawless.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Catfish entree at lunchtime

RQRzntUDiYP-cgM0Anxeng.text: I have to rave about this place. A friend and I were out and about on Saturday around 2pm and I really wanted to check NOLA out. We walked in and were seated near the bar at one of the high tables. The first thing I noticed is how much bigger it was on the inside versus what it looked like on the outside. Nice little surprise. I instantly wanted to bop my head to the music and enjoyed looking at the art on the wall. The atmosphere was perfect.  The hostess brought water over and then we had a waitress by the name of Stasha who talked to us about the menu (my first time there) and asked if we were interested in drinks/appetizers. I ordered the Abita Mardi Gras Bock beer and for an appetizer I got Zapp's Potato Chip Crusted Catfish. I was blown away by the flavor/spices of this catfish. It was delicious! Perfectly crispy and a nice, tender flavor on the inside. We were informed that our waitress had a big table she was tending to so we had someone else who came over, introduced themselves, and took our order. Then our lovely waitress came by to make sure our orders were in, which was then brought over by the manager (I believe that's who it was). I ordered seafood jambalaya and let me tell you how much I was in love with it. It had big pieces of shrimp, scallop, sausage, rice, and the spices...ohhh the spices. It was definitely spicy though not overpowering. I loved every bite.  While we were waiting to ask for a to-go box, one of the bartenders walked by and stopped to ask if we needed a box. Good timing. Then Stasha came over and asked us about dessert/got the check. She was so sweet, fun, and had great knowledge of the menu. I definitely appreciated her enthusiasm and interaction with us. One of the great things about this place was the customer service. I mentioned a few different people who came over to help us and they all made our experience that much better. It was the team work that I noticed and loved. You had the hostess, waitress, another waiter, the manager, and a bartender all pitching in for each other, which was so wonderful to see and experience. They did a wonderful job and I'd be more than excited to come back to try other items on the menu.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Abita mardi gras bock
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Zapp&#39;s Potato Chip Crusted Catfish and fried green tomatoes
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Seafood jambalaya. Amazing and perfect.

0jYIzekngMMOiagKzgzJzw.text: Great drinks! The Cajun martini is my favorite! The alligator appetizer is delicious was a little overdone but ok since we were mainly there to have drinks and it was late. Other times I've been here the food is really great! Nice atmosphere and live band tonight so we had a good time.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

YL6rRkO35YiGcsNLZz2TYg.text: My husband & I stopped in here for a few drinks and to listen to the band they had playing.  The bartenders were super friendly and the drinks were awesome!  The band sounded awesome too!  We hung out at the bar for almost 2 hours before leaving to head to the next stop.  We will definitely be back the next time we are in Pitt!

-FZbIBZhXwXBXzbionDGaw.text: This is a tough review. A friend and I went to NOLA for dinner this weekend and we had the pierogies for appetizers and I had the jambalaya while she had the shrimp and grits. The appetizers were great but our entrees were SO spicy!   Both my friend and I love spicy foods so it's not a matter of us having a low tolerance for heat. Both of us have eaten at numerous restaurants in New Orleans before and the entrees we both had were so spicy that it bordered on uneatable. That said, it had the *right* spices, just too much of it.  My friend had been craving shrimp and grits and she said while she was managing with the heat, she found the portion of grits to be lacking. Most people would expect a bowl of grits with the shrimps in the center but NOLA makes a grit cake in the shape of a rectangle for its presentation. There was some kind of bacon over the top that did look good. My friend said there was way too much of whatever sauce the shrimp came in so when she finished, there was still a significant puddle of it left over that felt wasteful but she thought it did taste good.  My jambalaya was tomato-based and came in a small cast-iron cassoulet-type bowl. A hearty serving and piping hot temperature-wise too. Flavorful shrimp and scallops were on top while embedded in the rice were sausage and chicken. Trust me, this was a good dish but someone went seriously overboard with the seasoning. Even the next day I ate some and it was still spicy to me and it gave my friend heartburn. I wanted to be a fan of this meal but unfortunately I'm not.

wTEaajehjJE9zFq2IrPiiQ.text: This experience was the WORST! 40 minutes after ordering drinks - they arrived- but only because I reminded the waiter 3x that we were still waiting. The wait staff was overwhelmed, the food was below average. Meals: 2 of 4 were 'okay, good' and 2 were not cooked properly and very fatty (chicken). Dessert took another 35 minutes (slice of chocolate cake). They did comp us the drinks but I left the restaurant hungry. There are so many great places to go in Market Square-- do yourself a favor and go elsewhere.

4E0lGq7G6KeAKN62LoQT0A.text: The food here varies in quality by a very large amount. We had 4 dishes in total, the fried alligator and catfish were ok, but the jambalaya and margarita flatbread were god awful. They both had extremely strange tastes, and eating them made me want to throw up. Prices aren't cheap either, and the portions are very small.

svhkpFxci77DN8yep_udjA.text: Visited here with the family for a light dinner and live jazz. Had a great time. Theirs flat breads are delicious, nice fresh salads, good choice of drinks. But the main highlight is the atmosphere. Loved the jazz band performance (Benny Benack), had lots of fun.

QpXTxrEHGD1dDHtA0Esmlg.text: Me and my boyfriend shared some gumbo and a sandwich/salad combo. The flavor in this food was very unique to most places I've been and impressed us both. We loved the Cajun salad, each bite had something new that we didn't notice before! Also a very nice atmosphere and decor.

LLnBOScMaYnhPcsFXmJH_A.text: Worst place waited more than an hour and now she is saying it will take at least 30 more mins to get to your order, ridicules make sure u only sit people u can serve and don't waste people's time, never going back and will highly non recommend. Professional behavior is a minimal trait expected from any business, specially the ones dependent on customers. We are leaving the restaurants after sitting here for 1 hour 20 mins without food.

KhXAH82OqqWk_Fva-dFQbA.text: My co-workers and I ended up here since Meat & Potatoes was booked till 11pm. The entrance looks small but its a lot bigger inside so it's a great place for groups. I was very excited to try this place from what I heard from friends but I was underwhelmed by the food I had. Although the catfish was cooked well it wasn't as flavorful as the name of the dish. It didn't have any kick to it for something described as cajun. I was able to try the grits too and thought it was bland. The aligator bites were good though, very tender. I've never had alligator and it tasted just like calamari! I unfortunately didn't get to try the gumbo that Yelpers rave about.  They had a very enticing menu of special cocktails and I ended up ordering the Bayou royal tea. It was described as having lavender and honey but I couldn't really taste the lavender. It was pretty pricey too imo.

ySz24YetEA_fG8j3j8Ocnw.text: Loved it. Fantastic food, service, cocktails &  music! We were seated earlier than our reservation. I think our servers name was Al. He was out of this world. We had: fried green tomatoes, alligator, shrimp & grits and jumbalaya. Then beignet and creme brule fantastic!! .

Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Shrimp &amp; grits: NOLA

1LMy8aDKZc3lMy1yu6O-iw.text: We loved the fried green tomatoes. All of our dishes were good, but this was the winner.

H5LCcka9ornPro-dKRHHJg.text: Really enjoyable experience on market square.  Loved the live music and atmosphere. For the food we got po boys and pizza.  All excellent. Will be back for sure !

pKZYkW2RhWA4Vrb_ly4eZA.text: I love Southern food, especially from New Orleans so of course we had to give this place a shot.  Definitely a great place for appetizers and lunch, but I think we should of ordered different items for dinner, wasn't pleased but definitely l wasn't displeased.   For what we paid I think we should of gotten more, but to each their own.   I suggest avoiding this place if you see a large group present too.  Overall though we were happy and probably will try it again, but for lunch only.  The service was definitely great here though,  the employees definitely had their knowledge on the food they offer.

y0gc4l-U0vQvqmMOc6JOBw.text: Get restaurant with food that is very reminiscent of my visits to New Orleans. The atmosphere is great, the staff friendly, and the prices fair. A must try if you love spicy Cajun food!

nwMBJcZ2C4tMYj0bY1iMYA.text: I love Noa! I have been here for dinner twice and lunch twice. I love the menu and the cocktails. I am new to the area and this is the first place that I really enjoyed.

oHEXuTxDYEyg5XPrNEQG1g.text: I just haven't been blown away by this place.  I've gone there for happy hour and lunch, so maybe all the great stuff happens for dinner, but I likely won't make it back for dinner b/c of my experiences with hh and lunch.  The drinks are good but I'm not impressed by the food.  For happy hour I had gotten the crawfish flatbread and the crawfish was not fresh and had an overwhelming fishy taste and rubbery texture.  While I expect fishiness to some degree on crawfish, it was too much and distracting.  I couldn't even eat another slice of the flatbread after the first few bites.  For lunch I got a vegetarian sandwich b/c this was a few weeks after my hh experience and I didn't want to deal with another bad fish ordeal.  So while the sandwich was fine, it was lacking some flavor - granted there's probably only so much you can do with veggies, but come on let's flavor it up a bit, this is supposed to be New Orleans inspired.  I will admit that the fries were delish and perfectly seasoned.  That was the only highlight of my meal and my experience at NOLA.

c2I9SXw_v33ZvDKGuLVfqA.text: Great food and good service but I think this place deserves three $ instead of two $ mains are priced from $20-39.

MypnqQearkoVJBpU6Lz4cg.text: Very delicious. Highly recommend the fried green tomatoes. In fact you can't visit NOLA and not get them. I still crave them on a daily basis. The food is tasty and the portions are filling. The drink prices are normal. Over all a very enjoyable place.

C7uftBber9NWSHx5wABgSA.text: I love creole, I know creole, I cook creole myself.  So I was beyond excited to try this place, and thrilled to see this style of cooking introduced to Pittsburgh.   It didn't stand up to my standards, I guess if you don't know creole food it can pass for a poor imitation.  It simply lacked heart, which for me, is everything with this style of cuisine.  I found the atmosphere tacky and cliche.  Our server was well-trained, but again lacked heart and personality.  An overall corporate feel, when to do a True cajun/creole menu you need soul.

9-_uJeUhn0SUi9jx55BZ0w.text: I have been to Nola twice - the first time as a willing foodie, the second as a prisoner of social graces. The only enjoyable dish here, in my experience, has been the eponymous 'Nola Salad.' It's really a lovely salad - the candied walnuts, arugula and fresh goat cheese are definitely a winning combination.  Unfortunately, everything else suffers from the too much salt, too much grease or too little taste malaise that seems to be the defining characteristic of Nola. Even the jambalaya - their signature dish - was one dimensional and salty.   So.  Long story short:  Is Nola conveniently located in Market Square? Yes, BUT that shouldn't stop you from going to the other excellent restaurants that are in the same area or nearby (Eleven, Sienna). Extra star for the yummy salad.

yLhFzY470XMOtFUZDiPNOg.text: NOLA gets packed in the evenings and on weekends, but for good reason.  The bar is nice, the food is good, and the service is great.  Everyone that helped us was friendly and attentive, and made for an all around enjoyable experience.  I also never felt as though the restaurant was over-crowded, as some restaurants feel when there is a line out the door.  Also, Market Square is a great place to be on a nice afternoon in the Burgh too (or before a show at the theaters nearby).  The menu is more of a northern version of Cajun food than authentic, but there are some interesting appetizer and entree choices, both for the timid and the daring.    My table ordered fried zucchini and alligator apps, and I had the quail for dinner, which was cooked perfectly.  The portions were very generous, and I was not able to finish my entire entree.  One of my friends had the scallop entree, and while it was a bit heavy and rich, it was also fantastic.   Definitely worth a try if you have never been here before.

gPVMOaDOSDQ_uSRWP4170A.text: Excellent brunch which includes a starter, a cocktail and a main dish for $25.  A very different menu and it was great.  I had e cajun pastrami and eggs which were served with Lyonaisse potatoes.  Everything was awesome.  Flavors were very different.  Also had the grits - yes grits - and the apple crepes.  My son has the pumpkin waffles and fruit with granola as his starter.  I highly recommend.

jJ_03Z3SEujEU2MVRMwI5g.text: I was not very impressed with Nola as the service was extremely slow and I felt the food was average. Lots of fried food to go along with the New Orleans theme but still felt it seemed like traditional American food. Decent prices for lunch though just get there earlier if you are on a time crunch.

et3TWZxemEvdK0pJQSKX7A.text: I love NOLA! I have food allergies. They were super nice and accommodating with that. I brought friends back and then returned again.. so 3-4 times I've left Nola feeling happy and excited to go back.

wH_pimIa8XHhtEjxXE9RRg.text: Cute restaurant located in Market Square. Valet parking and wait staff in ties makes the place look a bit more upscale then it really is.  Only split a shrimp appetizer here but it was good. The beer list was awesome and you can even order New Orleans style drinks like the Hurricane.  Get there and snag a table outdoors  for people watching, this place is frequented by ridiculous drunk middle aged women. I saw a woman take her shoes off grab onto a parking attendant and start running across Market Square.

y9zaQJbnd436nfgcBhQyIQ.text: Loved this place!  We took the boys and they had no problem w/ children in the restaurant.  The boys loved our server and his handlebar mustache!  My oldest obliterated his pizza and my youngest finished his chicken fingers when we left.  I had a ham sandwhich.  I think it came w/ gouda...but it came w/ the apple dipping sauce!  MMMmmmmmm!  I annihalated that sandwhich.  Oh, it came w/ a side of voodoo fries, which were yummy.  Hubs had the salmon and loved it.  We will definitely be back.

ntnVzlrfithti0KzZbK5qA.text: Seafood jambalaya without rice, presentation was better then the food.a bit pricy for what you get. Still good, but nothing special.fries were excelent. great outdoor seating for people watching and relaxing. Great Nola bear selection!

LjkmXJpaHzpD-ChGXq3RAw.text: There was a band playing inside which made it too loud to talk to my wife.  The food was good but overpriced for what you got.  Thus would probably be a great place to hang out and get drinks but not a great dinner atmosphere.

CkkbxglpuWwO-dwTwO41PA.text: Larkin Larkin Larkin... I cannot say enough about this server. She was not only knowledgable about EVERYTHING on the menu, but also incredibly sweet and efficient. Food was amazing but I will come back for the service.

bTWEYoLGyNIL0xQmayEB2w.text: Meh. I was sick and in the need of some soup or something warm to soothe my the throat.I came across this place and wanted to try the gumbo. I ordered it to go, and had my husband pick it up and bring it back to the hotel. The gumbo wasn't what I expected, the flavor was so so. My husband ordered the fried green tomatoes and a flat bread. Both were gross, the flatbread was lukewarm when he picked it up, he even arrived earlier than the given time. With all the amazing food places in Pittsburgh, not sure why anyone would choose to come here.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

d59kpeBhH1YnGgctwi9pnA.text: We arrived around 2pm on a Saturday during which the Market Square Christmas Village was active so we were expecting chaos but were surprisingly able to get seated immediately. We were quickly greeted by our waitress and learned that brunch was still in session.   My wife ordered the French onion soup and Nola salad and I ordered the pulled pork po' boy sandwich. The salad was amazing (all ingredients complemented each other well and the amount of dressing was just right)   and the soup was average. My pulled pork was juicy and the voodoo fries were delicious though the onion rings topping the sandwich could have been fresher.   With tax & tip we were out the door for $25.

lfODuupXHngqy8_O2lVYCg.text: It's fun and the food is good. But don't expect authentic New Orleans cuisine.  It's a festive atmosphere, and there's live music on Wednesday, Friday and Saturday.  Our service was fairly good.   The dining room is quite expansive, and there's also a long narrow room that has the bar.  We were excited by the happy hour specials listed on the sign out front, but disappointed those were only available at the bar.  Why make rules like this?  Overall, the food is good, but rather pricey for what you get.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Sorbet
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chocolate cake
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Salad

NLKzauhSuVKiiIn2DtxZvw.text: Hello hello fellow foodies!  It's Mr. BlueJay back for another review.  Unfortunately, this time it's not a very good one.  I've been wanting to get down to NOLA on the square for some time but other places and circumstances put it off until tonight.  I'm not sure if they had a head chef change or leave or what....but this was abysmal by every definition of the word.  The place seemed cool enough on arrival, even though the music at volume level 11 in a place that's acoustically similar to a bathroom made my ears bleed.  We were seated in the dining room directly adjacent to the kitchen and the place was completely empty.  The carpeted floors, decor, and desolate room made me immediately depressed...but hey, I hear the food is Amaze- with a capital A.  Onward and upward.  God do I love fried alligator, yes please, I'll have some.  Fried green tomatoes, MMmmmmMmmmm.  Well, it turns out, the fried gator is rubbery, slightly fishy, and disgusting.  I had 5 bites.  Nothanks.  Ok, fried green tomatoes; can't mess that up right?  Well, they weren't awful, but I can name 5 dive bars with better at half the price soooo.  Main course was the voodoo pasta.  Damn that description sounds delicious, lets recap:  "Creole Sauce, Garlic Butter, Red Peppers, Spinach, Wild Mushrooms, Parmesan Cheese, Bucatini Pasta"  Let me put the real description:  "Can of crushed tomatoes, pasta, no flavor"  This food would have been bad if it was free, yet it cost me about $70.  I would suggest just going to Eleven or driving to NYC for a better joint.  OH, worth saying, our server was absolutely perfect!  What a shame.  :)  -This review was brought to you by Mr. BlueJay and the letter N

z1_YDk2tMwRYXwhFm7b3Og.text: I've eaten here a couple times and the atmosphere is nice and the interior of the restaurant seems clean. Service when we went both times pretty quick and the servers were nice.   I am not a major fan of this type of food as it turns out which is disappointing so I'm probably not the best judge of that. That being said, I do like shrimp and grits which I tried here. I thought the grits were a little bland but it was otherwise okay and I would give it another shot if I came: Also, I have had their flatbreads which I did really like and would try again. I'd recommend it to anywhere coming if you don't really like creole. I have had better food in the real NOLA though of course but this isn't bad.   Everything here seemed sort of average to me so while I'd come back if someone else wanted to but wouldn't pick it myself.

-aCweEF-rHrl9rvtBH1KWQ.text: Friday night at 6:30 and it's totally empty! What?? It's happy hour from 4-7. They really do have a great happy hour menu. From food to drinks it's cheap and delicious! Tonight I have the white wine sangria, stuff mushrooms and perogies. I was underwhelmed by the perogies. They were just okay. My sangria was so good! I highly recommend for happy hour.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

DReoVN6NeeRq74OgXt92VQ.text: Took 30 min for a happy hour size beans n rice ?? This place is a joke . FYI THIS is my 3rd attempt at this joint. Fuck this shit

RmKjNX9qwsSQXe2hMrkbMg.text: The happy hour lasts about an hour past every other one in town! Loved the drinks! We had flatbread, stuffed mushrooms and pierogis. The pierogis were ok, I've had better but definitely homemade. The flatbread was good. We were there for appetizers.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. great drinks!

vAETrWCAgtrHbYgRP5sVsg.text: We ate here on a Saturday night and I have to tell you it was fantastic. The alligator and pork shank to start was awesome. We shared the quail, jumbolia, scallop Mac and cheese, and shrimp and grits. Everything was awesome from the food to the service to the plating.   Next time I am in Pittsburgh I will be coming back

uphihykm2NqBzt1cz4_rUw.text: Came here with a group. It was very lovely in the back room , the decorations were cool. The music was some sort of strange 90s/2000s station where they were playing blink 182, self esteem by the offspring, I just wanna fly, and some other odd tunes to hear at a place that was charging $19.00-$30.00 per dinner entree.   The other reviews were right. Don't come here unless for lunch, its way overpriced for what you get, and it's not that novel.   They're often out of the thing you want, for example, my friend wanted to order stouts, they were all out, he then tried to order two other beers, all out. My other friend wanted the sidecar cocktail.  All out. It was disappointing.    We had a big group, but it took over an hour for our food to come out.  One of the 3 main servers that was helping with our group was nice, the other two were visibly angry that they had to help our group, so it felt like anyone in a group shouldn't eat here unless you want to be resented by the staff.    The food was subpar. Not awful, just not great. I got the $19 chicken and dumplings, where the crispy sage leaves were the best part, overall, just some charred bird in the tiniest bit of gravy. My partner got the margarita flatbread, which had lemons on every slice. It was interesting, but not great. My friend who got the catfish wish the cornbread souffle let me have some, I thought it was very good, decent seasoning and flavor, but small portion.   The gendered bathrooms also didn't seem well tended too. The stalls were out of toilet paper.   All in all, there are better restaurants in the square that'll treat you well with good food and good service. Go to them.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bottles and mock tail drink menu
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Draft menu
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Cocktail list

uuhlXsQYDl_1o__oVlPLUg.text: I heard NOLA was really good. Taking inspiration from New Orleans cuisine, I expected it to stand up to that testament. It did not.  Service was fine, but the voodoo pasta I got was basically just spaghetti sauce with hot sauce. You could make it yourself with exactly those three ingredients, and not spend more than $5 on them. My boyfriend got the pork tenderloin and sent it back because it was very... very dry. Management replaced it with the andouille flatbread which was ok. Then they gave us a complementary dessert which was, again, ok.  I cannot recommend you go here to eat.  NOLA deserves 2 stars instead of 1 only because of the redeeming quality of the waitstaff's service and management's attempts to make it right.

bzaMGF03iHxxcVFfwowPDw.text: Interesting and unique creole and southern menu options like alligator, crawfish and fried green tomatoes. Cauliflower soup was overly salted, but my friends said the seafood bisque was fabulous.  Po boys (sandwiches) had generous portions, but bread is way too thick making eating these almost impossible.  Bread should be thinner & sandwiches really need to be cut in half.  Service from Isiah was friendly, quick and attentive.  Plus Isiah is missing his calling and should go into modeling :-).  Overall an enjoyable & unique experience.

8U7reRCq5mNS_x11IhoqfQ.text: Would be five stars but they no longer have the separate vegetarian/vegan menu (despite it being on their website), our server informed us they don't do that anymore when we went this weekend. They were one of the few restaurants in the city that offered that option which was wonderful. They have fewer vegetarian options now compared to what's on the vegetarian menu listed on the website and the combined menu creates confusion because items such as the flatbread aren't listed as vegetarian due to the option of adding meat.

T9SMaoaJR2izrkMtPgiquQ.text: Went on a Saturday night and it was busy, as I suspected it would be. Don't go without a reservation because the wait is very long. We ordered the alligator for an appetizer and it was very good! I ordered the southern fried chicken sandwich and my friend ordered the grilled catfish. The food was good and the drinks were good! I would definitely eat here again!

osaOqw-IuCtfDDoRVhjDiA.text: Panera bread does a better job of serving overpriced soggy sandwiches. Extremely disappointing.

DpNxHVMC-UmTN7UfJ3L1Lg.text: We had tickets to go to the Pirates game on this Sunday afternoon.  So we made brunch reservations to Nola so we could have a few drinks and some good food before we walked over to the baseball game.              We weren't sure if it was going to be busy or not so we made reservations just to be safe.  They opened at 11am and our reservations were at 1115.  We were the first customers to arrive that morning but I'm still glad that we made reservations.  Soon after this it did start to get busy.         We were greeted right away and taken to our seats.  Our waitress was training somebody so we have to girls waiting on us.  I felt a little rushed with our drink orders and looking at the menu.  They gave us a minute to look it over and came right back.  This is usually fine but we really needed a few more minutes.  We both ordered Beermosas!   We used Miller lite and mixed it with our orange juices.  It was a good combination for the morning and a perfect drink right before afternoon baseball.       My wife ended up ordering the Eggs Trivette.  She said it did sort of remind her of an eggs benedict.  She liked it.  I really wasn't hungry for breakfast food right then so I ordered their Nola Burger.  That really hit the spot for me.  It's a big burger with cheese, cornmeal fried green tomatoes, and onion marmalade.  It was juicy and delicious!  My hamburger came with their Voodoo fries.  They were seasoned very well and I enjoyed the fries.  This early lunch was really good and it was the perfect combination right before the Pirate game.       Overall we did have a good brunch.  I wasn't that big of a fan over their brunch menu but my wife did like hers.  The lunch and dinner menus are probably more for me which is why I really enjoyed my burger.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. I just ordered a non alcoholic beverage by mistake... ugh!
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Nola Burger
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beermosa to start

Jpxgg_uZTa-U3eY9ALXdAA.text: Brunch was meh - their "brunch jambalaya" is a heavy portion of cubed potatoes mixed with tomato sauce, 4 slices of andouille sausage,  2 shrimp and a very runny sunny side up egg. Photographs well but is not a good dish.  I should've known when our waiter in training (who greeted us with "how are y'all doing tonight" on Easter Sunday morning) said it was his favorite....  hubby liked his fried alligator po boy (but commented that bc it was so breaded he couldn't taste the alligator (which to me may have been a good thing?), and girls were satisfied with their french toast and vegetable cheese omelet.  The fruit that accompanied it was standard cut up melon and pineapple and grapes, like what you might get at a hotel's free breakfast buffet (aka institutionally packaged). Beignets were lukewarm and underwhelming, as was my coffee.  I chose this place at the last minute from a short list of available open brunch places for Easter... so I was grateful they were open but bottom line disappointed in the food and wouldn't recommend it.  Positives- reasonable prices, big space, and lots of tables.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

S679vLQjJV-vZpCZcbE7sA.text: It was very good food and I can't believe it's taken me this long to come out here and try it.  I loved the atmosphere and our waiter was attentive and helpful.  We went with a large group which sometimes means dinner can take a long time, but I didn't feel like we were a struggle for the restaurant.   A bunch of us tried the fried alligator which was very delicious.  I'm a huge fan of duck and pretty much get it anywhere we go, and NOLA was no exception.  It was cooked well and they even made the swiss chard taste good.  I ate everything.  The sweet potatoes were legendary.  I would love to figure out how to make my own version of these.  To finish we all ordered beignets with ice cream or sorbet and they were delicious.   We definitely left with a hefty bill, but the food was worth it.

hiaoDnZc_m6amL89wY4JUA.text: What an enjoyable experience!  The weather today is perfect for outdoor seating, and today's special was fantastic.  It is the apple cole slaw that made the po-boy.  It really added a fantastic kick to the blackened chicken.  The service was also stellar.  I was seated right away, where I wanted to sit, and the table service also was quick yet not hurried, and courteous.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Blackened chicken poboy with Apple coleslaw.  Special of the day.
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Nice way to serve water!
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. View from my outside table

2avrelW_piLCGk2YIBF1Ew.text: NOLA is a can't-miss for all you adventurous diners. There are definitely some unique options on the menu. I was skeptical, but any restaurant that offers a vegetarian/vegan menu earns some brownie points automatically. The decor exudes an upbeat, jazzy atmosphere to complement their New Orleans vibe. I'm a sucker for unique restaurant themes, no matter how corny.   They provide lunch specials where you can mix and match soup, salad, and sandwiches, but unfortunately, the vegetarian selections are not included in this deal. I ordered the Spinach Summer Salad to start and it was delicious. Fresh and fruity with a nice crunch from the almonds. After cleaning off the salad, it was time for the Vegan Rice Creole. Amazing!! It's essentially rice mixed with a tomato salsa topped with carrots and peas. I know it sounds a bit off, but trust me, it's phenomenal. The portion is also big enough for a second meal which is always a plus.   Oh, by the way, the voodoo fries are a must! I'm not sure what dark magic they use to season the fries, but I couldn't stop eating them until every last one was gone. Insanely addicting!

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Summer Spinach Salad
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Vegan Rice Creole

hxa5RQXvToUWObO9qKOB8w.text: I wasn't sure I was going to like NOLA initially looking at the menu, but they really surprised me and were fantastic.   I myself had the Jambayla and split a flatbread with some friends and would order either again.      The service was fantastic as well both as we waited at the bar for a table and during the meal as well.

uwGiM85LEvETe7iqzyST7A.text: Stopped in for a late lunch, sat outside with our dog.  The service was excellent, our waitress Olivia was super friendly and cheerful .  The app, Fried Green Tomatoes were the best we ever had, that includes the ones from New Orleans.  Super crunch and fantastic spices with a sauce that's to die for.  My wife had a chopped salad with chicken.  The salad should have been chopped a little more, plain Iceberg lettuce, chicken was so so and the hush puppy croutons was a total miss. I had the Shrimp & Grits.  The flavor and plating was spot on!  The spic had the right amount of heat, the shrimp was grilled to perfection.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Shrimp &amp; Grits  yum yum !
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Fried Green Tomatoes !

gP1u2AuKT6Unx4rJGIwKRQ.text: Not a fan. Food is OK. Weak happy hour. A bit too dark and a strange /cramped layout around the bar.

xXXoRx0crQEX0_G8k03EbA.text: While the atmosphere is good, found the pulled pork bland and the service soooooooo slow - and there is no one here (I wonder why...) If you decide to come here block off 2.5 hours because that's how long it takes to get served for lunch. Next time I am back in Pittsburgh I am going to pass on coming back here.

n_2RWbUrdcug5Kzuzgd_Cg.text: Beautiful decor and ambiance. Very accomodating staff and courteous. They will prepare the food as you ask them and there is a vegetarian/vegan menu.  Had a nice team with my group of 10 that were promply seated!

8elKq9PXYeyGSKQ1KDAJSw.text: A special date night started in Market Square and to Nola's. A crowded and hectic entry way soon passed when we were led to a private little booth. We started with the sangria and it was the best I've ever had!  So, my wonderful date and I had a few more of those smooth wonders. Then for the appetizer:  The fried green tomatoes were amazing. Not sure what the sauce is that comes with them but it makes them pop.  A wedge salad was very good then for the main course I ordered the trout and he went for the jumbalia (can't spell it, but you know what I mean). Totally hot and spicy, it was almost too much for me! My boyfriend and I like to share dishes so we switched mid dinner.  The trout was mild and the rice with it was a great contrast to the hot hot hot Jumba- you know- the Brussel sprout side dish that came with the trout was the only disappointing part of the meal. An odd horseradish sauce made them just not good enough to finish.  A server with a less than sweet attitude was okay but provided good service.  The fun artwork added a nice touch. We definitely recommend this place and will be back again! Thanks Nola.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Dishes with sangria in pretty glasses
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Fun artwork deco
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Jambalaya

eS8xs6qLk6nc2WDkXqlpZw.text: As out-of-owners we went to Nola on the recommendation of a Pittsburgh local and we were not disappointed. Glad we were not deterred by the noisy bar scene at the front of the restaurant, however, because the dining area was well insulated from the noise level at the bar.  This is convenient to Heinz Hall for those attending a concert, and the Cajun style food was well prepared.

V1po6qHEkEnCAkQ4GoEE_A.text: The service is fantastic! We had the pizza, amazing! My husband had the Roast beef, it wasn't what he expected and they happily replaced it for the turkey! So nice! The fries are what stole the show! Really, you must try!

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Voodoo Fries! A must try!

uk5Qm_Y-MbQVqQZKVcltUw.text: NOLA is always on my list of go-to's for Market Square restaurants. I have had dinner and lunch here are various times and have always had an excellent meal.   My latest foray to NOLA was for drinks before a late dinner. So let's move on...   Atmosphere: Love the atmosphere at NOLA, it's why I continue to come back! I've been to New Orleans and it definitely takes me back. It has all the pomp and circumstance that I expect of the Big Easy. The one downfall was when I was visiting they had a jazz musician singing and while the music was fantastic, it was so loud I couldn't hear or talk to my date unless we were screaming at each other.   Service: Our bartender was fantastic! He chatted us up and answered questions we had about the drink menu. Made and muddled my drink in front of us. The drawbacks were the one drink is actually hard to drink bc there is so much stuff muddled into it, and then when I ordered wine they were out of wine glasses for a solid 30 minutes. For a busy downtown bar / restaurant, how do you run out of wine glasses?! Needless to say, neither ruined my experiences with our night, just minor inconveniences.   Drinks: Solid beer draft choice. Drink list was very interesting, but like I said above, it was hard to drink one of their cocktails because there was so much in it. Wine list was solid.   All in all, I'm always going to make NOLA a stop.

pegZlfP0ZWD1rqESKKKefw.text: Went for brunch on a Sunday morning and was pretty disappointed. The beignets were an absolute joke, small and crunchy, NOTHING like what you would find in New Orleans. The shrimp and grits also left much to be desired. We won't be back.

7H5cxPGuWHmo-7lqwuHFTw.text: I give this place props for even having vegetarian and vegan options. But everything we ordered was far too salty, smothered in oil, and served luke-warm.   The ambiance was bad. Rickety table and horrible lighting accompanied our dingy back dining room.  Service was actually decent, and our waitstaff was very nice.

6pi7qebP0DZ1NLvFKxPwQA.text: We visited Nola on Saturday night for a late dinner with friends.  Overall, I was incredibly impressed with the service and the food.  My husband had the jambalaya which was appropriately spicy but I thought the tomato sauce was a bit to acidic.  However, the chef did accommodate my husband's request to substitute more scallops for shrimp (he doesn't like shrimp).  My husband also tried the frog legs which he said were OK but not great.  I tried the sauce and the sauce was spicy and very tasty.  I had the filet mignon with swiss chard and squash puree.  The steak was perfectly prepared and the squash puree was creamy and delish!  I didn't eat all the greens because I'm not a big fan of swiss chard - however, the greens were appropriately prepared and not overcooked.  We also tried the butternut squash soup with crawdad tails.  I felt it was under-salted, but otherwise tasty.  Our friends really enjoyed the duck pasta and the mushroom bread pudding.  They had ordered the fried green tomatoes as an appetizer, but it didn't appear until our meals had arrived.  Our server was gracious and had it removed from our bill.  The creme brulee is amazing and the panna cotta was outstanding!  One thing that impressed me the most was that the manager came over to check on us several times.  He also had a very thorough knowledge of the whiskey selection and was able to give our friend several very good alternatives to suit her palette.  The beer selection was decent if you're a hop head (which I am).  However, if you aren't into hops, you might find yourself unable to find a suitable beer.  I asked for a table that was near the band but not too close as to preclude any conversation.  I'm happy to say that our table was close enough the music for us to enjoy it and still be able to hear our friends.  Overall, I was incredibly impressed with Nola.  The inconsistent Yelp reviews made me squeamish about visiting, but I'm very glad that I did.  The restaurant is pricey, but the portions are decent and the food is quite good.  This is not the place to go if you have some place to be.  However, if you're in the mood for some music and a leisurely meal, I would recommend Nola.  One thing to remember, don't expect to show up on a weekend and get a table.  Reservations are a must!

jsB9EEG0btWg2toQXbalLw.text: Very friendly busy happening place. Busy on a Tuesday night mainly due to happy hour.  Great menu phenomenal beers.

E7-Zp5yz0ku-ZH_726zM_Q.text: I really enjoyed my dinner at Nola. We ordered some reasonably priced wine and a meat and cheese plate when we first sat down. I would absolutely recommend the meat and cheese plate. It was simple but delicious and huge for the price. I had the jambalaya which was also very good. Our server was very courteous and made some good recommendations. My only complaint is that they were out of quite a few things- such as scallops and the fish of the day- and the kitchen seemed to be annoyed at our substitutions for the out of stock seafood. We heard one chef or cook admonish our waitress for allowing us to substitute catfish for scallops in jambalaya. If you are out of multiple menu items, it is only reasonable to allow some leeway with otherwise inappropriate substitutions. We did get our catfish but the chef could have been a little more accommodating to the server's request. Overall though, it was a really great meal.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Seafood jambalaya
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Generous meat and cheese plate

QJbWk2e31f3qbqr2fqObQA.text: Great location, music and fun decor/ambiance. The food was pretty good - our favorite was the side dish of jambalaya.

daM-bkrnjbgnKgcHd_cTSw.text: Better than last time. First time since remodeling.  Nola salad was decent.  It had mixed greens and roasted nuts. The jambalaya improved from the last time i had it. On the expensive side for $27.  Wish it had more seafood and less rice. Tough to eat here on an expense account. Drinks are around $10. Add tax and tip and you have 40 bucks and i just had water. 50 dollars per day doesnt go far.  Service was ok. Nice to sit outside. Water refills were slow with a spicy dish. Had to ask for bread and then it was nothing special.

c75QFqWZE084QBDwxPpUuw.text: First of all, I'm a fan of Seviche and the Sonoma Grille, so I had fairly high expectations walking in to the newly renovated NOLA...and I wasn't disappointed.  I have nothing but good things to say! The band was outstanding - sort of a Cherry Poppin' Daddies, jazz rock, kind of vibe. Our waitress was great and the food was excellent - the service was immediate and fast. We only had appetizers but I was impressed by the freshness of the fried green tomatoes, the perfect grill on the in-house sausage, and lack of grease with the hush puppies.   Overall, I absolutely intend to go back for a full meal; and, expect this to become a 5-star rating.

PeQvKV3QBKjQpeMsUPjwKw.text: Three stars for our waitress, alone! She was absolutely amazing! But the food took entirely too long to come out, was really expensive, and REALLY mediocre. We came because of their "vegan menu," but they only had rice available for my vegan coworker. Both of my boss' steaks came out overcooked. The jambalaya tasted spicy, yet lacked flavor (think El Monte canned tomato paste mixed with raw peppers). My other coworker had the shrimp and grits and had to force herself to finish, as it was over-seasoned. I hope our phenomenal waitress takes her talent somewhere that deserves it! I would not come again, at these prices.

2NolXPVqrdwdO8fYMsvt3w.text: My alligator bites were more like alligator crumbs. I had rice and beans which were serve lukewarm. My granddaughters fried green tomatoes tasted watery and were not crisp. A very diappointing experience. Would not go again or recommend it to anyone.

zsmjcbP1GOxEstlUcwn9cQ.text: Before I dive into the negatives, let me say that the entire staff was friendly and accommodating. I had absolutely no qualms about the service.   This used to be one of my favorite lunch/dinner spots for memorable and delicious cuisine. However; ever since the menu/head chef was changed, the menu appears to have nose dived. The frog leg appetizer portion has been cut in half and covered in an unnecessary sauce. The soup cups were so shallow, I only got a thimble's worth of broth. Lastly, my pulled pork sandwich was 60% un-chewable fat. I had noticed that the appetizers were lacking during a recent happy hour, and I had written it off as a one-time fluke. Sadly, it appears that the menu quality as a whole is not what it used to be. Can't say I'll be going back.

A0041F-1TTPqKTiri2CAiQ.text: Excellent. Authentic New Orleans food as good as I've had outside of New Orleans. The place looks, feels and tastes like New Orleans. Definitely worth a visit when in Pittsburgh. Also a great location right on Market Square.  Beignets almost as good as Cafe Du Monde. Po'Boys were on perfectly baked French Bread. The oysters and shrimp were perfectly seasoned and fried.  Outdoor seating seating available.   A taste of New Orleans in Pittsburgh of all places.

qdzJZXLuy8CRaPSYVjeJtQ.text: Great Waldorf salad awesome blue cheese dressing. Shrimp and scallop Mac and cheese was incredible. Wife had shrimp and grits creamy grits tons of flavor

28xmTnLlOj7tGeNMzVgWoA.text: Pretty good southern food fare! Reservations are a must, otherwise there may be a long wait, although last time we waited around 20 minutes when they had told us it'd be 45-60 minutes. There was a $5 off for joining loyaltree's iphone app and scanning the QR code inside the bill folder. So yay for unexpected and extra discounts.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Fried artichokes!

cnLe_JxFcr-ULwkquViC9w.text: I've only been in once for lunch but if the rest of the menu is comprable to the blackened shrimp I had, then I can certainly stand by NOLA. Best blackened shrimp of my life. Excellent little salad. Portion wise it was just right for lunch (maybe a bit on the small size but that's how I like to eat). Waiter was attentive and quick with suggestions. Overall a very successful meal. Would definitely try this place again.

paQd1n75W1p8oWiWFYmmVg.text: Do yourself a favor, and get the alligator. No it is not "kinda like chicken." It's a different taste, a different texture and whole lot of goodness. The sauce drizzled on the lightly battered, crispy pieces of alligator tail meat has the right amount of kick to make you close your eyes and go, "yummmm" and secretly wish that your dinner buddies that you are sharing this with would disagree and not eat a lot of the crunchy, fried alligator bites and so you can devour them all.  Well, that ain't happening! It is THAT good! I got the quail as dinner. I didn't want a piece of blackened fish or something that I could make myself! So quail it was! The bed of wild rice and oyster dressing is delicious. The quail itself is juicy with a crispy skin.  One of my friends raved about the gumbo. Another had the cornmeal crusted tilapia (special) of the night. The cooking here is done very very well. The cornmeal crust is just perfect, crusty, yet juicy fish on the inside. The experience is truly great and kinda unique. The bar is crazy busy, the seating area is vibrant with people of all ages enjoying their food. A happy crowd is always a sign of a great restaurant.  The portions here are more on the Pittsburgh portion side. The place has valet parking, I didn't know about it until I parked, so don't know the details. There are quite a few garages around Nola.

5pLJAOm-056O2818HqY8dg.text: This place would have been at least a 4 if I hadn't been to New Orleans last week. My food was pretty good. I got the Jambalaya. It needed a bit more of a kick, so they provided hot sauce, but that's really not the same. As mentioned in the other reviews, the red beans and rice was amazing, and the quail that my brother got was awesome. My problem came with the ambiance, the price, and the beignets. Even though my group was seated in the dining area, the jazz music overwhelmed any conversation that may have been had. We also got the beignets for dessert and they were more cake-y and dense than any other beignets I've had, resulting in a really underwhelming desert. On top of that, the price was a bit high for the quality of food. I would recommend this place more for the bar and music than for the restaurant end.

A0iSm8CKG1CHJWpQm8tzGA.text: Great Cajun food and good service. The waiter was able to answer all our questions and provided awesome recommendations. I had the Blackened Red Fish (Red Beans & Rice with Blackened White Fish and Coleslaw) and my friend had the Jambalaya. Both dishes I recommend trying. They were awesome. We had the fried alligator for a appetizer. A little tough and chewy. I guess it was good, never had alligator before--Just had to try it.

cvxMjmYIBzWzmevpgiAudw.text: Tried this based on pressure from the group I was with. I am generally wary of restaurants in touristy squares. We shared a whole bunch of apps and mains amongst the group. All of the fried bits as starters were good. One plate had a pork shank that was really good. Mains included quail and the hanger steak. Both were tasty.  Was it an epic culinary experience? No. Was I glad we went there? Yup. The food was good enough and it was fun. The good food, unpretentious atmosphere, good beer list and great service all came together to earn this four stars.

FOKHLcpNPVOe2OTmxPaMfA.text: Nola never disappoints! I've been three times in the past 6 months and it's always just so yummy. The service is wonderful and it's affordable.  I don't so much like the decor. It feels dated somehow, but that's just personal taste. Try the red beans and rice! To die for!

PxTtSssKaEHm066HXmASlA.text: I've been to New Orleans and eaten my way through that glorious city and I can safely say that NOLA is not really representative of New Orleans food.  The Partner In Cuisine and I split an alligator appetizer, a po'boy, and a mufaletta, but they had been "Pittsburghized."  The Voodoo Fries were just french fries with seasoned salt.  Fortunately for them, the lack of New Orleans authenticity didn't take away from the fact that the food was tasty.  I'll definitely go back  to indulge in some Abita (since it's not an easy find in Pittsburgh) and perhaps the alligator, but I think I'll leave the other dishes for when I go back to New Orleans!

p_FOdgRu5Ys2l2VIjDg_xA.text: Pretty average place. Alligator appetizer was overly greasy, hard to tell what kind of meat was in there. The mains were over-sauced but filling and relatively tasty. A better beer selection would improve things as well.

NWoZv8p-UP5cqG79rcuJww.text: I'll be fair, I only tried one dish, but at the moment I'm annoyed - and starving.  I ordered shrimp & grits, which is a lunch entree.  The other plates I could see around me looked generous, big sandwiches, lots of fries, or a big bowl salad and half a sandwich on the side.  My entree was more expensive than the sandwich plates, and  it came with ... nothing.  I got a gigantic plate-bowl with about half a cup of grits and four shrimp in the bottom.  An appetizer sized portion at best, and no bread, crackers, salad or anything else.  The grits were bland and runny, and the shrimp was overcooked and too salty.  Basically, this "main course" was a small cup of mediocre soup for $20.

cUwPKwwliDlnDYCD7jY4gA.text: TERRIBLE..Woodfired flatbread pizza, sausage and crawfish. Not a flatbread just pizza dough that was very flimsy. Way too much cheese. Crawfish disgusting, fishy flavor. Sausage ok. Also had gator app. Best part was the creole sauce. Plates were dirty. Nola is a nogo

yhr4BLagbB2Y7Yk5Sb6W0g.text: Visited twice, for lunch and dinner, and both meals were great.  Good portions, although the shrimp po' boy was a little heavy on the bread.  The bar was extremely loud, and we found it difficult to hear each other even when we were screaming from a foot away. Definitely recommend the red beans and rice though...and most noticeable was the great service!

kUVFglF_uoyhrYffk98JjA.text: Friend is the manager so down here for lunch. I'd been hearing about this and was treated pretty well since I was with the manager, but the server was not very good. My friend had to get up and get our own food, drinks, etc... The gumbo was just ok, the beer was great, and the desert was tasty.

JpvKR6t9kascBOxUj_SYIQ.text: Wow was really looking forward to trying this place out while we were in the Burgh and I am sorry to say I was not impressed. The decor and service were great but the food was OK at best. The alligator was all breading, the fried green tomatoes were lame and my blackened fish was so dry it turned to dust when I touched it. Another person at our table got the same fish and it was cooked the same way which was too much. The scallops and noodles with cheese was by far the best dish at the table but even that lacked scallops. The alcohol selection was good and the cocktail I had with milk and bourbon (can't remember the name) was very tasty. Unfortunately the next time I am in pittsburgh I will be dining elsewhere.

UCVgBvUEJzOfgXRFL-Jmvg.text: Food was okay. Had the flatbread, which was a little burnt. The shrimp appetizer was underwhelming. Service was good. Good wine selection. Would go there one more time to try the jambalaya and alligator meat.

fbR8355YK6ABFagQJoDPfg.text: Great atmosphere, service and food.  Only thing that keeps me from giving it a 5 star rating is the fact that they didn't serve bread or rolls and the time between our appetizers and dinners was a little long.  I had shrimp and grits and it was absolutely awesome!  My husband had a Mac Daddy pasta dish that was chockfull of seafood, my son had the jambalaya, also full of seafood.  My other son said his peach cobbler was the best he ever ate!  Food portions were large, we all had a doggie bag for home.  Everything was perfectly seasoned, felt as if we were eating cajun food from they bayou!  Bar area noisy, we ate in the dining area--quite nice!

XHS2jw8EOISZC-youyDUgQ.text: Read some of the reviews and just had to go it was worth the walk great food and drinks.... :)

WPJzyDxhDOajjYlUvHDgbw.text: WOW... granite I have not been to Nola's in about a year. We went there over the weekend just because I have always loved their fried shrimp. They limited their menu to absolutely nothing. Fried shrimp was taken off. No biggy, although for a New Orleans based restaurant, how can you not have fried shrimp. Thats ok, I ordered the craw-fish... waitress said, I am sorry, we are out of craw-fish. Again New Orleans based restaurant without shrimp nor craw-fish. I then ordered the pulled pork sandwich that stated it came with onion rings on top, literally, one onion ring. The sandwich was cold, the bun was hard. Ohhh and when I tried to go healthier with fruit cup. Sorry, we are out of fruit cup, I went with the fries, please change your oil more then once every six months please. We also ordered the Gumbo and flatbread. Those were not to bad, but we had to ask for silverware and napkins. The restaurant was not crowded at all, there was no reason why we needed to ask for utensils. So disappointed. Please try another restaurant before stopping here. I don't know if you are under new management, but please get it together.

48c1kq1Zjs6gJmNO6vBLJA.text: I had dinner at NOLA on a Saturday evening before a Pens game with my son. Our 5:15pm arrival allowed for no waiting and a relaxing meal with plenty of time, (almost an hour) to walk to Console Energy Center afterward.     We received quick and friendly service. The waitress was very helpful with her suggestions. We enjoyed a Shrimp Po Boy and the NOLA Burger both served with fries in Voodoo Dust which were a big hit!!      The French Onion Soup is VERY good and also a great value as it is topped with gruyere cheese. A definite must try and worth the trip itself!    We were both pleased that NOLA was our choice for our pre game meal and I will soon return!

jZffA7eLrqEj97AUYYcB9Q.text: We started off with the crab bisque. I ordered the jumbalaya and my wife went with the  shrimp & grits. Both dishes were excellent. We finished off the meal with creme brulee. Excellent food, excellent drinks, excellent service. Top drawer experience.

9uZY0kHUZkXs7FgehvhcPw.text: I went for the first time for an early dinner around 4:30 PM on Sunday prior to going to see a show at Heinz Hall.  We opted to sit inside instead of outside to avoid the cigarette smoke coming from people smoking outside the restaurant but nearby to the outdoor seating.  My cousin has been here many times and loves it and we've traveled to New Orleans together around 20 times over the last 15 years so I was excited that she recommended it so highly.  The restaurant has a fairly extensive cocktail, beer, and wine list and my cousin ordered a beer but I ordered a glass of wine and felt that the pour was very small for the price.  For our appetizers and main courses, she ordered the gumbo and the BBQ shrimp (from the appetizer menu) and I ordered the Cajun chowder and was torn between the shrimp and grits and the scallops and shrimp mac daddy, but upon our servers recommendation and because I'm a sucker for shrimp and grits, I went with the shrimp and grits (which at least another reviewer mentioned that it is really overpriced at $27 - believe me, the quality of the grits and the amount of shrimp that you get for the $27 is far from worth the money).  My cousin tried my chowder and I tasted her gumbo and I found the flavors of both the be tasty though I felt that the gumbo was a little under-seasoned while the chowder was flavorful but overly salty.  Our main courses arrived and again we shared a taste of each other's dishes.  The BBQ shrimp was very flavorful but again overly salty and the shrimp and grits were a mixed bag in my opinion.  The sauce on top of the grits with the shrimp was the same as the sauce on the BBQ shrimp plus it had the addition of very salty bacon yet the grits on their own were rather bland and even mixing them together to mingle the flavors did not cut down on the excessive saltiness in the dish.  I am someone who actually prefers my food on the saltier side so the mere fact that I am actually complaining about how salty everything was means that it was quite over salted.  I could feel my ankles swelling as the meal came to a close.  We also shared the beignets for dessert.  The trio of sorbet that came with the beignets was delicious and refreshing and but the beignets were a little flat and dense compared to the beignets that I've had in New Orleans but tasty.  Overall I would go back but I would probably keep to the lower priced items because I feel that much of their menu is overpriced for what you get.

ktf9yz-4GtwarUXQUGfDCQ.text: Oh my gosh Nola - now when this place opened everyone talked about it and loved it and raved and I never went. Finally this weekend I got the chance to experience and I thought it was great. The wine selection (which was what I wanted) was great and to be honest I just wanted some pasta so when they turned out to have pasta I was a happy camper. I very much recommend the dish I had, the Pasta Pontchartrain. There was a little kick to the sauce and the meat and crawfish in the dish were perfect.  Everyone in my party had a great meal - I'm pretty sure the grit cakes were called the best meal my dining partner had ever had. The staff was very friendly and knowledgeable and the environment was fun -I'm going to go ahead and highly recommending trying this place.

cM_e-OuZibn_HnwxUSCTUg.text: Maybe some of the worst food and service I've ever had...anywhere. I think our server had never ever even eaten in a restaurant before starting work at Nola. We were there for almost two hours since it took  so long for food and she came to out table three times.  We had to ask the manager where our food was after an hour.  It was a Sunday and the restaurant was about a third full. The 'bone-in' short ribs was a fatty pot roast (literally sitting in a clear pool of fat on my platter) there were no bones or flavor.  The grits had a dried layer on top from sitting under a heat lamp. I used to frequent Nola when it opened. It was great and I don't know what happened.

Bqa4mL-nlhZsFIZYd1Iknw.text: Yay for Team Nola!   By that I specifically mean Jackie the event coordintor, Jen the mgr, Joyce and Matt for service. I live in Atlanta and theyhelped me execute my Dad's 75th bday party last weekend even while planning from a remote location!   We used the speakeasy upstairs and It wasan event for 30 close friends and family.  The setup was awsome, service was fun and lively, food reviews were very good.   Our menu consisted of Crab cakes and Fried green tomatoes, Crab Bisque, Salad, Lemon Catfish, the Filet, and the Pasta. Everyone loved the fish and the filet. The pasta was a little spicey for most to finish but they still said it was good.   As far as the service, Joyce and Matt were AMAZING and formed great connections with my hostess crew. They also helped us transform the room to a True harlem rennesance type of look and made our set up and breakdown smooth and easy. We brought, in our own desserts bar and Nola supported with brining out the birthday cake. We had music in room and people could flow downstairs for the live music if they chose. Lukily we were fun enought that no one did. :-)   I do wish they had free wii fi to facilitate the music but that was a minor issue since I have a mobile hotspot.   Overall I'm very excited at the end results and Truely appreciate Jackie, Jen, Joyce, and Matt for helping me give Daddy an awsome memory! Go team Nola!

nYReSQBExdg_mpE5mGNPnw.text: far and away the best food and atmosphere of the 3 restaurants in this , for lack of a better word, chain.  Trully authentic Creole cuisine.  Loved the po'boy

9SleZlqFDLMYTqlpXukAVA.text: Really great food.  Fresh and unique.  It was a nice change!  Service was slow, though.

rrxZpJGbotMKZ-D9K-l45w.text: My friend and I ducked in here Saturday night for a bite and drinks before the ballet...and the main reason we went is because it was too cold to wander around looking for a place to eat.  We should've braved the cold...drinks were ok, I liked my Cajun Martini which had a little kick of jalepeno, that's why it gets two stars instead of one...the catfish appetizer was tasty but very small portion to share, and I was really looking forward to the Shrimp Po Boy since I haven't had a good one in years (in Pittsburgh)...well, it's mostly bun...and slaw/tomato 'filler' ...the bun was tough and cold, and the 4 shrimp on top were heavily breaded and not too tasty...I ate one off the top and sent it back.  Definitely not a $14 sandwich.  My friend said her burger was just "ok"..and she was never asked how she wanted it cooked...it came medium rare.  So with four drinks, a burger and appetizer our bill was $70.  With lackluster service (waiter was not very friendly), and the kitchen's inability to get even a simple 'signature' sandwich right...I'll never return.

b6JHxxMSmHqt1DDVRkAXaw.text: I enjoyed my meal here, but the atmosphere was quite loud, and I think geared a little bit more towards the younger, 'trendy' crowd.  There was a live band playing, and they were decent, but very loud to the point where it was pretty difficult to hear my date.  I got the salmon etoufee as my entree - I asked them to cook it medium rare, because so often I find that my dishes are slightly over cooked.  When it came out, it was definitely very rare - basically just quickly seared on both sides.  Now, I love raw salmon/sushi - so this actually didn't bother me as much as the average person, but both the seasoning and the sauce that it was in was very salty - and I love salty foods.  Though enjoyable, I don't think that this would be a destination for me, unless I happened to be in the downtable/Market Square area.

0tH4GhJyA8SkmmykOCQMfQ.text: Big time Bummer.  This would have been my fourth time going to NOLA for lunch and the first time that I have eaten at the tables as opposed to the bar-top.  We got in before the lunch-rush hit and were seated quickly and in a friendly manner.  Our waiter was quick to ask about out interests in food, take our drink order and walk is through the menu.  Service was good, so that wasn't the issue, the issue here was the food.  I ordered the Chicken Po Boy Sandwhich with a fruit salad instead of fries.  The whole meal was a disappointing, I only ate it because I was hungry and I didn't even do a good job at finishing my plate.  The chicken on the sandwich was dry, not oops it was grilled too long fry but oh dear me this might get stuck in my throat dry.  From there it was a series of unfortunate events.  The bread wasn't up to par with past sandwiches had and I stand by the thought that the bread to content ratio for the particular menu item is skewed in the favor of the bread.  The sausage was good but there was not enough kick to salvage the palate.  I can't remember if there was tomato or lettuce or any other veggie in it mostly because the biggest bummer overpowered the whole entree--the mustard.  It was there in dollops and it wasn't good in its own merit adding to the dryness of the whole sandwich.  Lastly, I chose the fruit salad in lieu of fries ... it was warm.  Now I understand if it's at room temperate in an air conditioned setting like the dining area ... but it was hot kitchen room temperature and biting into it didn't release cooler juices that might have survived the onslaught of the ambient heat in the back.  So that was a big bummer.  I hate that I didn't like the food because my first three times were very good experiences.  When I do return, I'll have to try a different lunch entree since I don't want to risk another Po-saster.

Hm0I6B8jIThVafXs4TZGUg.text: We couldn't resist stopping in at this place. The outside eating area is small and can get somewhat uncomfortable when many people are waiting to find a seat. This is made up for by the amazing band that was playing and the general ambiance of market square. Many people stopped to take pictures of the restaurant, patio, and band. This restaurant really adds to the market square environment.   We were told to grab any open seat on the patio since the indoor seating area was unavailable due to our lack of a reservation. This did not bother us and they were polite. The draft beer selection was good and their "house" IPA was decent. The alligator starter is crispy and smothered in a zesty sauce. Good stuff! The pork chop was huge and worth the price. Overall we loved this place due to the good food, service, and environment. Check it out while it is still warm.

160HnISEogk_cGEpCELk7g.text: Amazing food , service was wonderful and to top off the had a good jazz band will def be back

bzWhlDwKDcMNJZWVEQ9XUQ.text: Place is awesome!  Chicken Andouille Po Boy is off the hook!

-EAoNEanqYdVKeKJ8MqIEw.text: What a great experience at Nola on the Square!  Our server, Kathryn, was impeccable!  Her suggestions for food wand wine were spot on especially since she carefully listened to our food preferences...my wife being more of a fine french foodie and I a spicy buff.    The crawfish & sherry soup was tasty, more of a bisque with chunks of crawfish.  I had the fried gator tail.  Panko breaded chunks of tail with a beautiful creamy, but spicy sauce - the meat was fresh and sweet.    For our entrees we had the Scallops Mac Daddy - Beautifully prepared and the scallops were huge and perfectly done. I had the wood roasted quail. Two complete quail that were again perfectly done although my wife thought just a  tad over salted.

XmOCvTJ0oVd_xW5EXRim5Q.text: So, just......not great. At all. Was our second try with this place. We ordered apps for the table, didn't get plates to eat them on. Waited a full five minutes for the server to come after a food runner delivered apps, he never showed. Had to get up and go looking for him so we could have some plates.  Server took our silverware after we finished the appetizers, didn't give us new. Had to take them from a neighboring table because he went MIA again. The menu is heavily overpriced, the food is nice but definitely not worth the prices. Disappointing in that regard.  This place could be really fun and cool, it's trying so hard to be upscale and it's just so not. It's a Cajun/creole place, to me them atmosphere should be all about that. Fun, good zydeco music.....something?? Service was poor at best. We won't be back, too many great places downtown to eat that get it. We wanted to like it!

VLURfvc5zyqaWpOK1yNRaw.text: We came here for dinner on a Monday night while at a week-long conference downtown. The service was very good, and our server was very friendly and knowledgeable. Great music too, and the drinks were very good as well. Unfortunately, the food didn't blow us away. It was above average, just not great. Personally, I would have liked to see the catfish cooked a little more (you can't be too careful when it comes to undercooked seafood), but it was flavorful. Overall, I'd rate the total experience at 3.5 to 3.75 stars if Yelp would let me, and would give NOLA another shot if in the area.

VCPkfYCW9sPYZUF5xlCISQ.text: Found ourselves in search of food at 10pm, and we came across Nola.  Decided to give it a try, and we were so pleasantly surprised!  Menu is filled with unusual southern dishes including catfish, alligator, and frogs legs!  My party opted for lighter fair, being so late, but the portions were much larger than expected!  I had the chopped salad and added chicken to it.  Such delicious flavors!  And it was topped with a HUGE chunk of blue cheese! Plus had hush puppy croutons.  One of my friends had the French onion soup and was full about halfway through it.  The other had a flat bread pizza, she customized it a bit, but the waiter forgot that when he put the order in.  Told us that he goofed and had sent it back, and promptly brought out the corrected order.  The service was wonderful.  Also had really good water and supplied each table with a glass bottle for refills.  I highly recommend visiting this restaurant if you're in Pittsburgh!

NT9A6wVs_nLqB2PLKe1lHA.text: Food was good. Had a daily special of duck with butternut squash and some pasta. The duck was a little over spiced, but made up for hte pasta being under spiced. Added a little salt to help.   The service was a little slow, but the rest of the evening was good. Servers were very freindly, Price was a little steep. Overall, I'd go back.

SM0YlPG_S62Cfwb6sLlDTg.text: Atmosphere is nice. Food is okay, though not real New Orleans style presentation. I had the jumba yaya soup which lacked a little of the Cajun punch, I didn't care much for the lack of bread on the side.  The entree was the blackened salmon with pecan rice and shrimp etufee. The salmon was tasty the etufee was bland. The dish was good but not four stars. Seems like a popular place although I have found that after six years of travel to Pittsburgh, you don't come here for the food.

cBzih9-KMfsQyF72GJX0wA.text: Four of us went here before a Pens game.  The meat and cheese appetizer was the best item we had.  Shrimp and grits too bland.  Chicken and dumplings was too spicey.  Didn't mention that in the menu.  Seafood jambalaya was fishy.  Not very good.......sorry.

AzF7x8QXsXvihyT--1CAtQ.text: Food was not worth the price. Our server is under equipped to deal with the public. He should have one table and that table should be robots and that one table should not be ours. He forgot a drink order and claimed to not have heard my food order. He is untimely to refill drinks and seems absolutely insulted to write an order. If I was the manager, he would be retrained or doing something else. I actually had server envy as I observed several servers enjoying their job.  Food: Caesar salad was made with ice berg: Pizza lacked flavor outside of the green tomatoes Shrimp and grits is actually a grit type cake. Disappointed from the shrimp and grits 3 years ago.  Salad featuring Brussels sprouts was fortunate to have 2 Brussel sprouts in it.   Music was good. Just the right combo and the right loudness.   Nola is a no thanks!

mhnMgBQRpjTnEEGsqz0_ww.text: I was expecting New Orlean food .It was none of that .We ordered a plate of chhese and meat .I do better job at home and even presentation was not appealing . We ordered Jambalaya .It was not spicey and full of Ketchup and very pricey for the amount of food ..It tasted like a prefrozen and reheated food . We also ordered Cjun fish .It w3as not so bad ,but vegetable dish with it was terrible . For the price you pay ,it would not be on my list of Pitt restaurants to visit,even if I was not paying .It seems to be busy ,I guess most people do not know NORLEAS food

ZU25ageNyBwLzr3Rdc53yg.text: Annoyingly poor service and subpar food for the price point. Seems like a tourist trap on the same level as a Hard Rock Cafe. Avoid.

npIN3takDNZ-40RWRiL6GA.text: Stopped in before heading over to PPG place to ice skate. Kassandra was our bartender, she was awesome!! She helped my picky self choose  something great to drink. She had a lot of recommendations and was super friendly, efficient and attentive.  The French onion soup is by far the best I have ever had! My boyfriend had the shrimp fried sandwich and he really liked it as well. The other guy bartenders didn't really seem to care about us considering they came after we have been eating and they just seemed to care about talking about their personal lives right in front of us, must not have cared because they probably weren't getting apart of the tip, besides that everything was perfect!!!

XDhft_1gmLKJ1M_w3wha0g.text: This is a charming little restaurant in Market Square. We went on a weekend and had to wait quite a bit to get a table. It's a fun atmosphere with a Southern flare.   The item that I would recommend was the frog legs. I didn't absolutely love the texture of the meat -but then again I'd never tried frog legs before. But I could rant for days about the sauce it was served in. It was probably the most delicious "masala-y" dish I'd tasted in a while and we were literally licking the bowl clean.
