The french onion soup, on the other hand, was quite salty and too cheesy and overall not really worth ordering.  If I come back here, it'll be for the frog legs.

22M3crimN1dHQu2fMpYykg.text: Delicious Lunch! Decided to head to NOLA for a Monday Afternoon Lunch! Nice Creole New Orleans menu options. I got the Brassiere Steak Salad and it was delicious. Even though there were a fair amount of fries, the salad was still a healthier option from their menu. Steak was cooked perfectly as ordered Medium. Waitress / bartender was very nice, got my order and my coworker's order correctly ordered! I'm sure I will be back very soon!!

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. NOLA Brassiere Steak Salad was delicious!!

9peLXCrkLlK1eNj9ovB04A.text: My boyfriend and I went down to PPG ice rink to celebrate our anniversary, we wanted to grab something to eat before hand but weren't sure where to go. The sign for Nola stuck out to us so we decided to try it. Excellent food! I'm not much of a spicy food person, that's all him, so whenever the waitress said it was a Cajun restaurant I was unsure if I would like it or not but it was perfect for the both of us! Mildly hot for me and nice and spicy for him. The waitress was helpful, friendly, and attentive. I tried frog legs for the first time and was not by any means disappointed! Really cool atmosphere all together, and reasonably priced especially for the quality of food. Definitely going back!

ZdOJnWIzeo2qSlH9K9bPQA.text: Terrible service. Sat outside and the waitress was extremely rude. Left before we even ordered because it was so bad

iwNh7Kp-F7NHFe1TKgvZ8Q.text: I think the restaurant was okay. It's in the market square do it's a bit self important . The food is okay, I don't get an authentic NOLA vibe . True southern way crawfish and pull them apart, it's just what we do and how we prefer to eat crawfish.   I had a wedge salad and asked for no tomatoes. I got a wedge salad with tomatoes. No biggie, I just picked them out. We then had to ask for silverware, not that the runner cared. We also had to edit for napkins. This is not including the long wait for service or the okay food.  Overall, I'd go back just not in a hurry.

YmE_MEhsmyZONsXmuw_qMw.text: This is the best cajun food I've had since visiting actual NOLA.  I've been wanting to try this place since moving to the Burgh and my only regret was not trying it sooner.  From the front (and even in the bar area), it appears fairly small, but once you enter, there is a large dining room way in the back.  We visited on a Friday night without a reservation, so we waited about 15 minutes before a table in the bar was available.  Despite being very crowded, service was fantastic and friendly.  The downside was that it was VERY loud.  Especially once the band started.  We had the gumbo and rice and beans as our appetizers.  Both were fantastic and had a little bit of a kick.  The grit cake and the shrimp and grits were both amazing.  My one complaint is that the prices are quite high.  The food is high quality and the environment great, but $25 for shrimp and grits did seem a bit extreme.  I will be back!

t9zJ0nTrHehsFeLhR4Bhyw.text: This place is located in a centralized location in Downtown Pittsburgh. There are many options to choose from but this is the only Cajun place in the area. I hadn't tried cajun food before so I was super excited to try this place. I came right after lunch rush hour so we got seated right away. The waiter was quick and made recommendations. I ordered the Jambalaya which had shrimp, scallops, chicken, and sausage! It was super yummy with its tomato spicy sauce. I recommend this plate when the weather is NOT hot. The plate was super hot so it was hard to enjoy. Either way I recommend this place.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chicken wrap
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Jambalaya
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chicken chopped salad

Cy7RFEyLfa6iPPxzDPF9Vw.text: Great cocktails. We went for pre dinner drinks I had the blackberry old fashioned which was great but all the cocktails looked good.

VmgZPA1IlT0_MDwNbfxrvQ.text: The food would have been a 2, but the service and management were a 5, so I settled for 3, and hope to let them redeem themselves.  Here goes... First, we were seated early on a busy Friday night, and they did it with a smile.  The waiter was prompt and efficient.  Our appetizer was boudin.   Now, we are truly Cajun food foodies.  We throw a Cajun food fest every year in our town, and we have dined in some of the finest shacks in NOLA.  We KNOW from Cajun food.  This was not it.  First thing I said was, "how do you eat boudin without saltines?"  All jest aside, though, it wasn't right.  The boudin was in ball form, which is fine, but it didn't have enough liver.  It didn't have the good boudin funk.  It was sweet, which was weird, and not very flavorful.   I asked for hot sauce, and they brought me Tabasco ....crystal would have been better, but, whatever.  Second course for me was red beans and rice for me.  Serviceable, not great.  I like big hunks of andouille in mine.   This had none.  It was listed as an ingredient, but I couldn't find it.  Phil got a "smoked " Cesar salad with white anchovies.  The dressing reminded me of a creamy dressing you would get at the Colonnade in Atlanta....a rich southern old white guy's restaurant....creamy and flavorless.   Finally, I was very excited about the main course.  The special fish was wolf fish which is an eel-y type thing that has terribly flavorful flesh.  Unfortunately, I finally had to complain (which, believe me, I never do).  I think Lot's wife would have become human again next to this dish.  It was so salty that Phil, who LOVES salty food, said it made his mouth turn inside out.  I tried to make it work by eating the fish with the greens, but the greens were just as bad.   It was inedible.  The side of mushroom and crab Mac and cheese was ok, so I ate that.  Phil's Mack daddy duck had an excellent duck confit on top, but the pasta was really sweet.   He ate all the duck, but the pasta was just kind of gross.     So, they get up starred because of the service.  When I finally broke down and told the waiter that the food was inedible, he was quite apologetic.  I explained that we didn't want anything, but that we felt the chef should know that the fish special was terrible.  It was early in the night, and it could be fixed.  He then brought the manage over, and he apologized.  Again, I explained that it was fine, we just wanted to let the chef know.  Eventually, they actually comped my meal.  That gesture by the waiter and manage,net is enough to make me think that it's worth another shot sometime.   Anyplace that is willing to listen and cop to their mistakes is a place that I'm willing to revisit.  Hopefully next time I'll have a better experience.

Kz0sPz6Gv8a4LviF1j9wfg.text: It pains me to only give NOLA 3 stars, but I have to.  As a former resident of Baton Rouge, I expected a little more from this restaurant.  That's not to say that the food isn't good - it is good.  It's just not as Cajun/Creole as it should be.  I started with the Abita Amber (which they have on tap!).  We then ordered frog legs and the alligator to start.  Both of these were solid.  The frog legs seemed fresh, and the gator was not chewy.  The sauce that came with both of these dishes were tasty with a little zing.  I had the seafood mac and cheese, which had lobster, crab, and crawfish in it.  The flavor of this dish was great, and the cheese bits that got darkened under the broiler were to die for.  Please note, though, that the locals down in NOLA don't eat lobster...  I'd love to see an etouffee added to the menu.

Im6DeeadhcAkBs1gGVff6w.text: Went to this place a while ago when it first opened.  It's a good attempt at New Orleans dishes, but missed the mark a bit. Frequenting New Orleans on a regular basis, I know what good, southern creole food is about. I ended up sitting next to a guy at the bar who was from New Orleans and he agreed.  Did have the beignet dessert and it was a very good attempt. Nothing beats cafe du monde, but this was a pretty decent dessert.

LLGzOhUHWv7AVdTYnWcP3Q.text: With my office in the PPG complex, I really love this little market square at downtown Pittsburgh. DC has our parks, but I wish we had something like this where we can sit. It feels quite European. Anyway, we wandered around looking for a lunch spot and found this place. The lunch price looked pretty reasonable so we decided to just go with it.   Both my coworker and I decided to get the half sandwich with fries and a soup. I had a French onion soup and the pulled pork sandwich. Sometimes with these lunch deals the sandwiches are so small, but not in this case. It was a good portioned half sandwich, plus a full side of fries. Oh god their fries are so good, like the Cajun fries at Five Guys since it's covered in spices. My French onion soup I didn't like much though. All the cheese kind of gooped up together in the bowl and it was hard to eat. I hate having to bite down on stringy melty cheese like I'm eating noodles. My coworker had the gumbo and the turkey cuban and he said it was really good, and filling.   Being a New Orleans food, the food wasn't very spicy. But our waiter told us that they don't do it as spicy as True Cajun food, because I guess most of their customers aren't used to that amount of spice.   Great lunch spot with their lunch deal. I was definitely way too full after this lunch. I just can't resist them fries.

7A2XP_ixA5SAq_aSkJm_Vw.text: Great food and cool decor, but terrible service. Servers and bar staff were rude and inattentive, took an incredibly long time to get anything

PLbOJ7_RDOtw0-1rKPl4QQ.text: Nice place. In the heart of downtown. I can say that it is a nice local bar :) with a great food. My friend got an alligator, for me it was a little bit fattie but it tasted good. I got a salad with a catfish which was very good. Large variety of beers and full bar. Highly recommend for tourists like us :)

8dnKmNmnLyILvrSxgDAq8w.text: Great location and friendly people  But the menu and drink list needs work. Was out of a lot of things and to called this creole/Cajun food is just wrong

1f798k0mkT5hqALqcu15XQ.text: Service was excellent!  Food was really good. I will have to go back and try the cauliflower soup. I had a Pittsburgh salad for the first time too, wow, Pittsburgh puts fries on every thing. It was quite yummy. The catfish was delicious!

D4MyhVnVfmXVIeKFuA6pRg.text: The appetizer (gator bites) was great and our drinks were good. The main dishes were a bit disappointing, since they weren't spicy enough. We thought NOLA was New Orleans cuisine and didn't realize it was a very tame version of everything they have listed on the menu. The jambalaya wasn't very flavorful and the "blackened" catfish didn't have enough blackened seasoning and was actually charred/burned on the edges, so only the center was edible. The voodoo fries were good, but also didn't have enough cajun seasoning on them.  The wait staff and manager were wonderful. The manager sent out a dessert to make up for it and explained that everything is made to order, so next time we'll ask them to make it spicier like real New Orleans food.  If you go there expecting real New Orleans food, I recommend you ask them to make whatever you order spicier.

wVwScuZ8lVbN6gJj56UftQ.text: Fantastic food and service. 5 star dining at its finest? Exclusive, authentic, gourmet cajun dishes combined with affordable prices makes NOLA a go-to get you southern fix. I've been here at least a dozen times and they have yet to disappoint.  A must-have every time we come is the fries alligator. Its surely the only place that I know of in the city the offers it, and every time is just like the first time. Today we stopped in for happy hour and we're delighted to find a handful of appetizer items for $4, small sides for $1 and half off flatbreads. Get the Peato Crawfish flatbread if you can. They also had house wines for $5 and beer and cocktail specials.  NOLA is a fun experience no matter what the occasion. Stop wasting time and get here now to see for yourself!

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

hsWrGEyKwlKaKSFj8eOkrQ.text: I've experienced much of what NOLA has to offer - happy hour, food, and the live performances. All of the above is excellent. Happy hour: they have great gourmet plates that are discounted. The drink pictured here is a daiquiri which was, to my surprise, not frozen. It was definitely worth buying! For food, I tried the soup or salad, voodoo fries, and sandwich pairing. WOW. The voodoo fries blew me away, the alligator po boy was exotic and delicious, and the gumbo ya-ya was incredible. For such a cheap price, it was a lot of high quality food. The wait staff is incredibly attentive too. For the live performances, NOLA lights up market square. Inside, the music can admittedly be a bit loud for conversation. However, the overall New Orleans vibe of the restaurant outweighs any cons. I've been to NOLA now four times, and I will definitely be back again!

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

HufjsEzvYMJ2_TCnjRmq-A.text: This is a restaurant in downtown Pittsburgh with a New Orleans twist. During the afternoon it is a little more casual than if you would go at night. They also have love music on certain dates at night. We originally sat outside but then it started raining. Our waitress was great about finding us a seat inside and making sure we were taken care of. I ordered a cocktail which unfortunately was watered down from all the ice they put it in. If a drink is going to cost $9-$10 I would love to be able to truly taste the liquor in it.   I ordered the shrimp Poboy with voodoo fries (which are fries that are seasoned). Honestly, the sand which was average - there wasn't anything that made me go "wow!" Or that it stood out. It still was good though! The inside of the restaurant is dimly lit which would be nice for a couple that want a date night together.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

mkdxjG5CW7YCJ51WQzO7RQ.text: I came here on the day after my birthday because I am on the mailing list for this restaurant group. And as part of that you actually get a $25 certificate to use at any of the restaurants that they have. I mean, how good is that? I have been on the list for a few years now and have never used this perk. Am I an idiot or what? Anyways this year I thought, well, lets start 34 off a little different and use a coupon. We took an Uber down to Market Square. I suggest everyone who is trying to go here to just get an Uber or Lyft and not worry about parking. There is nothing worse than trying to find a parking spot when you know your reservation is soon. Yeah, they have valet and parking garages, but why spend the money and have to drive yourself home (aka no drinking) if you can just request an Uber. Seems like a no brainer to me.   Sadly I did not indulge in a drink, but after the two weeks of celebrating my birthday, it wasn't that big of deal. The table was ready right when we got there and the service was top notch like usual. Our hostess was really nice and even indulged us a bit when we considered sitting outside instead of inside. We opted to sit inside, as a side not, I am not a big fan of sitting outside usually, especially in the dark, so, we sat inside near the kitchen where we usually head to anyways. Another sad part of Sunday was that there wasn't any live music. I would have liked to hear some fine tunes while I ate.   Starters: Oysters: A foursome or dozen; wood roasted bbq or raw half shell. I of course ordered this and of course ate it all myself. Yeah, my partner is not really into the whole raw oyster thing and I absolutely love them. I will eat them each and every day if I could. I will say that they had a little bit of a different take on the cocktail sauce which I do not know how I really feel about. And they then had some sort of red pepper jam cocktail sauce that I liked, but it wasn't what I was used to. While good, I think that they were a little bit small in size for the price. I may not get them again, but that night I was happy I did.   Salad: Cajun Cobb Salad: Romaine, Tasso Ham, Edamame, Cucumber, Radish, Point Reyes Blue Cheese, Hard Boiled Egg, Tomatoes, House Made White Balsamic Vinaigrette. I wanted a salad but not a large one and the server suggested that I just get a side salad of any of the salads that they had on the menu. While smaller it was also just $3 less than the original price for the usual portion. If I knew that I would have just gotten the regular sized salad and brought some home with the dressing on the side. The cobb was good. Nothing out of the ordinary or outstanding. A solid salad for sure.   Dinner: Seafood Jambalaya: Cajun Rice, Chicken, Wild Caught Shrimp, Sea Scallops, Andouille Sausage. So the server asked if I liked spicy food. My answer was, sometimes. So he suggested that instead of the cajun rice I get the white rice. He said that the cajun rice had a lot of the spice in it and if I was not in the mood for a 6 on a scale of 1-10 then maybe to skip it. I took his advice and I think that next time I might ask for a mixture of the white and cajun rice. The dish was good but it lacked something, maybe the spice? It just needed a bit more to make it a real mouthwatering moment. The dish also came out so hot, its in a skillet, that it took a good bit of time to cool down. The shrimp was plump and juicy and the sea scallops were amazing. I was not the biggest fan of the shredded chicken, it tasted a little dry to me. It was a solid dish but I would hesitate to get it again.   12oz New York Strip Steak. Loaded Mashed Potatoes, Sauteed Leeks, Wild Mushrooms, Demi-Glace. This really stole the show. I do not know how a steak could taste this good but boy, did it. I had more than a few bites of this steak and would have been ok if I too ordered it. My partner got the mashed potatoes but then substituted the leeks and mushrooms for peas and edamame. The mashed potatoes were amazing. They were just so good. And I cannot tell you enough good things about how well the steak was done and how juicy it was. YUM.  We took leftovers home for both of the dishes and ate for another day. It was a great time and it was even better with that $25 dollar off discount. AND!!! Nola is part of the Yelp Cash Back, so I was super surprised to see money in my account on Yelp! I totally forgot about that and it was a nice surprise. So come here with family and friends, sign up for their newsletter, and link the card you are going to use so you get cash back! Its really a great deal for a great place to eat!

dKXg5EQP1mFgVJVscwai3A.text: I had been looking forward to this place for a loooong time. I will say, the quality of the alligator, fried green tomatoes, and Louisiana pasta was to die for. However, I would advise against their $30 namesake jambalaya as it not only could fit in a coffee cup, but it also tastes like zatarains out of a box. We came on a Friday night with a live band and the noise was so deafening that my ears hurt. I'm not the type of person to write average reviews; I usually only ever heap praise or damnation where it is warranted. If you come here starving for a filling meal, you may be disappointed. But if you are already out for a night on the town and you want some 5 star munchies then by all means, this is the place.

yCU0t8CL5SCQD86v__0n4A.text: Nola on the square has authentic New Orleans dishes. I love this restaurant, not sure why I don't dine here more often? The menu is reasonably priced and the service is pretty good. I love that they have outdoor seating. The restaurant looks tiny from the outside, but it is surprisingly big inside. I enjoy the jazz style music they play, really makes you feel like you're eating somewhere in the French quarter. I recommend the voodoo pasta. It's really good with the perfect amount of spice, full of vegetables and I suggest adding shrimp. The shrimp are jumbo and grilled to perfection.  I am looking forward to going back sometime soon!

rPHqIgWHxzRdyaKCHBZl-g.text: I love the city of New Orleans and this place refuses to do it just a little bit of justice. The music and art are spot on. That is where it ends. The food and drink interpretations are pitiful and the service is severely lacking.

TFFYHpXjwuntVZDEm1b0Gg.text: The service was wonderful, not too busy on a Wednesday afternoon around 2pm was seated right away. Out door seating available which was very nice. I had the steak salad and it was cooked to perfection and tasty. Pricing was reasonable 13.00 for a salad isn't bad with the lovely ambience. Would recommend with spot to anyone looking to have lunch with a friend or by yourself:)

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

jRV-1pp59C4bB3aFrq4V-A.text: Parking: there's a garage right across the square that's $5 in the evenings   Happy Hour: 5-7 Includes half priced flatbreads, $1 red beans and rice, $1 gumbo ya-ya, $4 bites and drinks on the insert  Tip: sign up foe the birthday rewards for Big Y group. You get a $30 entree voucher to choose from at their family of restaurants.  I've been here for happy hour and think it's delicious! Good food, decent portions and a fair price. I went once for dinner and honestly thought that the portions were small for the high price. The meals were alright. I didn't leave feeling wowed. I was glad that the meals were covered by the birthday coupon. I highly recommend going for happy hour!

TsjUWroiHxFVtme7kykW0w.text: Second stop here in a second city, have dined here in Downtown Dallas as well. To its name obviously bring New Orleans flair, but traditional Pennsylvania incorporated as well - with delicious pirogies. Not a veggie eaters paradise, but the pirogies were stuffed with creamy mashed potatoes, really a hit - and the NOLA salad was fresh, with crisp produce. Service was pretty good, not over the top, not any complaints. Right inside the market square, still easy to get to PNC Park afterwards.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

nSE5tG6oVYdMBQSPsNGWcQ.text: This is a definite go to place for us. We love having them as a neighbor downtown . The convenience , atmosphere and service along with their amazing lunch specials have us hooked. Fairly priced food and drinks will keep us coming back for as long as we can .

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

W9kl9_FSSA8WhUCH2wIMrQ.text: We had such a nice time here! Really good food, the outside area was really great for people watching and our server Ian was awesome! Would definitely recommend!

zlyzMxEOoiy7rd-r8SAsiA.text: The evening hadn't started well, because I had just walked out of the restaurant next door due to very poor service even before the appetizer. However, Logan at Nola made everything all better with his attentive and sincere service!  Foodwise, I could give the chef a few tips on fried green tomatoes. Like many other restaurants, the batter was a bit heavy (at home I dip the tomatoes in milk and corn meal just to add a little crunch without overwhelming the tomato).  And cheddar cheese topping?  How about pimento cheese or remoulade sauce to stay in that Creole genre?  In contrast, the roast chicken and dumplings were best in class!  Off the BBQ tasty roast chicken, light dumplings, and carrots, mushrooms and peas in a light tarragon sauce!  Heavenly!  My only regret is that I'm traveling and couldn't take the leftovers home for lunch tomorrow.  So thank you, Logan, for restoring my faith in Pittsburgh waitstaff, and thank you, Nola Chef, for the sublime roast chicken!  I'll do a free consult on the fried green tomatoes if you like....

f8RUCx9wJFVoNbBw6IMHhw.text: The minute we walked into Nola there was a band playing and the place was filled with grear music. I knew I would like my experience. I got the stuffed peppers which was good, peppers were a little too hard, not as much flavor in the red sauce. But everything else was great as far as the experience and i would come back.

ms-vUhwBuesT_jRB6cFVuQ.text: I've been here a couple times and both I left with the exact same experience - Decent but not particularly memorable! They do have multiple veggie/vegan options - Ask for their veggie/vegan menu! The names of their dishes are interesting - Voodoo pasta, for instance, but the dish itself was plain old spaghetti in red sauce and veggies! It wasn't bad, just that for $18, I was expecting something I couldn't whip up in my own kitchen relatively easily. The cauliflower soup was nice and comforting but again, nothing spectacular. Same with the friend tomatoes, stuffed mushrooms and my two cocktails. Service too is just about okay! I waited too long for my drinks and my check.. when the restaurant wasn't even full! That it isn't full on a Friday evening is telling... All in all, I had an ok meal, not bad.. but just nothing I'd want to go back again for.

W-hPsHPVRQMhpxfM4oOFFA.text: Great service and place! Some people might like more flavor but I think it was a great sampler of Cajun food! Had the shrimp and grits and blackened catfish--the taste of the spiced honey and the catfish was very good.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

oBKNHR5NMg2BAW3xvPYhZw.text: Fantastic dinner. Shrimp and Grits were to die for.  Fried Alligator app was fantastic too.  We also had the Seafood pasta and Jambalaya which were both excellent.  Waiter was very attentive and we even had the chef stop by and chat with us.  They had a great live band which topped things off.

4A2ZTTlf7UPJnoR1oKTEiA.text: The place was good. We liked the environment. There was live music which we really loved. We had jambalaya with fried alligators. Unfortunately the jambalaya was too mushy. I didn't like it. I never had fried alligator before so I was looking forward to it. But it was very rubbery and salty. The fries and pierogis were excellent.

_7MwIRo9K40x4gJstmiFfg.text: I would have to agree with some of the other reviews about NOLA. I experienced much of what was reflected in other reviews. My 4 star rating comes mostly from the overpriced food, and generic desire to provide customer service to us as I will explain.  A group of us (6) made reservations for 8:45pm on a Saturday night.  We arrived early and had a drink at the bar after we checked in with the hostess. 8:45pm came and went and at around 9:05 we began to wonder why we haven't been seated yet. Finally around 9:30 we finally sat down. A whole 45 minutes past our reservation time, I find this unacceptable because there where numerous open tables on the other side of the restaurant. Also the management and staff constantly asked us if we were doing good and having fun etc. I find this approach to be like walking into a department store and someone is breathing down your neck. When I made the correlation that their approach was generic was when the waitress spilled my wife's glass of wine on the table. Rather than simply asking "what kind of wine she had," and replacing it with a full glass. She actually asked how much was left in the glass and brought her another glass that was approximately a half serving of wine. Slightly tacky in my opinion. It really seemed as if they could have used more waitstaff for the dinning room.  The food was pretty good but I seriously believe that it was a little bit on the high $ side. I also thought that their menu was lacking some other staple Cajun dishes such as etouffee, boudin, boiled crawfish. Although they did have frog legs on the menu which I tried, have to say they were good. And alligator. I did think that it was weird that they did have things on the menu labeled as Cajun like Salmon??? I also tried the shrimp and grits and scallops Mac Daddy. I thought that the shrimp and grits while flavorful did not have the correct consistency of True grits. I also thought that this dish represented more of a "Southern style cooking" rather than New Orleans / Cajun.  And for $26 which I knew was high in the first place. The scallops Mac daddy was definitely the Mac Daddy. Very good rich dish with perfectly cooked scallops.

hfbYXI7CfofdZnAyse-DHg.text: I want to like Nola, probably will and wish them the best.  Trying them for the first time during the arts festival was a mistake. But . . .  The service was horrible. A 7:15 reservation became an 8:00 when we were forced to hover over an outside table waiting for the group to leave. We thought the four-top was incredibly rude as they lingered over their completed and cleared meal until we realized they were still waiting for their check. They immediately produced a credit card only to wait another fifteen minutes for the waitress to return. We then got the same waitress and the same level of service. No manager inquiry and only painfully uneven service. The food--at least the things they weren't out of--was good. But I'll try again on a quieter night.

og9kAdtyj-UzdTlcJCgFWA.text: Our second visit to NOLA was a long time after our first.  We last came here when NOLA first opened.   What impressed us most the first time, the quality of the service and the food, impressed us once again.  I had jambalaya (again) and my wife had the blackened redfish.  We both loved our meals, even though we took home a lot of them.  Anton, our server was very attentive and evened offered to hold our left-overs until after the show we were attending.  We asked to be seated in the back, away from the bar and were taken to an attractively decorated room off to the side and well away from the noise of the bar.  From my seat, I even had a bit of a view into the workings of the kitchen.  We remarked that the noise level was actually lower than what we usually experience in other restaurants.   We had recommended NOLA to several friends, and the feedback we got from them wasn't positive.  Some complained about the service and  everyone complained about the noise level.  Our seating in the back would explain the difference in the noise level, but regarding the difference of opinion as to the service,  that I can't explain. All I know is that on both visits, service was superb.   We'll try not to wait so long for our next visit!

6fuM7bME2hHd1ww6SAVuoQ.text: Christa is the man! She was my bartender for the evening, she also works at Perle right next door. yelp.com/user_details_re... Any who I had the frog legs and also gumbo. I love me some gumbo and I like that Nolas is keeping with Creole tradition and has okra in their gumbo. The flavors of the gumbo were on point , smokey, and spicy with sausage, veggies and as I mentioned okra and rice. On to the frog legs. I would have preferred my frog legs battered and deep fried...but none the less they were still really tasty. Nola's is open on Sundays too, which is a bonus for me since I work Downtown on Sundays, and it's just a short 10 minute walk from Grant street. I now have a swanky place to enjoy a cocktail or two after work. The entire front of the restaurant opens up to the square which is lovely in warm weather and brings in a lot of sunshine and it's great to see the owners working the floor and checking on you that for me is some quality service.

Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Hot sauce goes great on everything.
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Peach and prickly pear puree with champagne , customer cocktail

nTgniH6oBspb-iiHjRrWjA.text: Went here with my boyfriend when we were on our way home from vacation. Saw that there were great reviews on Yelp & all those reviews were spot on!   We got sat at a high top table in the front of the restaurant, and had ordered drinks shortly after. The manager came up to us about 5 minutes later to ask if we wouldn't mind moving to their dining room because the table we were sat at was reserved. We didn't mind, especially when he offered to pay for our first round of drinks!!   We ordered the gator bites for an appetizer, which were amazing! Neither of us had had gator before, and it defied our expectations! The breading and seasoning was so delicious. For our meal, we both ordered the gumbo and a Shrimp Po Boy sandwich to share. We got the gumbo first and it was so simple, but had tons of flavor!! There was tons of okra in it, which is one of my favorite vegetables. Then came the Po Boy! Which is huge, btw. The shrimp were easily the size of tennis balls, lightly fried, with a slaw sauce and I'm pretty sure their bread is homemade. To top off that sandwich, were easily the best French fries I had ever had. My boyfriend & I are French fry junkies. We both agreed this was #1 on our top French fry list!   If you are in this area, I definitely recommend Nola, if you like New Orleans type food. I wish this restaurant was closer to where I live so I could eat here all the time!!

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Shrimp Po Boy with Voodoo fries

dANlqkXQ3nQroJXVIV66DQ.text: Went to NOLA for a mid week lunch retreat.  Ordered the red beans & rice for a starter and the blackened catfish for my main.  Both were excellent but had to add some extra spice with the bundle of hot sauces.  The fish was topped with a green tomato relish that included fresh jalapenos, onion, and corn!!!

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

1PiPL4pBJ9bacLUJB8Dm1w.text: I've been to Nola's a few times before and have always had good experiences. The fully stocked bar always has a "relevant to the season" selection of Craft Brews and the staff is courteous, knowledgeable and professional. They offer a New Orleans Nouveau Creole menu with live jazz on select evenings. The outdoor seating with a view of the bustling Market Square presents a wonderful atmosphere (if you're lucky to get a seat) on a hot summer day while the interior provides a feeling of being in a tavern on Bourbon Street (I know, I've been there too).  A couple of days ago during my lunch break I had a hankering for something spicy so I headed over to Nola's and ordered up a serving of the jambalaya. It took only about ten minutes for a hot cast-iron dish to be placed in front of me filled with shrimp, scallops, chicken, andouille, veggies and of course beans and "dirty" rice. The spices blended together to make the meal flavorful without being too spicy... a delicate line to tow.  It was truly delicious; I know I'll be back again. Perhaps one day I'll muster up the courage to try the Frog Legs or the maybe the "Crispy Fried Alligator".

HGACMcN9TN-ap72T5SmZng.text: Yay for new restaurants!  Yay for fun new restuarants!  And a final yay for a good exerpeince at a fun, new restaurant!  I always love walking into a restaurant which looks super duper tiny from the front and then surprises you by being large on the inside.  The colorful pictures and art make it a bright and fun atmosphere.  Just like you'd expect from a 24/7 Mardi Gras party, minus maybe the flashing!  First time's a charm with this place!  Service was fantastic!  The server came up and explained everything to us in terms of drinks, apps and main courses.  Since it was for lunch I went on the light side with the Crawfish and Sherry soup and the Nola salad.    The soup was delicious with just the right amount of kick for me.  Sometimes if things are too spicey for me I become a watery mess, and not in the emotional way!  I think the soup was just creamy amazingness!    The salad was also very fresh with some great toppings such as candied pecans and my personal fav, little mini potato chips.  Of course the later mentioned doesn't end up making a salad healthy, but whatever, it was tasty!  For a final send off we ordered the fried artichoke's as our "dessert."  They were incredible!  Nice, crispy and huge with a spicy mayo type sauce.  I'm all about the sauces, so it was just the right touch.  I really can't wait to try out this place for dinner and/or a happy hour!  I will definitely be back.  I hope they have some idea's for events, because I think the place will be a great host for special parties.  Great addition to Market Square!!

f8p_nQ4OFSKebWMFJzXd1Q.text: First of all, I'm from New Orleans so I have high standards when it comes to N'Awlins food.  Overall this place was pretty good when it comes to places outside of New Orleans.    The gumbo and crab etouffee were made from a nice roux and were properly flavored which I was impressed by.  I would've liked a bit more meat in it and some French bread on the side though (that is the only proper way to eat gumbo!).  When I asked for some bread I was informed there were 2 choices which were a "complimentary baguette" or cornbread for a charge.  I was wondering why we weren't offered this complimentary bread in the first place and by the time we got it we were almost finished our gumbos.  And the bread was cold and not actually French bread.  I long for that flaky airy bread that is crispy on the outside and soft on the inside that is so ubiquitous in New Orleans.   We also had the fried gator appetizer which was tasty though could have used a bit more of a kick to it to spice it up a bit more.   I tasted a friend's jambalaya and another friend's cheesy scallop pasta and both were really good (though the scallop dish was not a typical New Orleans dish).    I had asked about the oyster appetizers which were market price but they were very expensive ($28 for a dozen or $12 for 4, no half dozen options allowed).  I asked the waitress if they were from the gulf, and she disdainfully replied that actually Gulf oysters are small and tasteless so they get theirs from Rhode Island.  Umm seriously? You are trying to celebrate the food of N'Awlins and you just dissed our oysters?  Gulf oysters are delicious and often quite large.  I grew up on them so I was offended by her comments.  And the oysters they served that my friend got were actually super tiny -- tinier than anything I ever get in New Orleans.  And they were not served with the proper accoutrements (Tabasco, horseradish, etc.).    It would have been nice if the PoBoys or Muffaletta sandwhiches could be ordered for dinner but they are only on the lunch menu.  We also had the bread pudding which was very good, and the red velvet ice cream was an unusual touch.    There was a small jazz band playing in the bar area which was a nice touch, especially for a weeknight.  I'd go back and I think they did a decent job for being so far from New Orleans.  But I think there are some basic things they could work on that would make this place even better and more authentic.

oQWP6rPZqTkmLOgFRHZ9Tg.text: I grew up in Louisiana so I was excited to come across a New Orleans themed restaurant. The server even said the restaurant was approved by the City of New Orleans, so I was quite anxious to try out the different dishes that I've been missing. First of all, I have to say that the ambiance is very inviting. When my boyfriend and I went, they had a live jazz band performing.  While the service was excellent, the food itself was subpar. First, we had the fried alligator. It was ok, but I think they should consider serving blackened alligator instead, because alligator can be quite fatty and frying it makes it even oiler. The frog legs were actually great. Super flavorful sauce. My only complaint with that dish is that I wish they gave us some bread to mop up more of the sauce because there wasn't much meat to the frog legs (of course) and there was a lot of yummy sauce left. We got two seafood jambalayas. Strangely, one of the dishes was lukewarm, while the other one was piping hot. The jambalaya tasted ok, but didn't resemble the jambalaya I grew up with. I think the rice was a bit too mushy and there wasn't any spice to it. We also ordered the crawfish tapenade flatbread. This dish was the worst as the flatbread was soft and mushy, and the crawfish and olives didn't go well together. We had to use utensils for this dish because it fell apart in our hands (as flatbread should not). For dessert, I had to try the beignets. The were the worst beignets I've ever had. I think what went wrong is that they fried the dough and then completely caked the beignets in the powdered sugar. If you let that sit around, then the powdered sugar gets mushy and crusted on, instead of lightly sitting on top of the fried dough. If I could recommend a change, I'd say they should try dusting the powdered sugar on, instead of tossing the fried dough in a bowl of powdered sugar. I have to say though that the housemade sorbets that were oddly paired with the beignets were excellent. Last suggestion to the restaurant is that they should hire a chef from New Orleans. I think that would help a lot.   Sorry this post is a bit of a rant about what they should change. I don't want to be too down on the place, but I came in with high expectations, and ended up paying a good amount of money for food that doesn't do New Orleans justice. Next time, I'll just save the money towards a plane ticket to NOLA.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Fried alligator
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Seafood jambalaya
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Really flavorful frog legs

3ptTGVPcyEvvNPrTDD6-Mw.text: I'm used to the real thing in NOLA and Baton Rouge, but this is very reminiscent of them.

wSLvsLu-ku3Hjx4n11W0qA.text: We ate there on a Tuesday night,  and received excellent service.  I had the steak and salad.  The steak was very good for the price.  ($25) overall nice dinning ambiance.

TKRje1JLo-gkcnqCc5hp9g.text: I stopped by here this past Friday evening with my fiance for dinner.  We had made reservations on open table and arrived a few minutes before our time.  The bar and outside seating was absolutely packed and I thought that this was going to be a problem but we were taken into the dining room which was fairly empty at this point (5:30) and thankfully quiet.  The decor of NOLA is pretty cool as it incorporates many pictures and items that make you think of New Orleans like a picture of Cafe Du Monde, Mardi Gras related art and a picture of a jazz band walking down the street,  My fiance and I decided to start off our evening with the fried green tomatoes.  Whenever they came out I was surprised at the size of the tomatoes as they were not even close to be being thinly sliced like I had imagined.  They were breaded in abita batter and sat on top of a base of creole ranch mustard while being smothered on top with cheddar cheese.  The fried green tomatoes ended up tasting good and I thought the thickness of the tomatoes actually gave a good tomato/batter ratio and brought in enough acidity from the tomato that it paired nicely with the savory cheese.  For my entree I decided to go with the Bourbon Street Pasta.  It was a gemelli pasta that had 8 or so fried oysters around the outside and then tasso ham, peas and piave cheese mixed with the pasta and was topped by a single cooked egg yolk.  Breaking the egg yolk into the pasta gave the pasta a little extra creaminess which I enjoyed.  Overall it was a good dish with the salty fried oysters being my favorite part of it.  The bottom line for me is that I will definitely had back to NOLA again in the future.  I am actually surprised that I hadn't written a review of this before as I have been to NOLA many times and have always been satisfied with the service and food that I received.

AOGxuawCvVgYctcSGY_tSw.text: I came here for lunch during the week and we were able to get a table walking in with no reservation. I didn't realize how deep and far back the restaurant went, but there were a lot of tables in the back.   I am from Houston and I have pretty close access to real cajun food... that being said, I ordered a shrimp po boy and was sad to see that it wasn't quite the same. It was so close, but yet so far. Instead of putting just mayo, lettuce, and tomato, they used coleslaw which changed the entire taste of the poboy sandwich! I was not excited about this!  The service was fine, just disappointed as it was definitely not authentic cajun food... so beware if that's what you're expecting!

n-2sb09gdXLpupyyKohZvg.text: Whether or not NOLA is serving up bona fide Cajun/Creole cuisine is a non-issue to me. Whatever it is they're dishing out has successfully channeled the spirit of the late Justin Wilson, a colorful bard of a television chef who introduced me to Louisiana cookery when I was but a boy... youtube.com/watch?v=eK4u... Before taking in a show at Heinz Hall, I decided on NOLA for my pre-event meal and was favorably taken aback by each and every dish I consumed. I was welcomed by a sociable staff and was seated promptly without a reservation. The patrons were a diverse bunch that ranged from middle-aged couples to teenaged skateboard anarchists, and the ambience was closer to time-honored than cutting edge; if a long-defunct, dimly-lit, and bygone Bourbon Street tavern was plucked from the timestream and into modern, urban Pittsburgh, you'd have an approximate rendition of NOLA. Jazz, conversation, and laughter nudged the air jovially, gently... Finding it difficult to choose an entree, I was tempted by a threesome of appetizers, and in a fit of lunacy and foodlust, I ordered all of them. The Crispy Fried Alligator comes to your plate in a bronzed mound of protein morsels artfully littered with chives and accompanied by a smear of spiced aioli. The dislimbed swamp dragon recalled lobster, scallops, catfish, and of course chicken with its meaty, juicy flavor and mouthfeel that was punctuated by the piquant orange cream. Barbequed Oysters on the half shell came next, and the slithering, slimy, slightly saliferous creatures were eviscerated swiftly by me, tart sauce, buttery cheese and all. The rocky chassis of each mollusk was left to creak in the dusk winds. House Cured Pork Belly completed the trilogy. Candied and fabulously fatty, the protein portion of the dish was embrocated with a root beer-mustard glaze that wedded saccharine to brackish in eternal, Mephistophelian symbiosis. Fall squash puree, sliced Granny Smith apples, and cornbread arrived with the sour, the citrus, the juice, the crunch, and the grains in tow. Jalapenos were arrested on the spot for obnoxious loitering. How Mardi Gras. Looking over the dessert menu, I was once again came up against a dilemma, so I crazily doubled-up, tackling both the Red Velvet Ice Cream and the Bayou Chocolate Cake. Housemade, the scarlet ice cream had a sass that recalled cheesecake and was severely creamy, glacial, bewitching even... youtube.com/watch?v=VoQg... The cake was nothing less than a devil... youtube.com/watch?v=niCJ... A brooding, threefold chocolate cake, the sinister slab was desecrated by cocoa nibs, Guinness caramel, and Chicory Pudding, threatening to make me... youtube.com/watch?v=d9er... The occult danced with the sweet and briny around a mountain cemetery bonfire as crispy globes of decadent doom floated high above the muddy, funereal soil... youtube.com/watch?v=GJvT... Exorcised with a glass of water, I thanked my hospitable waitress for her kindness and adept service, and left feeling renewed... youtube.com/watch?v=MzQK... A meeting with comedic firebrand Lewis Black awaited me. I may never make the pilgrimage to New Orleans, but I'll always have NOLA in my city, my heart, my stomach, and on my mind... youtube.com/watch?v=gChl...

a6xDr5SY0xcWlgPOXqnf6Q.text: We came here for a quick drink and a snack. The place seemed promising. We love creole food so we were excited. That excitement quickly turned into disappointment.    First off, the service is horrible. The waiters and waitresses seems disinterested. And one of our plates were dirty! We tried to signal for a waiter but no one came by so we had to go up to the manager for a new plate. The food was no better than the service. We ordered the sausage and crawfish flat bread. The whole thing lacked flavor and was way too oily for my taste. I will definitely not go back there.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Sausage and Crawfish Flatbread

rYNf12DxUsQ_z9ySIb8SCQ.text: My sweet friend took me here one night after hanging out, and I was a little nervous. I don't like to let people pay for me, especially if it's not "cheap" food. I was also worried there would be nothing vegetarian. Well, one fear was confirmed. There really is next to nothing vegetarian here.   I ended up ordering the single item that was. I think it was a flatbread with pesto and tomato. We sat outside listening to the (very loud but good) music and sipping on one of the most amazing fruit-type beers I've ever had. This was in July, so I honestly forget the name of it. I won't forget the taste, though!   The flatbread came out, and I was surprised by the generous size. It was incredibly flavorful and well made. I typically loathe little tomatoes on top of food, but these were perfectly ripe and delicious. I'm getting hungry remembering this meal.   Oh, did I mention my meal was $9, while hers was $27? Vegetarians are cheap dates.

nWTCMew6btbn8Ipxus4ERg.text: The Gumbo YaYa and Red Beans & Rice were excellent. The jazz band was very good (cohesive). I can't wait to come back and try the entrees.

HjV3_Sb8sioYaJqYLkAsXw.text: I let sister Stenquist pick this one out. I gave up perusing Yelp from my Hotel bed and we just stumbled into market square hoping something would be open before 11am on a Saturday. Oddly not a lot opens before 11am in Pittsburgh. And alcohol before 11 and after 9pm seems to be frowned upon. And makes me frown.  But as we sipped our mutual coffees, she decided on this place since it didn't exist when she used to live out here. We were seated super fast and the service was super. Fantastic waitress and not an ounce of complaint. I was just really bummed with how bland and flavorless everything tasted.   We split an order of fried green tomatoes. Which, are huge and have a ton of additional decoration on top that doesn't seem necessary. Sprinkled cheese with greens is weird. Not to mention the batter just didn't seem right. I just like simple, normal sized battered green tomatoes. Frown. But that wasn't where I was even terribly disappointed. The sandwich and soup or salad combos both failed. At least, my sister's sandwich was better. She got a creole pulled pork and I stuck with a creole cordon bleu. It was charred chicken with bacon and swiss cheese. So freaking dry I could scrub the dishes with the chicken. There wasn't any sauce on the pieces of bread either that seemed to have come fresh out of a cooler. Her rice and beans tasted obviously canned. Both of our sides of fries tasted like mesquite wood chips. I ate about 2 or 3 of them and gave up. The best thing I had in all pure honesty was the side salad. Because I would find it incredibly hard to eff up a wedge of iceberg lettuce. I hate to give this a bad review because people seem to enjoy it. But I really like to eat and I ate about only half my food.

Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

U29yUzrLUxgD2aROrS_IHw.text: We ordered red beans & rice and Gumbo soup. I don't think they gave us gumbo soup because it looked like beef tips with lots of gravy which was so salty. The red beans and rice was not tasteful either. We should've taken a picture of the 2 most disgusting meals that are an insult to the state of LA. Please just stop making food and just shut down. We have also eaten there at least 2 more times within 2 years and it's just terrible and seem to have gotten worst.

1IcCrnRPddVR2_c0_6m3Lw.text: We went for happy hour on a friday evening which runs from 5 until 7. We wanted to sit outside as it was a nice day and were seated quickly. After that our service was not very good. Our server had 4 tables outside and im not sure how many inside she had but she wasn't very helpful, and didn't check in on us very often. We weren't initially given the happy hour menu but a manager brought one to us when we asked. We ordered 4 food items on their happy hour. The brussel sprouts, and catfish fingers were my favorite. I would definitely go back for the catfish. I did not enjoy the pulled pork sliders or mac n cheese as much. The mac n cheese was tasty, but quite salty and it looked like the sauce had split as it was a bit oily. All the food was nice and hot. All in all, it was a pretty good experience. I would like to go back to try some cocktails and listen to some live music!

qWKUzEyx145CCMOgIzn9tQ.text: Taste nothing like food in New Orleans. Maybe they can fool people in the area because they are so far from N'Awlins. My appetizer came out waay after my entree. However, the waiters especially the host guy were VERY friendly. Great customer service here, poor food

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Fried Green tomatoes

_TDB0pXfdReHHBrwpZREvQ.text: If you can only eat one dish and have one drink from their menu... get the fried alligator and the hurricane...NOTHING on this menu matches up to them! I have tried several other dishes on the menu including the flatbreads, seafood jambalaya, shrimp and grits etc...these are all good... but these guys sure know how to make some mean Fried Gators!! This dish is sooo delicious that if you go in for a late dinner (ie after 8:30 pm) its ALWAYS sold out!...i have only gotten to eat it twice of the 8 times I have tried ordering it...Sigh!  The restaurant is conveniently located at market square in downtown and is bubbling with life....especially during the weekends ...it is hard to find a seat even at the bar. They usually have live music on the weekends which adds to the ambiance...  This restaurant is like a piece of New Orleans in the heart of Pittsburgh...Worth a try!!

r3Utz4tGDtVXfXc-FdlfNQ.text: Went here on accident, but it was a pleasant accident! My grandmother was in the mood for pizza and we had planned on going to the italian restaurant next door, but we got mixed up and got a table and drinks here. When we realized, the menu looked so good we just stayed put!   We ordered a flatbread pizza and fried green tomato appetizers. Both were really delicious! Nice combination of interesting flavors, cooked well, not overpriced. My only problem with this place were the fruit flies. There were several flying around and one ended up in my water. The restaurant had an open patio which I think contributed to the bugs.

fViJi_tuULS-5X8yqggYNQ.text: Came here for happy hour with a friend.  Our table was sticky. My wine glass kept sticking to it.   Ordered the Margherita pizza as an appetizer and was surprised to see pesto and onions on it. Should have read the menu more closely.    The fried green tomatoes were good! Would order them again.   They have exotic items like frog legs and alligator if you are into that type of thing.   Just ok in my opinion.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Margherita flatbread pizza
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Fried Green Tomatoes

PiE8zl8XqpGoXd_t_g8GKg.text: We found this location prior to a Pirate's game for dinner. There were 4 of us and we didn't have reservations.  However, we were seated quickly.   Our waitress did a good job.  We ordered some beers but unfortunately they were out of two of the local beers on the list.  But that happens with craft beer. We also had sangria but very sweet. I had a seafood jambolaya and the others had a crab cake or seafood dinner.  Food was good.  The interior was nicely done, but it got pretty loud as we were leaving. I am glad I went, but with the number of places in Pitt... it will probably not be on my return list.   If you really like Cajun... give it a try

IGbeciKnKlzrTof8qcxqTg.text: I stopped here for an early lunch since I had business to attend to downtown. The place was fairly empty when I arrived and since the day was nice I had outdoor seating. They have nice artwork on the walls.  I wasn't overly hungry and thought a salad would be best. I ordered the "Pittsburgh" salad with chicken topping and ranch dressing. The salad was a decent size and good. Nothing to write home about but at least it was all that I needed.  Little did I realize that within 30 minutes of my arrival this place was packed with people. I had an attentive waitress who brought my food and drink over quickly but then seemed to disappear as I was looking for her to pay my check. I got off my high top chair hoping someone would see me so I could get the check. It paid off after a few minutes. Another waiter came back and explained that my waitress had been transferred to the bar area so he went and got it for me. I was able to pay and then leave.  Nola on the Square sits next to Sienna Mercado in Market Square and on the other side is Nicholas coffee company. Lunch prices are on par for most of your downtown sit down restaurants. It's an average restaurant if you prefer it to grab and go.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pittsburgh salad with chicken
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Nice artwork

3qmavwd7x1e3ROE386S_Lw.text: While I'd give NOLA high marks for atmosphere, the food is mediocre. I ordered the shrimp and grits and my husband had the jambalaya. Having been to New Orleans, the flavors were disappointing and inauthentic.  My shrimp and grits was smothered in a salty gravy.  The cocktails, however, were delicious. Would recommend NOLA for drinks and small bites but would save my money for a more quality entree for sure.

0dXU6uMUdUSbLiTwpgTH8w.text: Stopped by here this evening for a bite to eat before going home after work. I got the margarita flatbread and my friend got the jambalaya with a side of voodoo fries. The flatbread was good, but not your typical margarita. It had onions and pesto, which I love, I just was surprised. It was a little over cooked and charred in some spots, but overall great. My friend loved her jambalaya! I would definitely go back to try some more items.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Margarita flatbread

pVt-5n91wlXZUpyCZrjUhg.text: We stopped in for dinner before a show at the Arcade Comedy Theatre.   We sat in the bar area to catch some of the live music on Friday night. The band was great. Even the music playing beforehand was good too.   The place was pretty well packed.  We ordered drinks. The rum hurricane was very sweet and bitter at the same time. You'd have a hard time drinking more than one of them.   I ordered the cauliflower soup which was way too salty for me.   For dinner I had the shrimp and grits. The shrimp was cooked just right. Bacon was thick, smokey and delicious. The grits were yummy too. Lots of layers of flavors with the diced veggies and sauce. Best I've had.   Hubs order the Nashville hot chicken sandwich. He really liked it. He also liked the beer selection.  For dessert we shared beignets with iced cream. I thought they'd be warm and soft but were not. The flavor was still good though.   Service was good. The bartender tried to make a less sweet/tart drink for me. I give him a star for trying even though it didn't work out well.   My one real issue is that everything was sticky and I'm not sure why. Our table, the floor, the bathroom. I can't say that it looked dirty. It just felt very sticky.   I would go back for dinner and to hear the band but would skip dessert and drinks (other than beer).

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Band list
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Half my shrimp and grits, because I already dove in!

MNnWYXVoeCXQ5qetVfcmVg.text: I liked the atmosphere at Nola. we enjoyed our server as well, he said it was his first day on the job, he had been a cook previously. I had a really nice cocktail...maybe I had two of them!  We ordered fried green tomatoes as an appetizer which came with four fried green tomatoes and probably the best I've had. I ordered the stuffed peppers with andouille sausage as my main meal. I really liked the sausage, and I'm not a big sausage person. It was good and definitely more than enough food.

Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

pMYOqL6-WYu_wetOcVMYHQ.text: We stopped here on Wednesday evening for a late dinner. I have been to NOLA before, years ago. I actually used to frequent this restaurant. However I haven't been here for several years and I have to note that it has definitely changed, but I'm not sure it's for the better.  Upon arriving, although it was busy we were seated almost immediately. I was impressed with the vegetarian options on the menu, but I'm on whole30(ish) so I decided to pass because they all included rice.   Our service started our mediocre but soon failed. We waited what seemed to be an eternity for our food.. once it arrived though It was surprisingly good. I do however agree with other reviews when they say that menu items are a little overpriced for what you receive (my cauliflower soup was $6)   My friend got the catfish, which came with yummy sweet potatoes, and I got the shrimp salad. I can say the homemade dressing was quite good!   I would enjoy coming here to listen to live music, but I probably won't be back for a sit down dinner. I
