oJGSyP716Ks21RDHBzB3Ww.text: Came here for a beer and quick snack.  French onion soup was flavorful...salty, but very tasty! Will come back for it if I'm craving soup in this chilly weather.  Fried green tomatoes were excellent. First time having beer battered fried green tomatoes...usually see them crusted with bread crumbs or panko. Sauce and cheese topping were on point.  Nothing on the dinner menu caught my eye, but I would come back for sure!

x8Ho5qCnRwCnw2JQ8Sk_TQ.text: Really not good.  Shrimp and grits is really salty small overcooked shrimp soup with a square of dry tasteless grits.  Service was good as well as atmosphere.  Others in the party liked their food and some didn't.  Very inconsistent.

cCRB32YidwqeyoiyrWaTlA.text: Live music in any atmosphere adds to the ambience. Service was really fast and the the waiter was super polite, knowledgeable and helpful in helping me choose items from the menu. I had the fried alligator which was delicious but small for the price. For my main course I opted for the shrimp and grits. Mind you I hate anything with grits as an accompaniment and I was truly surprised at how good the food was. I emptied my plate needless to say. I definitely recommended this place on a Saturday night with friends. It's a very relaxed and inviting atmosphere.

MTUYf5sJtQtmnnI-3pJmag.text: I was going back through my old reviews - and I HAD to add a star back to NOLA.  Their happy hour is one of our favorites.  Half off flat breads (which are all insanely good) and $1 red beans and rice or jambalaya.  Don't quote me on this, but I think the draft beer is also $1 off.  There's usually a new flatbread depending on the season, so its nice to always have something new to try.  Since I've been more of a regular here, the food has really grown on me.

Mbb-uU77rY9vI03mJ_s3TA.text: Made an impromptu visit to this restaurant, glad I did. The coffee was nice and hot, fresh. We sat on the patio while eating our brunch. I had a simple meal with breakfast potatoes and eggs (don't remember the name of the dish), I asked for mild seasoning and they did it just right. My boyfriend had a voodoo Mary and he says it was fair. Overall good experience, would want to experience dinner here.

le1_KfJf3Kbdgis4iJAS6w.text: NOLA has been on my list for quite some time and I'm happy to report that my first experience was pretty good overall. I went with a group so I got to sample everyone else's food too!!  We started with the frog legs and fried alligator. I preferred the gator to the frog legs.  I had the shrimp and grits, which was a massive portion. It was good, not as spicy as I expected and slightly on the greasy side, but I ate around the puddles. We also had the steak frittes, seafood jambalaya, red fish and the cat fish. No complaints from the peanut gallery regarding their meals.   I'm anxious to go back and try something new!

mCojeLzOZClY_bKGriVwQQ.text: WOW. I was seriously so impressed with NOLA. My friend and I decided to go here for dinner on a Thursday night on a whim. I'd heard pretty good things about the place so I was excited to give it a try. We were seated quickly (the place is a lot bigger than it looks from the outside) and our server came right over. They were fairly busy but not packed. I was feeling somewhat confused by the menu because I am NOT familiar with Creole food at all, so I was very happy when our server asked if we've been there before and helped us a lot with the menu when we told her we hadn't.  She was extremely familiar with the menu, and even things that weren't actually on the menu but could be done by customizing a dish. She recommended the jambalaya and the scallops mac daddy, which is a scallop mac and cheese dish. My friend got the jambalaya and I got the scallops, and we opted for a flatbread pizza as an appetizer. We were so happy with our choices. Everything was absolutely excellent. And I can't stress enough how great the service was.  The manager came over and asked how our meals were and about our experience in general, which was nice of her and we told her how pleased we were.  As a disclaimer, yes it is a little pricey but in my opinion the food and the service is well worth it. And it's in a great location in Market Square. We will certainly be back!!

4XGJxU22_wlt632fYVvlqw.text: Based solely off of customer service- I live in Orlando, but my dad was having his birthday dinner at Nola's about a month ago. I called and spoke with a friendly girl and asked if I could send a drink to the birthday boys table and she was more than happy to assist me promptly. It was a busy night for them plus and unusual request so, I was pleased that she was so willing to help!

FNxsjKpGRO_zVJpjS8GT8Q.text: Stopped in late Friday night for dinner with my girlfriend. We split appetizers of fried alligator and fried green tomatoes.   The alligator was good, tender and crisp. Think popcorn chicken...errrr alligator. It was plated with a  remoulade dipping sauce.   The fried green tomato were sliced about a half inch thick, battered and fried. They were plated with sprinklings of cheddar cheese, micro greens and a creole mustard ranch sauce drizzled on top. Normally I am anti-ranch, it has a strong flavor that overpowers most things (think cool ranch doritos....bleh). This was not the case here, the dish was great! Would definitely order again.  We split an order of seafood jambalaya for our entree. They thoughtfully split our dish between two individual skillets which were lined with rice topped with a spicy red sauce, a scallop, 2 shrimp, grilled chicken, and slices of sausage. I wish the sausage was crispier/rendered out more but the seafood and chicken were all prepared great.  My girlfriend had the classic New Orleans drink, the Hurricane and I had a boring plain old Yuengling draft. Would definitely return to try some other menu items.

s7vv_rbJwOB5kost9HKvHg.text: $40 for a cup of Gumbo, Jambalaya, a Pepsi, and tip. Very, very spicy, to the point of overwhelming any flavor. Jambalaya was a bit salty and greasy, with dried out chicken, definitely not worth $23. I won't be rushing back any time soon.

A6brWeTMmYZlRfa-5YUtbw.text: William recommended the fried green tomatoes to me. They were amazing. He was a great server and ready attentive. My first time at NOLA and I will definitely be back!

bsytu8aj8o55aM9kqafB0Q.text: I have visited NOLA on two different occasions.   The first was a very casual afternoon when we had been out and about exploring downtown Pittsburgh. We sat outside (a great location for people watching in the square, by the way) and enjoyed a couple of drinks and a sampling of appetizers. Everything we had was wonderful - including the service!  Our second visit was on Easter Sunday. We had a party of 5 and were assigned to a table in the back part of the restaurant that was being overseen by William (I'll get back to him later).   First off, I will say that this restaurant has 3 unique seating areas to choose from based upon your mood. As I mentioned earlier, the outdoor seating area had a very nice cafe feel with a great view of Market Square. Then there is the bar section, where various televisions were broadcasting sports programs while jazz music played in the background. It had a very fun, New Orleans feel to it. This particular location seemed to be a pretty happening area for people in their 20s & 30s given the loud music and sporting event coverage. The place that we were seated was located in the back of the restaurant. It was quieter and had much more of an upscale feeling than the front two sections. This was perfect for us as we had just come from a theater production and were anxious to discuss the details of the play. The kitchen, which is located in this area, was open and visible to us, although we were not bothered at all by the noise level. They workers seemed to be very conscientious of keeping it that way. The food was fabulous and so was the service - which brings me back to William.   William, our waiter, was AMAZING! Not only was he extremely familiar with the menu and the available specials, but he made sure that each one of us had his individualized attention as we were ordering. Each of us had different tastes which he personally evaluated before offering suggestions of those dishes he thought matched those qualifications. We all loved the selections we had made thanks to his input. Also, many times waiters and waitresses can tend to be over attentive, in that they strive to make sure that their customers' every need is met. This, however, can become a bit complicated when you have a group involved in deep discussion. It took a lot of though and insight on his part to know what times were best for him to step in and which times were better for him to quietly remain available in the background. Somehow, William managed to juggle this task in the most efficient and least-intrusive way possible. Although he never interrupted a conversation or thought, he made sure that he took care of all of our needs including drink refills and plate clearing with almost no notice of his presence.   I would highly recommend this restaurant. Service and food are fabulous...and make sure to request William if you want superior service. Way to go, William!

O1sYUAcBbYRO9XOdI4aceA.text: One of the best places when it comes to live jazz! They have live jazz 3 times a week and it's ALWAYS good! Their wine menu is also great, the decor is lovely, and the service as well! I gave it 4 stars only because the food is not that great! It's good but I wouldn't go there specifically for the food!

0v6fXI7Mfym2UUhaOeuUkg.text: The service is great (been here 2 times), the food is tasty, and the atmosphere is appropriate for the theme. I had the jumbalaya, the NOLA salad with scallops added, blue crab etouffee, & bananas foster mousse. Everything was great. My favorite was the etouffee. The jumbalaya was baked in a iron skillet and any sauce that should have been in there when served was baked out. I like it with some sauce running around. Therefore, I picked out the meat and left most of the rice. But the shrimp and especially the scallops were awesome.

Jb2SX63YBbkmrtB1lXPC7w.text: I liked the food, but it was nothing too memorable. I do however remember being turned off by the service. I don't think I've ever had a hostess be so rude to me in my life. I'm a pretty relaxed person, and totally understand that the food service industry can be stressful....but when it's a Monday night and not crowded, the hostess rolls her eyes at you, doesn't say hello, and just grabs menus, I'm going to be a little bit upset.

XSI5vgJOEM_CHiJ3RfoWrQ.text: Went for lunch; not speedy service but not slow either; it's a nice place so don't expect rush service. I read reviews about the service but I had no problem here. In any case, I had the gumbo ya-ya and gulf lump crab cake; both were terrific! Hope I get back to Pittsburgh to try some other items...

zV3c-UNWi_Jqi619mppzwQ.text: We went in for a late Saturday lunch.  We had a reservation, not knowing if it as really necessary.  On this particular Saturday, it was not.  We were greeted right away by the host.  We were surprised when he gave us a "tour" of the restaurant showing us the rooms in the back for large groups.  We must look like party organizing people.  We are not.  We were seated near the open kitchen.    Being a huge fan of red beans and rice, we decided to share a bowl.  Their version is totally unlike any I have ever eaten.  It was incredibly thick and tomato based with a lot of ham shank.  We liked it anyway.  For my meal, I ordered the half salad/half sandwich.  I got the NOLA salad with candied pecans, red onion, tomato and sweet potato chips with yummy vinaigrette.  For my sandwich, I picked the Croque Monsieur.  It was stuffed with tender, thick carved slices of smoked ham, grilled rustic bread, my favorite Gruyere cheese with apple butter and dijon.  Even though this was 1/2 sandwich, it was more than I could eat!!  BJ got the Seafood Jambalaya.  He really liked it.  Of course, we didn't have room for dessert.   Enjoyed the atmosphere, food was great, service was passable.  We can't wait to eat here again!

lqGmkakJ9-3clvykBupxsg.text: Service 4/5 Decor 4/5 Food 2/5  Nothing we ate had much creativity. The frog legs were okay, the salad, and Jambalaya were mediocre.

k8rdoh9H3JPIRvztjgN7RA.text: Love the atmosphere at Nola's on the Square.  The food is always sooooo delicious.  a great place for a group or a couple.  In the summer they have bands that play and you can sit outside.  Great time!  Highly recommended.

E5MPH9FsXVHRoHjtSOTnGg.text: Never had a bad meal here! Fried gator app is amazing! Had several entrees- scallops Mac daddy, seafood jambalaya, and catfish all where great!

-Pc6LOaNiLiAGbCbrSPz0w.text: I don't know, it's a nice place, but I really felt that the options were kind of limited, especially for vegetarians. It's also kinda pricey and I paid about $12 for a salad that didn't leave me satisfied.

IYMuaJIGETPIacRepQAlHA.text: Working downtown, you're always looking for new and good lunch spots. It's nice to see classy joints like this popping up all over the downtown area. Especially in the newly renovated Market Square. When they first started renovating the area, I just had this "what's the point" feeling. Market Square was a haven for the homeless and unemployed. Driving property value down, and detracting your average downtown commuter.  I'm happy to say I was sorely mistaken. The face-lift Market Square has gotten has made me look at downtown Pittsburgh in a whole new light. A nice open airy atmosphere with plenty of trendy eateries all around. Sure you can't drive out all of the "riff-raff," but they certainly tried.  A co-worker and I stopped by NoLa to check it out a couple weeks ago. I thought the decor was cool, an over-the-top (in a good way) vision of Bourbon St and Mardi Gras. We both got the Chicken and Andouille Po Boy, which was tasty.  We found the homemade mustard was a bit overpowering though, as it was not evenly distributed and sort of gobbed onto the sandwich.  The service was good. In fact, it was too good. My co-worker and I were approached, no joke, six times by four different people asking how our meal was and how everything was going. This was excessive, and borderline annoying, given that we weren't even there an hour.  Overall I think this place is pretty good, and has the potential to be better. I feel like they are still trying to work out some of the kinks, and once they do, things will definitely approve.  If you love somewhat-pricey cajun food, and are downtown, this place is right up your alley.

8Byj-UxlJ-YL50F9kmucBA.text: I enjoy the city of Pittsburgh. And I enjoy trying new things.   So suffice it to say, I was happy to combine those two things this when my wife and I and two friends were hanging out in Market Square and PPG Place the Saturday of Light-Up Weekend. One of them suggested Nola, as she had eaten there once before. Since we hadn't, we went along.   I've been to New Orleans, and the first thing I noticed walking in: the place smelled a lot like that city. That was a good thing. Also a good thing: our timing. We were told that normally on a Saturday night, there would be a lengthy wait for a table, but since we had beaten the dinner rush, we only waited about ten minutes.   Once we were seated, a lovely lady named Mariah was our server. She was very knowledgeable about the menu and even when she wasn't sure about what that day's specials were, she let us know that she'd get us that information: which she did - and I was glad, as I wound up ordering the fried chicken, which was different from any I had ever had before and very good. It had a sweetness to it and a bit of a kick - much like the aioli that came with crispy fried alligator, which, along with the frog legs we ordered and the fried green tomatoes made for great appetizers (and I don't even like tomatoes).   I didn't try the flatbread, but it got rave reviews from my friends and my wife, who did. At the end of the evening, a manager came up and asked us how we liked the fried chicken, as they were experimenting with it and wanted a customer's opinion. At that point, I hadn't tried it, but my wife had and she assured him that it was very good (something I'd find out later).   For drinks, we kept it pretty simple, though my wife did enjoy the Canyon Oaks Cabernet.   We didn't wind up getting dessert, because we were very full. Too bad, because I imagine that they make a great beignet.   All in all, it was a very good dining experience. Can't wait to come back.

7WOJp-pOiCIpMAwyKmX7Bg.text: I've been wanting to try NOLA for a long time, and we finally made it for brunch last weekend. I think New Orleans has the most amazing food scene, and I was so excited that I might get to have some of that food-joy here in Pittsburgh. Unfortunately, we just weren't very impressed.  My husband and father-in-law had the chicken and waffles. It's soooo much chicken--like a huge portion--although it was not specially seasoned which we kinda expected it to be. It was just really good fried chicken. The waffle was good, but not incredible.  My mom had the shrimp dish; I had the crab and asparagus omelet. We both liked our food, but again, we weren't blown away. My daughter liked the french toast although it was a little dry. It comes with a marmalade and a little light sauce, but maybe it needed something a little more liquid-y?  The highlight of my meal was the grits. The GRITS are GREAT although in my opinion, Carmi still has the best grits in town.  I tried one voodoo fry (not gluten-free), and it was good. I'd have more if I could, but I wouldn't go back just to have them.  The service was uneven. The assistant manager greeted us and brought us to our table. She was very nice. Our server was nice, but sometimes it was difficult to get his attention and he kept forgetting things, and as soon as he got another table, he disappeared. I don't think he was a bad waiter, but he wasn't very quick.  Bottom line: Not bad, just not great.

OZ9yuvV9J67NDvyIUeYhtw.text: Knowledgeable and polite service and good food. Had the salmon and etouffe. Good size portion for lunch, great flavor as well. Glad I had the chance to try this place while here on business.

b1Y9DfUVbzUVuTiyJ47m7w.text: Outstanding!  My filet was cooked perfectly, great atmosphere.   I Highly recommend eating here!

5TqIGcLrB893iCkh5HOuGw.text: My taste buds are still strutting and waving white handkerchiefs in my mouth they were so happy today!  My very first visit to NOLA was the first of many more visits to come, for sure.  Three of us walked through downtown on a gorgeous sunny day, through the hip and happenin' farmers' market, past the live music in Market Square and through the wide-open doors of NOLA to quite a crowd.  And no wonder....what fantastic food!  I've had shrimp n grits all over the south...NOLA's was one of the best I've ever experienced....and most certainly the best in Pittsburgh.  Cheesy, Anson Mills stone ground grits, at least 8 or 9 great big ol' sweet, perfectly cooked shrimp, smoky bacon, the classic trinity of celery, bell peppers and onion all played together for a sweet, sweet song of the South in my mouth.    My dining companions both had the NOLA salad.  One had the croque monsieur, the other had the muffaletta.  Both were very, very happy.    Curtis, our server, was friendly and efficient; Ann, one of the managers, stopped at our table to make us feel right at home.  Heck, she even walked me over to the Chef's Table and told me about the special dinners they hold there.  Nice.  Our table was at the back of the restaurant right by the "pass."  The line moved together in harmony to pump out fine food with exquisite attention to detail.  Serving plates were wiped clean of any stray drips before being whisked away to the lucky recipients.    Welcome, NOLA!  Make yourself at home and stay a while....a long, long while.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Catfish sammie and French onion soup get a 2 thumbs up!

7bv3Qi57zw1aO8Bpv3A_0Q.text: Food was good and so were the drinks. This was priced at $$ but it should probably be  $$$. The ribs were way better than I expected. The rib is a beef rib. The firried green tomatoes though....omg they were great! Best ones I have ever had.

cI4FIVakG7gQrd1XdLclzw.text: I had the perfectly cooked, chicory rubbed,medium rare, filet mignon steak with sheered brussel sprouts, and potatoes. I'm in love!! I shall return Chef Emeril to try some more of your dishes. Applause to the start.

md78hhQj__rul2HaFWjz0w.text: What an amazing New Orleans experience! The decor was phenomenal and the live band set it off! The Nola truly captures the Bourbon Street ambiance! Our waitress Cassandra was phenomenal in her menu expertise. Our party included a small child and our waitress was very accommodating to her needs putting a rush on her food and bringing her crackers while we waited. The Drink menu has a great selection of craft beers and speciality drink. The menu is traditional New Orleans  . I highly recommend the frog leg appetizer it was exquisite. I have ate them from many establishments and these were by far the best! I truly enjoyed my experience and felt like I was in the French Quarters!

0G1aXc-Fk2BepzY5zk3SRQ.text: I've been to Nola a few times over the years and it's always been enjoyable. They must be under new management now because the drinks and the service were terrible. We saw one female manager  who either sat at a table watching tv or was yelling at the servers who all seemed like they had no idea what they were doing. It was very uncomfortable. Also who doesn't have luxadaro or amarena for an old fashioned?! Very disappointed about the drinks and the price we paid for them

Wm0t6m_f9g4U0rlkII1VRg.text: The bartender Shane was a friendly gentlemen. The food and service were phenomenal. Shane's energy kept us here all night. It was a great experience.

YBE9k76aO-ojTUz_PIUylQ.text: Super slow.   Came with a table of 8 for brunch and were seated promptly since the restaurant was essentially empty.  Orders were taken and it was a solid 50 minutes before our food arrived.  When we asked about the timing we were given some lame excuse about how there were orders in infront of us, but like I said the restaurant was empty when we got there...  Food ranged from awesome (French toast special) to passable (most everything else).  Service was polite engaged and friendly, but somewhere between the front and the kitchen there were big problems.  I won't come back.

94BUGlFj-HFfWTwThBRkeA.text: Best french onion soup around.  Lunch prices are affordable and this is a cuisine unique to downtown.  Great addition to market square! Plus they participate in LoyalTree mobile rewards program.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

Nm1Yqb-xqJKiMjs097pTNA.text: This place is excellent! My girlfriend and i have been here twice; we sat at the bar both times and both servers were very nice and knowledgeable.   The first time we were there during happy hour and we got the pork belly and the flat bread - both were amazing. The cocktails were very good as well - I had something with jalapenos in it and it was flavorful but very spicy as well.  We ended up going back the next morning to try the beignets - they weren't as good as Cafe Du Monde but they were still worth getting.   I would definitely go back next time I am in Pittsburgh, sounds like the live music would be exciting.

tmqK5gv8VmfkgYi9LSgGLA.text: I've been here twice within 1 week and it has instantly become one of my top 5 favorite restaurants to visit. I'll break down my joy below..  Food: Great! I've been to New Orleans, so I wasn't shocked by some of the offerings since they do seem to try to keep to traditional NOLA foods. The only thing (which they do mention) is that the spiciness is adapated for the Northern palate, so it's not as cajun as you might expect. The best? The red velvet bread pudding changed my world --- seriously, just try it out.  Atmosphere: I love the look, feel, and vibe of this place. It's inviting, jovial, and a lot bigger than you'd expect. I was shocked by how large the inside was. They also play live music in the bar most nights. The only issue was that the one band was incredibly loud and my second visit was near the front of the joint. They allowed the band to continue playing loud and we could barely hear eachother. We even told them about it, and the waiters seemed to agree, but nothing was done. While I appreciated the music, it's still a restaurant and not a club.  Service: Great! Both times it seemed that the waiters enjoyed working there and were nothing but nice.   Price: They are a little expensive. You can get by with a cheaper tab if you stick to their flat breads (starting at $9) and desserts, but you'll definitely end up paying at minimum $15 (most above 20) a plate when you're considering entrees.

aY5k0zm1qy4WwQ97fM4gWA.text: I've been here multiple times now for lunch during the week and it is completely hit or miss.  I've gotten food lunch that I just love and crave and then the next time I come it's terrible.   My "new" biggest beef with this place is that on one visit the server helped himself by upping my tip.  I pay with a credit card and I always tip 20%, I round up for good service and may round down for poor service but never less than 15%.   I had gotten the lunch combo which is around $12, so with tax and tip the total was $16.  My credit card statement showed over $22.   I brought it in the next time I went to eat there to discuss with the manager and he didn't apologize at all and said he couldn't refund me the difference but today's meal would be free.  Which was a little bit more than what I was owed.  The fact that he never said that he was sorry it happened just really irked me.   The fact that the food quality is so inconsistent and that someone on the wait staff stole from me means I will never go back.

bXsrZYw0W_Ara7xyMphlww.text: to people who had problems with their service if you go in their slow times you will see great awesome service! I got french onion soup it wasn't probably traditional but really good. Soup, felt like it took hours. Also, the shrimp were cooked perfectly on the poboy it was very flavorful every bite till the end! shrimp were huge too, and the crunchy breading stayed attached. glad I kinda wimped out on alligator it made me a really happy camper. I know I and other people sometimes substitute on the entree or if you wana call a meal; please dnt take anything off here.  today sorta felt like royalty. but, it's probably more southern than cajun. it is worth trip and money.

GtvlbsE-d1_X2RUnBz1OQQ.text: Certainly a cool spot in Market Square.  A friend and I popped in here on a busy Saturday evening when the Art Fest was going on and were seated immediately with no reservation.  We both enjoyed the jazzmosphere and vibe of the place.  Servers were all super friendly.  The food was a bit pricey, but it is downtown.

yovobmpWcf5Hj6p_ioEWNg.text: Very disappointed in this visit. Went with friends to watch the live music. Hostess told us the bar tall tables were open seating so we waited for one then when we went to sit down, were told there was a list, but that we could have the next one opening up.  Waited again, sat down, then were told that it was promised to someone else too. We finally got up and left. If there's no seats at the bar where they give you great service, best to leave because the hostess has no idea what's going on.

7RD-1OxJvJqMO9dJMix71Q.text: Perfectly balanced Creole cooking. Just the right amount of heat and spice but never overwhelming. Great beer list too. Service was good - not intrusive or forgetful. It was a bit noisy in the front of the restaurant so ask to be seated in the back. The fruit flies were a bit irritating. Otherwise, of was a great experience.

48OMwgyVzlciCHvype2Cfg.text: Food was fantastic, staff was friendly and courteous and overall just a great place. Never been here before but glad we took the chance - will definitely be back again!   We recommend the shrimp po' boy, voodoo fries, and red beans and rice. All were seasoned and cooked to perfection - best food I've had in Pittsburgh so far! Dessert, anyone? The bourbon ball is absolutely amazing - not too sweet and not too much - perfect way to end the meal! Thank you for everything!!!

Sa85rXRh130oGpmOc1HHPw.text: Nola is awesome because of its take on the "mardi gras, New Orleans" atmosphere. The food is definitely what you would expect it to be from alligator to jambalaya.. I personally favor the flatbreads but that's just me. The staff overall is pretty friendly. The outdoor seating is nice when the weather is right and the inside is dim lit and cooler vibe.

pugTykYKEUgIkWdFI_qruA.text: I've never had a bad meal at NOLA. They have great lunch specials (think half po' boy with fries and soup ). They have authentic Cajun cuisine with an atmosphere straight out of the French Quarter. I love that you have the option of traditional creole dishes like frog legs and gator. Plus you can accompany your meal with their take on traditional New Orleans cocktails. NOLA is definitely worth the trip to experience it for yourself.

6KWQW2998oF51gBmUr7LAA.text: Why did I wait so long?  NOLA had been on my radar for sometime but, I just never made it there. Then they had a severe fire in 2014 and was closed for remodeling so when my team chose NOLA for our annual Holiday Luncheon and being that I had never been I was pretty excited.   Once we walked in we were teleported straight to Bourbon Street. I have been to New Orleans and this space has the soul and feel of N'awlins.  Not long after we were seated David K. our server greeted us and took our drink orders. There were six in our party so we decided to start off with some appetizers to share. We ordered the Red Beans & Rice, Fried Green Tomatoes (Abita Amber Ale Batter, Cheddar, Creole Mustard Ranch), Salmon Cake (Basil aioli, pickled red onions, cauliflower and Arugula hash) and Stuffed Mirliton (Chayote squash, catfish cake, trinity, dill bechamel). The red beans & rice and fried green tomatoes were the favorites of the group. The red beans & rice had some spice to them and just enough heat. The fried green tomatoes were delicious as well.  For our lunch entrees my team ordered the Seafood Jambalaya (Cajun Rice, Chicken, Shrimp, Sea Scallops, Andouille), Fish Du Jour and the Cajun Grilled Catfish (fire-roasted sweet peppers and onions, mashed Yukon potato, sauteed spinach, spicy lemongrass-citrus Beurre Noisette). I chose the Gumbo Ya-Ya. It featured chicken, Andouille, okra, File, and steamed rice and I also chose the Shrimp and Grits. It featured shrimp, Trinity, Abita Amber Ale, Anson Mills cheddar grits and smoked bacon) My God! They were both so good!  Everyone raved about their food and said we had to come back! Very rarely does everyone all like their food as we have some picky eaters on our team.  After lunch a few of us went over to the bar for cocktails. I had the 504 Old Fashioned. It has Makers Mark, Peach Schnapps, Peach Bitters and a orange slice. It is strong with a hint of peach. It was quite delicious.  NOLA on the Square has great Creole food and excellent service. I highly recommend them!  Insider Tip: Come for lunch instead of dinner as the entree prices are about half that of the dinner prices.

9dgHVGV9s2QoWy0Dj6HBYg.text: If you have been to the real city of NOLA and had legit Jambalaya be prepared to be disappointed. The fried green tomatoes were good. Don't get the over priced Jambalaya whatever you do. It was dry. My mom liked her shrimp and grits.

OoY1eG7oqePRUjGPYZizyQ.text: Love Cajun food... but this place is not the place.   Very expensive, food is not that great, decent atmosphere.  Service is decent.  Wouldn't come back.

7vGq7iwTbNQNdBWGGRH7Jg.text: I've already given Nola a awesome review for dinner but why not do it again for lunch when it's well deserved. I've been to Nola two times now for lunch and my most recent visit has caused it to climb to the top of my list of favorite lunch spots downtown. Their menu gives you the option to choose between two of the following: half sandwich, salad, or soup. You get the best of both worlds. Why choose just one when you can have both?! My absolute favorite is the Nola salad with the Nola club. It's served with voodoo fries which are probably some of the best fries out there. I've also tried the Caesar salad and the pulled pork po boy but I would not recommend them.

LeZZ2I3WSrydOk2WYboZgg.text: This place is the closest place to authentic New Orleans dishes I've ever had outside of Louisiana. The menu is reasonably priced and service was outstanding! Chris did an excellent job from food descriptions, ensuring drinks were never empty, and great conversation. I will definately be back!!!

vy7rFnTQPSH56XwAaWqIkw.text: Have to say, used to be my favorite place until my recent visit. Plus recently went to new Orleans and this place is far from authentic. The best thing to order is the blackened catfish. The red beans and rice is not authentic at all. More like red beans chili.  I do come here for the live blues bands and some drinks. But I advise you to go to new Orleans for your southern delights.

EKh73Pkzrgi1dNlxnyab3Q.text: I'm from the Gulf Coast and grew up a stones throw from New Orleans. My step-dad is no-shit Cajun. So, I have high standards.   Went for Sunday brunch. This is the run down: + Breakfast grits: ok but I would've liked to have tried them as described on the menu. They were out of peaches.  - Gumbo: too mild for authentic gumbo.  + Fried Green Tomatoes: really good, but I would've opted for remoulade instead of ranch.  + Bloody Mary bar: nice touch but it would've been nice to have toothpicks for the olives and pickles and such.  - Strawberry Shortcake Waffles: good but too spongy.  + Beignets and coffee: the beignets were really good but a little small. I'm used to Cafe du Monde where the beignets are pretty big. But these stood up in taste. The coffee was a little weak.  - Chicory coffee: iced chicory coffee? Wtf? In my humble opinion, chicory coffee should never be iced.   Other than that, the service was a little slow but things were good. I'll have to come back and try them for lunch or dinner and see how they really stack up.

lbqzqupRVZslnstmnXuCfA.text: Heard great things about NOLA. Decided to go for lunch. The waiter was non existent until he decided to come over and tell us their card machine is broken and we can't leave until it's fixed bc no one can pay yet. I'm sorry, im on a lunch break and can't sit around while you trouble shoot something. Now everyone eating is getting angry he legit vanishes. Had to go up to the bar where they said you can leave us your credit card number (no thanks) so I ran to get cash out. They requested everyone's contact information for the owner. The owner called half of our group to apologize and mail a gift card and never called the rest of us.

yqMAQllpu56pYLMKNu5Oqw.text: Had beers with a friend at the bar. Then we got hungry and ordered two apps: The pork sliders were awesome and the voodoo fries were delicious!   This was my first time here but it will be my last :)

7rq5i9I1CH_ujUVG02gIpQ.text: The servers are really nice. I came during happy hour and ordered the red beans and rice ($1) and the Catfish Fingers ($3)  1st- the beans had the right flavor (being from New Orleans I grew up on this dish) but the beans were not cooked all the way. I do feel sorry for my intestines when they have to break them down. They were way harder than canned beans, and need 30more mins in the pot  The fish was pleasing, I love the presentation of both dishes. I would love to give this more than 2 stars but I know that they should do way better. I'm no chief but I know good cooked food when I taste it.   I did let the server know about the bean and she was very understanding. Feedback is always the key!

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Red beans and rice with catfish fingers

o68oEpPt7Ct0npizk-CGLw.text: The service was awful.  Server did not take drink orders.  Waited and waited to get any service.  Food did come quickly and flatbreads and fried green tomatoes were tasty and came efficiently.  However the service was almost non-existent.  Beware. We lost an hour in waiting for various service.

dQpnFPO3jL4zBC737jOi8w.text: Been here several times and each time I try something new and find something I like whether its a salad, sandwich or calzone. Because its a New Orlean's style restaurant, it goes without saying there will be creole, jumbalaya and catfish.  What most people are worried about before eating here is whether there is food here that does not fit those categories or isn't spicy and the answer is yes.    First off, the fries are great - perfectly crispy, salty, peppery and maybe some creole in there for a side that no one will deny is fantastic.  The NOLA club is a nice twist on the club sandwich, turkey on ciabatta, with spicy aeoli, some crisp bacon, pickled tomatoes and little bit of avacado: A safe move done in a way that makes it exciting. The steak salad is also a good move for those with tenuous affinities for spice but with little flairs to make it unique.  Each dish here is tastefully created and consistently delivered.  The atmosphere is nice and is intended to make one dream of Mardi Gras but patron's won't forget that Pittsburgh is right outside. The service is friendly but nothing to write home about.  Overall the food is a 5 but with the service and slightly-above-generic atmosphere, the place gets a solid 4 in my books.

a6wI9IAfU-rVwBzGembbpQ.text: Was in the mood for classic Cajun & Creole ... NOLA was just the ticket! Ordered the Oyster Po' Boy. Oysters were jumbo, fried to perfection. Lunch service was quick and friendly. It came With a side of Voodoo fries - they tasted just like the voodoo chips they have everywhere in New Orleans! I will go back!

HqkqujD52Zlw3Wr3-7_suw.text: Had a very nice dinner there traveling in for business. I grew up in New Orleans and this place is certainly upscale Cajun/Creole. I had the half of Cajun duck plate. The actual duck was cooked perfectly and tasted amazing. The vegetable that came with it were good but some of the sauce over it wasn't my style. Not bad just took away from the duck. All in all a pleasant experience.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pretty plate for sure.

ADQtjPyn4XCVjfppu7_Wdw.text: I've been to NOLA several times over the years, and I've never had a bad meal. Great beer selection, good mixed drinks, and delicious food.  My wife and I are suckers for good oysters, and they know how to pick me. I'm particularly fond of their gumbo and PO boy sandwiches. You can get a nice side salad for lunch with your meal as well.  Regarding brunch I've had the beignets which are wonderful and the pancake special is always good from my experience. To top it off their coffee is delicious.  For my money, one of the best sit down options in Market Square, or downtown for that matter.

bvGneVIlJZy0yGujESDvQw.text: So many choices to choose from the fried green tomatoes where really good, the drinks are wonderful and the flat bread...wanted to order the beans and rice didn't leave room for it...I will go back and just order beans and rice.

8oNlkdGGl6JsK1IjYOq69g.text: It's been awhile since my husband and I had eaten here..7 years actually.  It was much better 7 years ago.  The fried alligator the first time was actual pieces of alligator- about the size of chicken nuggets.  We remembered how good it was that we ordered it again this time.  What a disappointment.  The waitress set the rectangular plate down on our table and my husband and I looked at each other and said what the hell is that? It looked like a pile of granola on one end.  The pieces were literal crumbles.. you couldn't even poke a fork in one.  Or taste any meat.  It was all breading.  For our entree we both ordered the sea food pot pie.. it was ok... super salty... more veggies and diced potatoes than seafood.  Silver lining, my glass of Reisling was superb.

cLTpe5YfZTDCGmoD4qaR4A.text: Def not authentic New Orleans style food. We had their Bloody Mary, which tasted like Tabasco sauce. Their gumbo and shrimp and grits tasted like someone from up north make the recipe. Upset as we were looking forward to having authentic Cajun food. We will not return back.

LfFP0DlikSic_6pMI_49rg.text: Food is good. Service and friendly attitude? Not so much. We were visited infrequently and rushed out.

Z94XvwTzGWMCgpOT1yMaHA.text: NOLA is a hidden treasure! I have only been here once, but the environment was awesome and the staff is super friendly! I went during their happy hour (mon 5-7, tues-fri 4-7). They have $4 grapefruit mules! I don't know if this changes ever, but it was delicious, and you rarely find mules on happy hour menus, so this was a plus (also deciding factor)! They have a happy hour menu with select apps and drinks and everything is $4 with 1/2 off flatbreads as well ($5-$6). Pro tip - sit inside because they don't do happy hour outside. I also ordered the Cajun Aricini, having no idea what to expect, but they were so good! The crust was a little salty, but they were basically fried balls of rice and Cajun sausage and they're huge! I will definitely have to revisit NOLA!

KarYPaYi-eXxIbAscgBniA.text: My pulled pork Po Boy was good but arrived completely cold. I had to send it back and wait for them to bring me another. My husband ordered the shrimp Po Boy which came with exactly 4 shrimp. They were large, but it looked scarce. It was an average experience. Too bad, we were so excited about the restaurant.

C68BLeYCwnSqQZ19vN6xVg.text: Nice atmosphere and generally a good place for drinks after work. I took some coworkers yesterday and sat at the bar waiting 20 mins for a drink. Two waiters came by and said someone would be with us soon, but didn't offer drinks or to find someone to help. The two of them waited on a table of 4 together and the hostess just stared at us rather than finding a bartender. There were 10 people in the place, 4 with two waiters and the rest of us left wondering why we were wasting our time. We ended up leaving and going to City Works next door, which actually took our money rather than stare at us.

Btf5EJYl7jv4nrDO0g5SmA.text: Horribly slow service. Our waitress screwed up everyone's order . Food was god awful. Waitress convinced me to order chicken and dumplings, and I cannot describe how horrible it was. Lukewarm, and the dumplings were like flour glue, but burned on the outside.    I could not tell what was chicken and what was dumpling. Bland. Horrible. Even my side salad was horrible. Soggy and wilted. If this wasn't a work-sponsored dinner, I would have sent it back. They brought free dessert, which they toured as "homemade". The beignets were horrible too. Not soft at all. Disgusting restaurant all around.

_Am-EeDnaqdSt6hcdfspLw.text: This place was aight. I hated the music choice due to it being a New Orleans inspired place but whatever. I got the shrimp and grits. The flavor was pretty good. A nice smokey kind of flavor. I don't know if I would say this is a place you need to go to but if you stumble into this place with two drinks in you will be pleased.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Shrimp and grits

ZUVimMKE0GqPjyIFpfuS9g.text: I used to pass by this place all the time when I lived downtown years ago. Having been to New Orleans, my curiosity got the best of me and I went here with two other people for lunch.  So, what's the deal...  Imagine you've never been to New Orleans but you want to open a restaurant that serves Creole, Cajun, and southern food in general and you want to do it right here in Pittsburgh - where we are known for putting french fries on salad (and on everything else) and coming up with "innovative" ways of ripping off interesting cuisine, namely from other cultures (looking at you DeShantz, Kucenic). Okay, now imagine you hire people who have no idea how to cook this food but function only in being belligerent.  Okay, so maybe that doesn't sum it all up for you so let me paint you a picture:  Nobody from New Orleans would ever go to this place - that much I know. So who is this place for? Think some yinzer from South Hills. Brentwood specifically. Born and raised but he tells everyone he's from Pittsburgh. This guy has never been anywhere else, ever, and he prefers it that way. Downtown is scary still but at least they got rid of all the homeless people in Market Square, he hopes. He's a simple man and enjoys few things but one of those things is Pittsburgh. The other thing he loves is some real authentic fancy food and what better place to find that then right here, dahntahn. This guy's idea of good eating is sweet sauce style spaghetti and meatballs, just like grandma Cercones used to make so imagine the ego-boner this dude gets when he rolls up to NOLA and sees some gator on the menu - here in Pittsburgh! And it's fresh, you know, what with our close access to swamps. 5 stars! And he's gonna tell all his buddies at the moose lodge too!

McamOJMD6GCxo-NNSCNssg.text: Came here for happy hour and was not disappointed! We got the captain mojitos which has new flavors every few weeks. We had the grapefruit one and it was so good!! We also got some $4 appetizers which were satisfying. We had the cajun andouille and Cajun cheesesticks. The Cajun andouille was pretty good-- not very standout and a little bland but good with the sauce. The cheesesticks were as expected but not much Cajun flavor. Would definitely return here for the drinks but maybe not the food.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Happy hour: Captain mojito (grapefruit) $4
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Happy hour: Cajun cheesesticks $4

YyPrTPjq6VpPLtNjgYBBcg.text: THE CRAWFISH MAC AND CHEESE. Their happy hour has great specials and the food is a great take on Nola cuisine.

bgjvCcRcAZItuZJOrctuVg.text: I've not been to NOLA since they first opened and I loved it then. But what was I thinking waiting so long to get back?? Seriously I know we're becoming a foodie city and have so many choices but this restaurant is a staple; New Orleans style. The decor is a chic take on the French Quarter with a superior wait staff and quality management style. The food is simply fantastic. Fried green tomatoes sprinkled with shredded white cheddar and drizzled in a hearty ranch mayo. The grilled chicken and dumplings---scrumptious! Ricotta dumplings with peas, wild mushrooms and carrots in a flavorful sauce. Chicken is grilled with fragrant spices that bring Bourbon Street to mind. If you're like me and not been in forever or have never been, you need to get there to enjoy what they have to offer.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Ricotta dumpling.
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Grilled chicken and dumplings.
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Grilled chicken and dumplings.

UyiWQ_hqWa7f0JlzqIeHQw.text: (Happy hour review only)  I've only been to NOLA for their Happy Hour... and I've got to say I was very happy during that hour!  Their drink options are average, eh, not bad....BUT food prices blow me away!  Gumbo for $1.  Rice and bean, also $1.  Half off their flatbreads (margarita was great, the other one was way too oily).  It's probably all I will ever want from NOLA.  I will be interested to return on a lunch hour next.

bUKc3ILQChnuz1XQPzuEEg.text: What a cool place. The live music brought my friend and I in on a Friday night. We sat at the bar and our bartender immediately greeted us and was very inviting and friendly.   My friend had a couple glasses of wine and I was in the mood for beer, so I tried hop gator by Abita Ales. Being the beer nerd that I am, I noticed that a lot of their featured "seasonals" were not very seasonal at all- at least three of them had release dates in early spring . BUT hop gator was quite good. Smooth and it was served in a fancy little beer glass.   We weren't planning on eating but one of the bartenders gave us a menu and I couldn't help but look. I saw fried green tomatoes and had to order them. I also ordered the New Orleans style BBQ shrimp because I was curious how their seafood was- being a New Orleans themed restaurant and all.   Yum. The shrimp was amazing! Perfectly cooked and seasoned! The sauce was amazing! The fried green tomatoes were good as well but not the best that I had. Wouldn't order them again. The shrimp alone is why I will come back and try some more New Orleans goodies!

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. New Orleans style BBQ shrimp!
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Fried green tomatoes!
Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beer! Hop gator

dbR-tgc7p-b83ZyUsMLXIA.text: I checked out this restaurant on a Saturday night, and it had a very lively atmosphere. There was live music at the restaurant and a community market going on in market square. Our food and drinks took realllly long, but the atmosphere made up for the wait. Upon request, they have a separate menu of vegan and vegetarian options. The fried green tomatoes were delishhhh and so was the squash salad. The couscous dish from the vegan menu was below average. The bread pudding dessert was AMAZING highly recommend. Cool place and I would go again :)

wn3192bReDW82Ky5o-UgAA.text: Enjoy the seafood pot pie with no seafood , excellent for vegans. I also appreciated the lobster who waved at the seafood pot pie from a couple of meters before they closed the pie. I think I wrote a review 6 years ago but this was worthy writing a new one.

CcoBHyr7klD3bSihFUblHw.text: Fairly descent Cajun/Creole food, but quite pricey.  Considered more 'upscale', which I find funny.  Good drinks, great location and has charm.  They have live entertainment and their brunch is worth checking out. Drink specials and they are strong :-)

qvk-C3RapWKaQ1ooV1mSEA.text: I will try to make this short and to the point.   I was in town for business and decided to give this place a try...   First and foremost, the food was decent, but nothing special. It's a little overpriced, but it's downtown Pittsburgh so that's to be expected.   What I didn't expect was the  unprofessional and bizarre service I received.   The restaurant has a mature business atmosphere, but the two young males I dealt with in particular, were not suited for this environment.   Normally, when I attend a restaurant of this caliber, the staff knows how to articulate and address their guess with respect.   These two individuals, the host (who came to my table often) and my waiter, kept talking to me in a manner as if I were one their PlayStation or Xbox buddies.   For example, these two individuals would say things like:   "Man, you want something to drink, dude?"  "Umm... You ready to order yet, man?"  "Umm... You need anything else, dude?"  "Man, you want a bag or something, man?   It wasn't anything overly egregious, but I kept scratching my head, because it was just weird and unprofessional.   Here I am, a paying customer, in business attire, in a business atmosphere and I'm being addressed with little to no respect.   At one point, I thought maybe this was part of the theme of the restaurant, but I doubt it.   For the record...   I'm sure a few people will read this and will automatically assume that these two young men were African American or minorities...   That would be inaccurate.   These two young men, we're both Caucasian males from Pittsburgh....  Be that as it may, although I received mediocre service at best, I still managed to give my waiter a generous tip based on the required gratuity percentage of my overall bill.   Again, the food was decent, but I don't expect to spend any more of my hard earned money at this establishment. I don't see myself returning.

Mk_tOQOTSwgCQrdl4gO_Jg.text: I was really excited to come upon New Orleans cuisine in Pittsburgh, but I should have known: good Creole cuisine is hard to find outside of the Big Easy. Having been to New Orleans, I had an idea of what the food should taste like, and was sorely disappointed. I came around brunch and was really excited to see beignets with a chicory coffee dip as an option. That was an obvious choice. But as a main, at the recommendation of one of the waiters (not the one that was helping me), I decided on the shrimp and grits (was thrilled to see they use Anson Mill grits!) The shrimp and grits came first, smelled amazing... and that's where the excitement stopped. It was four small pieces of shrimp, swimming in a pool of spiced salt, with a small cake of grits hidden underneath. The salt content was unbelievable. It's been a long time since I've eaten ANYTHING that salty. And when I mentioned it to the waiter who had suggested it, all he had to say was "Oh, that's why I like it". Great. I didn't even finish it. Suddenly I was really looking forward to the beignets. But the first course should have been an indicator of the quality I was going to get. The beignets were soggy, with the icing sugar just soaking into the dough... not hot and fluffy, like they do in New Orleans. This was a very poor imitation.  The icing on the entire meal, though, had to be my very unenthusiastic waiter, who clearly would have rather been anywhere else but there. Aside from introducing himself, very little was said and not once did I see even a hint of a smile. After receiving my food, he disappeared for a long while, I even had to go inside (I had been sitting outside) so I could ask for my bill because I didn't know where he'd been. All in all, a very disappointing experience from start to finish.

Yyl74OivxjcH6gOGBA55Ow.text: We stopped here while killing some time before Tako opened up at 3pm on a Sunday afternoon and came away  happy with our experience. We only ordered a couple of drinks but would've ordered food from their menu had we not intended to eat elsewhere. Their menu looked pretty good.

5yUYlc4snuu4HkvfQQSQuQ.text: Limited menu but everything sounded amazing. I settled with the seafood jambalaya-DELICIOUS! Great portion size and generous with the seafood compared to the price. I came during a cocktail hour on a Tuesday which resulted in a bit of a wait but I'm glad I was patient

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

4gynjHudFoK-K0a-8r5jyg.text: Went to dinner with an old friend from school. Appetizers Friend Green Tomatoes and Alligator were very good. Drinks took forever to come. Dinner portions were varied...but dishes: Jambalya and Chk n Waffles were quite tasty. Second round of drinks came quicker and were better than the firsts.   Enjoyed the live music.   Will patron again to try new dishes.   Pretty pricey.

rZDd6c5HYfXCHkJd-sHYvA.text: Terrible service on Take Your Child To Work Day, 4/26/2018. Waited for food for 50+ minutes, which never came. Server didn't bother to give us any update. Finally, when he did, he blamed the kitchen. My daughter was terribly disappointed with the experience. I am not sure if I'll ever put my feet on that place again.

ZL7BMiSj6Khw62Az3XoYUA.text: My first visit to NOLA was mediocre, my second visit, during lunch, was unexpectedly pleasant. My review here covers my second experience.  All 3 people in my party had the half sandwich/half salad/voodoo fries combination or a variation thereof.  Veggie lovers take note: The salad with watermelon and arugula was delicious! I really liked my smoked turkey Cuban (a little heavy on the meat), and the voodoo fries are good. My companions would recommend NOLA's jambalaya as well.  For $12 each, our meals were good and the price point is VERY competitive among the other restaurants serving the downtown lunch crowd. I will be back!

77I7LrXWtplUwUreMMir7A.text: The Frog Legs are 2 die 4! And then the Oyster Stew with artichokes! Great ambiance, artwork and cool hanging lamps! An eminent hipster's paradise! Delicious.

photos.caption: Photo of NOLA - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beautiful artwork and ambiance.

JA7vtnnwUOpK7VTqczEm4A.text: A little taste of Creole! Enjoyed the oyster poboy although it was a bit expensive- $15! Fries with Cajun seasoning were fantastic!
